questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlorine compound

 

Sodium hypochlorite, a compound of chlorine, is the best disinfectant for surface blood spills. It is used with a concentration of 0.5-5%.

 

If the spill contains large amounts of blood or body fluids, clean the visible matter with disposable absorbent material and discard the contaminated materials in appropriate, labelled containment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenolic compound: Phenolic compounds are effective disinfectants but are generally less effective against a broad spectrum of bloodborne pathogens compared to chlorine compounds.

 

Option C. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Quaternary ammonium compounds are good for general disinfection but are not recommended for blood spills as they are less effective against non-enveloped viruses and spores.

 

Option D. Alcoholic compounds: Alcohol-based disinfectants are effective for surface disinfection but are not ideal for blood spills as they can coagulate proteins, making blood more difficult to clean.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cleaning a blood spill in the operation theatre, sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant due to its effectiveness in inactivating a wide range of pathogens and its suitability for such critical environments.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bainbridge reflex

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Option C. Cushing Reflex: Cushing reflex is a protective reflex that helps save the brain tissues from ischemic effects during the periods of reduced cerebral blood flow. It is also called Cushing reaction, response or phenomenon.

 

Option D. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is a cardiovascular reflex that increases heart rate in response to increased venous return, enhancing cardiac output to match the increased blood flow into the heart.

choices.text: Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation
Reduced cardiac contractility
Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume
Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure

questions.text: A patient with Prinzmetal angina is administered isosorbide mononitrate and is noticed to have symptomatic relief. What is the mechanism of action of nitrate in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endothelium independent coronary vasodilation

 

Nitrates cause endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation when treating Prinzmetal angina.

 

Coronary artery vasospasm is the underlying cause of Prinzmetal angina. By relaxing the smooth muscles of the epicardial coronary arteries, nitrates treat coronary artery spasm.

 

The main mechanism of action of nitrates in the event of stable angina is preferred vein dilation (by increasing cGMP). Venous return to the heart is reduced as a result of venous dilatation (preload). Due to the reduction in ventricular end-diastolic volume, myocardial oxygen consumption also reduces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduced cardiac contractility: This is not the primary mechanism of action of nitrates in relieving Prinzmetal angina. Nitrates primarily work by vasodilation rather than affecting myocardial contractility.

 

Option C. Increased left ventricular end diastolic volume: Nitrates generally reduce the preload (venous return) by dilating veins, which can lead to a decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume, not an increase.

 

Option D. Decreased diastolic perfusion pressure: While nitrates can lower blood pressure, the primary therapeutic effect in Prinzmetal angina is not related to diastolic perfusion pressure but to the direct vasodilation of the coronary arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitrates provide symptomatic relief in Prinzmetal angina through endothelium-independent coronary vasodilation, which helps to alleviate coronary artery spasms and restore proper blood flow to the heart muscle.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps with persistent low mood. Which of the following would be the best investigation for a definitive diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sestamibi scan

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features of 40-year-old woman with bone pain and abdominal cramps along with persistent low mood is suggestive of hypercalcemia, which could be due to primary Hyperparathyroidism.

 

IOC for parathyroid adenoma: Tc99-Sestamibi scan

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While useful for detailed soft tissue imaging, MRI is not the first choice for detecting parathyroid adenomas.

 

Option C. Ultrasonogram: Can be used to locate parathyroid adenomas but has limitations in sensitivity and specificity compared to the Sestamibi scan.

 

Option D. CT scan (Computed Tomography): Provides good anatomic detail but is less specific than the Sestamibi scan for parathyroid adenomas and is not the primary diagnostic tool for suspected hyperparathyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a definitive diagnosis in patients presenting with symptoms indicative of hypercalcemia and suspected primary hyperparathyroidism, a Sestamibi scan is the investigation of choice due to its specificity and ability to perform detailed scintigraphic imaging.

choices.text: 50 mg
30.5 mg
12.5 mg

questions.text: How much drug will be left after 6 hours if a patient is given a dose of 200 mg and 75 mg is excreted in 90 minutes. (Assume that the drug follows first-order kinetics)?  (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 30.5 mg

 

This question can be solved by two methods.

 

Method 1: Using the fraction method

In 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time.

75 mg is excreted in 90 mins.

Therefore 75/200 = 3/8th of the drug is eliminated in 90 minutes.

Thus after 90 minutes, 1-3/8 = 5/8th portion of the drug is left behind.

6 hours = 4 * 90 minutes.

Or, in 6 hrs = (5/8) * (5/8) *(5/8)*(5/8)* 200 mg will be left behind

= 30.518 mg will be left behind.

 

Method 2: Using the formula

First we need to determine the elimination rate constant (k) and the half-life (t1/2) of the drug.

We know that 75 mg of the drug is excreted in 90 minutes (1.5 hours). This means that the amount remaining after 1.5 hours is 200 mg - 75 mg = 125 mg.

First, we can use the formula for first-order kinetics to find k:

k = {log (C0/Ct)} / t​

Where:

  • C0 ​is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • Ct ​is the concentration after time t (125 mg)
  • t is the time in hours (1.5 hours)

k = {log⁡ (200/125)} / 1.5

k={log⁡(1.6)} / 1.5

k ≈ 0.470/1.5

k ≈ 0.313 hr−1

Next, we find the half-life using the relationship between k and t1/2:

t1/2 = 0.693 /k

t1/2 ​= 0.693​/0.313

t1/2 = 2.21 hours

Now, we need to determine the amount of drug left after 6 hours. We use the first-order kinetics formula:

Ct = C0 × e−kt

Where:

  • C0 is the initial concentration (200 mg)
  • k is the elimination rate constant (0.313 hr^-1)
  • t is the time (6 hours)

Ct = 200 × e−0.313×6

Ct = 200 × e−1.878

Ct = 200 × 0.153

Ct ≈ 30.5 mg

choices.text: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin-mediated? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septicemia

 

Septicemia (also known as bloodstream infection) caused by Staphylococcus aureus is not mediated by toxins but by the direct invasion of the bloodstream by the bacterial organisms. This leads to the systemic immune response, triggering widespread inflammation, resulting in the clinical manifestations of sepsis such as fever, hypotension, and organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Food poisoning: Food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus is mediated by enterotoxins, which are pre-formed toxins in contaminated food. Symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea occur rapidly after ingestion due to these toxins.

 

Option B. Toxic shock syndrome: Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a toxin-mediated condition caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), produced by Staphylococcus aureus. This exotoxin leads to severe systemic symptoms like fever, rash, hypotension, and multiorgan dysfunction.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): SSSS is mediated by the exfoliative toxin, which causes separation of the epidermis, leading to widespread blistering and skin peeling, mimicking a burn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septicemia caused by Staphylococcus aureus is an infection due to bacterial invasion and is not toxin-mediated, whereas conditions like food poisoning, toxic shock syndrome, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome are caused by staphylococcal toxins.

choices.text: Do a routine episiotomy
Manual support to the perineum to maintain flexion of the head
Never give warm compress to the perineum
Perform labor in lithotomy position

questions.text: Which of the following is part of the WHO recommendations for managing the second stage of labor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Manual support to the perineum to maintain flexion of the head

 

The WHO guidelines for the management of the second stage of labor recommend manual support to the perineum and controlled delivery of the fetal head. This method, also known as guarding the perineum, reduces the risk of perineal trauma by preventing rapid delivery of the head. Gentle downward pressure is applied on the occiput to control the speed of delivery, and once the occiput is born, the rest of the head is delivered with gentle assistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Do a routine episiotomy: Routine episiotomy is not recommended by the WHO. Episiotomies should be reserved for specific conditions, such as shoulder dystocia, breech deliveries, or fetal macrosomia. The procedure is not to be routinely performed because it can increase the risk of unnecessary trauma.

 

Option C. Never give warm compress to the perineum: This statement is incorrect. The WHO suggests using warm compresses to the perineum during labor to reduce the risk of perineal tears and improve maternal comfort during the delivery.

 

Option D. Perform labor in lithotomy position: While the lithotomy position is commonly used, the WHO recommends allowing the woman to choose her position during labor, including upright positions (such as squatting or standing), which are associated with improved outcomes and less perineal trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO recommends manual support of the perineum during the second stage of labor to reduce perineal trauma. Routine episiotomies should be avoided unless clinically necessary.

questions.text: Silent choroid on FFA is a feature of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stargardt's disease

 

Silent choroid / Dark choroid on FFA is a feature of Stargardt's disease.

 

 

The 'silent choroid' or 'dark choroid' phenomenon is caused by the obscuration of the background choroidal fluorescence due to diffuse abnormalities in the retinal epithelium (RE). The accumulation of lipofuscin within the RE is a hallmark feature of Stargardt disease / Fundus flavimaculatus (FFM), which is the most prevalent type of macular dystrophy.

 

Signs:

 

  • The macula may initially be normal, later progressing to an oval 'snail slime' or 'beaten bronze appearance and subsequently to geographic atrophy.
  • Numerous yellow-white round, oval or fish-shaped lesions are seen at the level of the RPE.

 

Investigations:

 

  • Visual fields show central loss
  • FFA - Dark choroid, the macula shows mixed hyper and hypofluorescence. Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA). shows hypofluorescent spots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Best's disease: This condition is characterized by the accumulation of lipofuscin-like material within the RPE but does not typically feature a silent choroid on FFA.

 

Option C. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD): AMD is associated with drusen and neovascular changes rather than a silent choroid.

 

Option D. Cystoid macular edema: This involves swelling of the macular region of the retina due to fluid accumulation in the cystoid spaces, not linked with the silent choroid phenomenon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The silent choroid or dark choroid on FFA is a distinctive feature of Stargardt's disease, caused by lipofuscin accumulation in the retinal pigment epithelium, which blocks the normal choroidal fluorescence. Recognizing this feature is crucial in diagnosing and differentiating Stargardt’s disease from other macular disorders.

questions.text: All are reduced in Iron Deficiency Anemia except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TIBC

 

In Iron Deficiency Anemia, Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) is increased in order to compensate to the deficient state.

 

Iron deficiency anemia –

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin: Ferritin is an intracellular protein that stores iron and releases it in a controlled fashion. In IDA, ferritin levels drop as iron stores are exhausted.

 

Option C. Iron: Serum Iron reflects the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. In IDA, serum iron levels are reduced because iron stores are depleted.

 

Option D. Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin that is saturated with iron. In IDA, it is reduced because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of microcytic anemia:-

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1231-1234

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paralysis agitans

 

The substantia nigra is the marked structure in the transverse section of the brain that is shown. Degeneration of the substantia nigra is observed in Parkinson's disease, commonly referred to as paralysis agitans.

 

Due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which aid in the manufacture of dopamine, the substantia nigra is pigmented. The substantia nigra lacks or has less pigmentation in Parkinson's disease.

 

Parkinson's disease is characterized by bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors. It's also known as paralysis agitans due to the motor dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: Incorrect because depression is typically associated with dysfunctions in other brain regions such as the prefrontal cortex and limbic system, not specifically the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Alzheimer’s disease: Incorrect as Alzheimer's disease primarily involves the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, leading to amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, rather than specific damage to the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Huntington chorea: Incorrect because Huntington’s disease involves degeneration of the striatum and other parts of the brain but does not primarily affect the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra's degeneration is central to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease, manifesting as motor symptoms like bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been admitted with symptoms of altered sensorium and hydrophobia, indicating a potential case of rabies, you have obtained corneal scrapings for further investigation. Now, which test would you select to establish a conclusive diagnosis of the condition? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Viral Culture

 

Altered sensorium and hydrophobia is suggestive of rabies which can be diagnosed by viral culture from corneal scrapings.

 

 

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually, Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

 

Virus isolation through culture: best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears and centrifuged urine can also be used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

 

Option B: Seller stain for negri bodies can only be demonstrated in brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon's horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

 

Option D: Real time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect virus in fresh saliva samples, skin, CS, and brain tissues. However, it is not confirmatory test.

 

Educational Objective

 

Viral culture from corneal scrapings is the most definitive test for diagnosing rabies in a patient presenting with altered sensorium and hydrophobia.

choices.text: HRT to induce puberty

questions.text: A 18-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea, no breast development and Prader 3 genitalia was found to have raised FSH. Her karyotype revealed 45 X0/46 XY and an ultrasound revealed Mullerian structures with poorly visualized gonads. What would be the next line of management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bilateral gonadectomy

 

  • This patient has gonadal dysgenesis with virilization (Prader 3 classification is used to describe the degree of virilization of external genitalia)

 

 

  • If a Y-chromosome is identified during evaluation of primary amenorrhoea, laparoscopic prophylactic gonadectomy is recommended at the time of diagnosis to eliminate the risk of malignancy as dysgenetic gonads have a very high risk of malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. HRT to induce puberty: After gonadectomy, then HRT can be given for secondary sexual development

 

Option D. Clitoroplasty and Option A. vaginoplasty and other surgeries to correct the virilization may be required but the immediate next step would be to do gonadectomy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Whenever there is 46XY with primary amenorrhoea, always gonadectomy needs to be done in view of high risk of malignancy in dysgenetic gonads

 

Ref: Speroff’s Textbook of Reproductive Medicine

questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the green muscles marked? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Depression

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in green is the lateral pterygoid muscle, and its primary function among the given options is depression of the mandible (opening the mouth). "Depression is brought about mainly by the lateral pterygoid" and it is "indispensible for actively opening the mouth."

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  • Depression of the mandible (primary active opener of the mouth)
  • Protrusion of the mandible
  • When one side contracts, it turns the chin to the opposite side

 

While the digastric, geniohyoid, and mylohyoid muscles assist in depression, they primarily help when the mouth is opened wide or against resistance. The lateral pterygoid is the main muscle responsible for actively opening the mouth during normal function.
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protrusion:

 

  • Protrusion refers to the forward movement of the lower jaw (mandible).
  • The lateral along with medial pterygoid muscle are responsible for protruding the mandible. When this muscle contracts on both sides, it causes the jaw to move forward.

 

Option B. Elevation:

 

  • Elevation refers to the upward movement of the mandible, closing the mouth.
  • The primary muscles responsible for jaw elevation are the masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid muscles. The lateral pterygoid's main function is not jaw elevation but rather protrusion.

 

Option D. Retraction:

 

  • Retraction refers to the backward movement of the mandible.
  • The primary muscles involved in jaw retraction are the temporalis and the posterior fibers of the digastric muscle. The lateral pterygoid is not primarily responsible for this movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: A baby in the NICU is being evaluated for his features of microcephaly and hepatomegaly. CT scan revealed nodular periventricular calcifications. Congenital CMV infection is suspected. Which of the following samples is the best to detect the organism using PCR? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urine

 

Urine is the best sample to send for the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus infection among the following options.

 

CMV can be detected using either PCR or culture. Saliva, urine, or blood can be used to collect the sample.

 

  • Clinical features:
    1. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR)
    2. Prematurity
    3. Microcephaly
    4. Intracranial calcifications (Periventricular)
    5. Chorioretinitis
    6. Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL)
    7. Hepatosplenomegaly
    8. Jaundice
    9. Blueberry-muffin-like rash
    10. Thrombocytopenia, purpura
    11. Mild increases in CSF protein

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver biopsy: In any of the TORCH infection, liver biopsy is not the investigation of choice. Live biopsy is the gold standard investigation of choice in Wilson disease.

 

Option B. CSF: In case of suspected meningitis we do CSF, not in TORCH profile

 

Option C. Blood: In this question blood sample is not the right option. If the question was regarding diagnosing of congenital varicella infection, then the right choice would be ANTI – VZV – ANTIBODY

 

Educational Objective:


Urine is the most appropriate sample for the detection of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection using PCR, particularly in the neonatal period.

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given slide stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute angled branching aspergillus

 

The given slide stained with GMS shows acute-angled (45°) uniform, branching septate hyphae which is suggestive of Aspergillus species.

 

Aspergillus species grow rapidly, producing aerial hyphae that bear characteristic conidial structures. Long aseptate conidiophores are seen with terminal vesicles on which phialides are arranged in basipetal chains.

 

The following image shows LPCB mount of Aspergillus fumigatus showing the long conidiophores with terminal vesicles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obtuse angled mucor: Mucor produces non-septate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium.

 

Option B. Acute angled penicillium: Penicillium produces septate hyphae with branched, septate and brush-like conidiophores.

 

Option D. Obtuse angled Rhizopus: Rhizopus appears similar to Mucor but it has rhizoids with sporangiophores arising in groups directly above the rhizoids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gomori methenamine silver (GMS) stain shows characteristic features of Aspergillus species. These features include acute-angled (45°) uniform branching septate hyphae.

choices.text: Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status

questions.text: In breast cancer, FISH for gene amplification will be done based on which of the following IHC staining for Her-2/neu? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2+

 

In the context of breast cancer, the Her-2/neu status is typically assessed by Immunohistochemistry (IHC). The Her-2/neu protein overexpression is graded on a scale of 0 to 3+ based on the intensity and completeness of membrane staining. This grading is crucial in guiding further testing and treatment decisions.

 

  • IHC 0 or 1+: These scores indicate no or low levels of Her-2/neu expression, respectively. Tumors with these scores are considered Her-2 negative, and no further testing for gene amplification is typically needed.
  • IHC 2+: This score is considered equivocal. When a tumor shows a 2+ result on IHC, it suggests an intermediate level of Her-2/neu expression. Because this result is not definitively positive or negative, Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization (FISH) testing is recommended to assess for gene amplification of Her-2/neu. FISH is a more sensitive and specific test that directly detects the amplification of the Her-2/neu gene, providing definitive information about the tumor's status.
  • IHC 3+: A score of 3+ indicates a high level of Her-2/neu protein overexpression. Tumors with this score are considered Her-2 positive and typically do not require further FISH testing, as the overexpression is sufficient to warrant Herceptin (trastuzumab) therapy.

 

Herceptin is a targeted therapy that specifically inhibits the Her-2/neu receptor, which is overexpressed in some breast cancers, leading to more aggressive tumor behavior. Therefore, determining the correct Her-2/neu status through IHC and, if necessary, confirming with FISH is crucial in selecting the appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1+: IHC 1+ is considered Her-2/neu negative, and FISH testing is generally not indicated in these cases.

 

Option C. 3+: IHC 3+ is strongly positive for Her-2/neu, making FISH testing unnecessary since the high expression level is sufficient to guide treatment decisions.

 

Option D. Gene Amplification is done irrespective of Her 2 Neu status: This option is incorrect because FISH testing for gene amplification is specifically indicated in cases with an equivocal IHC result (2+), not irrespective of Her-2/neu status.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH for Her-2/neu gene amplification is performed when the IHC result is 2+, as this score is considered equivocal, requiring further testing to determine the appropriate therapeutic approach.

choices.text: AIDP with migraine
Right side paralysis
Acute intermittent porphyria
Conversion disorder

questions.text: A 22-year-old female patient came with complaints of vomiting and a decrease in movement of the right leg. In the past, she has had episodes of violent and aggressive behavior and abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute intermittent porphyria

 

Vomiting & decreased movements of right leg in young female with previous history of abdominal pain and mental symptoms like violent and aggressive behavior points towards acute intermittent porphyria.

 

Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder.

 

It is due to deficiency of HMB Synthase enzyme.

 

ACUTE INTERMITTENT PORPHYRIA

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Common precipitating factors include endogenous and exogeneous steroids, porphyrinogenic drugs, alcohol ingestion and low-calorie diets, usually instituted for weight loss.
  • Symptoms are more common in women, suggesting a role for estrogens or progestins.
  • Abdominal pain, the most common symptom is usually steady and poorly localized but maybe cramping.
  • Nausea, vomiting, constipation, tachycardia hypertension, mental symptoms, pain in the limbs, head, neck or chest, muscle weakness, sensory loss, dysuria, and urinary retention are characteristic.
  • The peripheral neuropathy is due to neurologic axonal degeneration (rather than demyelination) and primarily affects motor neurons.
  • Mental symptoms such as anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation, hallucination and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures can be due to neurologic effects or to hyponatremia (due to hypothalamic involvement and inappropriate vasopressin secretion or from electrolyte depletion due to vomiting, diarrhea, poor intake or excess renal sodium loss).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • ALA & PBG levels are substantially increased in plasma and urine, especially during acute attacks.

 

Treatment:

 

  • I.V. Hemin is more effective and should be used as first line therapy for all acute attacks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AIDP with migraine: Incorrect because AIDP (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy) presents with rapid onset muscle weakness and decreased reflexes, not specifically associated with vomiting or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Right side paralysis: Incorrect as this diagnosis does not account for the broader spectrum of symptoms including behavioral changes and abdominal pain.

 

Option D. Conversion disorder: Incorrect because conversion disorder involves symptoms that suggest neurological or medical conditions but are actually manifestations of psychological conflict or needs. The specific clinical presentation and past medical history in this case strongly point towards a physiological rather than psychological cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The acute intermittent porphyria presents with a complex array of symptoms, including neurological, gastrointestinal, and psychiatric manifestations, and is associated with specific triggers and a genetic basis. Elevated ALA and PBG levels during attacks are diagnostic.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis according to the given image? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoaneurysm of internal carotid artery

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows a digital subtraction angiography of ICA and it shows an outpouching of the contrast suggestive of a pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery as marked by the arrow.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) is the result of an abnormal vascular connection between the internal carotid artery (ICA) and the cavernous sinus. Pulsatile proptosis of eye would be the pathognomic clinical finding. DSA would reveal enlarged draining superior ophthalmic vein.

 

 

Option C. Tumor blush of angiofibroma would show feeder vessels from internal maxillary artery of ECA.

 

Option D. Extensive head and neck hemangioma would show multiple tortuous vessels supplying a mass which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery is characterized by an outpouching of contrast material in angiographic studies, as seen in the provided DSA image. This finding is distinct from other vascular abnormalities such as carotid-cavernous fistulas, angiofibromas, or hemangiomas.

questions.text: Noninvasive test to detect hepatic fibrosis include? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibro test

 

The FibroTest, also known as the Fibro test, is a noninvasive, blood-based test designed specifically to detect hepatic fibrosis. This test calculates the degree of liver fibrosis using a combination of several serum biochemical markers including haptoglobin, bilirubin, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin. It evaluates liver damage and fibrosis by measuring these markers, which are affected by liver function and architecture changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspartate aminotransferases /platelet ratio (APRI): Incorrect as it is primarily used to estimate the likelihood or severity of fibrosis rather than to directly detect it. It correlates with the degree of liver fibrosis but is less specific.

 

Option C. Forns index: Incorrect for the same reason as APRI. The Forns index is used to assess the risk of developing liver fibrosis based on variables including age, platelet count, cholesterol levels, and GGT, but it does not directly measure fibrosis.

 

Option D. Serum laminin & serum hyaluronidase: Incorrect as these are not standard tests for directly detecting hepatic fibrosis; they can indicate changes in extracellular matrix turnover but are less specific and commonly used compared to the FibroTest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibro test is a sensitive test to detect hepatic fibrosis. It is a multiparameter blood test which incorporate haptoglobin, bilirubin, GGT, apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin.

 

Test for estimating risk developing hepatic fibrosis:

 

  1. AST/platelet ratio
  2. Forns index
  3. Fib-4
  4. Cirrhosis determinant score.

 

Test for detecting hepatic fibrosis: Fibro test.

questions.text: On thyroid function test analysis, TSH value was much higher than normal with low free T4. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Primary hypothyroidism

 

HYPOTHYROIDISM

 

Types:

 

  1. Primary Hypothyroidism - Increased TSH with low T4 levels.
  2. Secondary hypothyroidism - TSH can be low, normal or elevated slightly. The latter is due to secretion of immune-active but bio-active forms of TSH. Confirmation of diagnosis is done by detecting low levels of unbound T4.

 

Evaluation of Hypothyroidism:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subclinical hypothyroidism: Incorrect because subclinical hypothyroidism would show an elevated TSH but normal free T4 levels.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Incorrect as hyperthyroidism would typically present with low TSH and high free T4 levels.

 

Option C. Secondary hypothyroidism: Incorrect for this scenario because secondary hypothyroidism involves a problem with pituitary TSH production, which does not typically result in a significantly elevated TSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary hypothyroidism is characterized by high TSH and low free T4 levels, indicating a failure of the thyroid gland itself to produce sufficient hormones.

choices.text: Bedside blood collection, label the samples, fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the patient
Fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the Patient, Bedside blood collection, label the samples
Label the sample tubes, Bedside blood collection, fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the patient
Identify the Patient, Fill the laboratory requisition forms, Bedside blood collection, label the samples

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fill the laboratory requisition forms, Identify the Patient, Bedside blood collection, label the samples

 

The correct sequence for blood collection and sample handling in a clinical setting involves several critical steps to ensure patient safety and accurate test results. The sequence is as follows:

 

  1. Provisional diagnosis by the physician: This initial step involves the physician evaluating the patient and determining the necessary diagnostic tests.
  2. Fill the laboratory requisition forms: The healthcare staff or laboratory personnel must fill out the requisition forms based on the physician's diagnosis. This step is crucial because it ensures that the correct tests are requested and that the laboratory has all the necessary information to process the samples.
  3. Identify the Patient: Before collecting any samples, the healthcare staff must properly identify the patient. This step is vital to prevent any mix-up of samples, which could lead to incorrect diagnosis and treatment.
  4. Bedside blood collection: After confirming the patient's identity, the blood sample is collected at the bedside. Proper collection technique is essential to avoid contamination or sample degradation.
  5. Label the samples: Finally, the collected samples must be labeled accurately and immediately to ensure that they are correctly matched with the patient and the requested tests.

 

This sequence ensures that the right patient receives the correct test, and the results are reliable and accurate.

 

Educational objective:

 

Sequence:

 

Provisional diagnosis by the physician > Requisition forms are filled accordingly for test to the lab > patient is identified by the laboratory personnel/ health care staff > samples are collected and labeled appropriately.

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Suprachoroidal hemorrhage

 

  • Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.
  • Signs of Suprachoroidal hemorrhage include the following:
  •  
    • Anterior chamber shallowing
    • Loss of the red reflex
    • Increased IOP, with firming of the eye
    • Wrinkling and bulging of the posterior capsule
    • Extrusion of intraocular contents: spontaneous nuclear expression, iris prolapse, vitreous prolapse
  • Maculopathy is a common consequence of hypotony, defined as IOP less than 5 mmHg.
  • Excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery is the most common cause of hypotonic maculopathy.
  • Other causes include trauma (cyclodialysis cleft, penetrating injury), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment.
  • Systemic causes of hypotony, usually bilateral, include dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes with hyperglycaemia, uraemia, and treatment with hyperosmotic agents or carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cyclodialysis of uvea: This refers to the disinsertion of the ciliary body from the scleral spur, a trauma-related occurrence that can lead to a direct decrease in IOP, potentially causing hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option C. Corneal perforation: Severe enough corneal damage, such as perforation, can lead to loss of aqueous humor and a subsequent decrease in IOP, posing a risk for hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Option D. Filtration site leak: This condition is specifically associated with glaucoma surgery where a leak at the filtration site can lead to a significant reduction in IOP, making it a direct cause of hypotonic maculopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suprachoroidal hemorrhage does not lead to hypotonic maculopathy because it typically causes an increase in intraocular pressure, not a decrease. Understanding the distinction between conditions that increase versus those that decrease IOP is critical in the management of eye conditions and their potential complications.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for her myopia. She is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on her: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tonometry

 

  • The image depicts the use of an Applanation tonometry. It is based on the applanation principle described by Imbert and Fick. With regards to applanation tonometry, the law states that pressure (P) can be approximated by the force (F) necessary to flatten the cornea in a fixed area, divided by the surface (S) of the flattened area. The Imbert-Fick law is defined as P=F/S.
  • The dynamic contour tonometer (Pascal) for tonometry looks as

 

 

  • Intraocular pressure (IOP) readings obtained with this tonometer are not influenced by central corneal thickness.
  • The Pascal tonometer is the preferred tonometer for measuring IOP in post-LASIK corneas.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pachymetry: This test measures the thickness of the cornea. It is important for assessing the cornea pre-LASIK but is not depicted in the image nor directly associated with measuring IOP.

 

 

Option C. Autorefractometry: This procedure determines the refractive error and prescription for glasses or contact lenses. It does not involve contact with the eye as depicted and is unrelated to IOP measurement.

 

 

Option D. A scan: This ultrasound test measures the length of the eye and is primarily used in cataract surgery planning. It does not involve the measurement of IOP.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tonometry, especially applanation tonometry, is crucial for monitoring intraocular pressure post-LASIK surgery to ensure no adverse effects on eye pressure, which could lead to symptoms like headaches and eye pain as described. This test is essential for the ongoing evaluation of patients' eye health following refractive surgery.

choices.text: Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

questions.text: Pregnant women with which of the following is called systemic hypertension? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypertension diagnosed at 10 weeks of gestation

 

Explanation:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is classified as chronic hypertension if it is diagnosed in the first trimester or if hypertension persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum. Hypertension present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation also qualifies as chronic hypertension. This is distinct from gestational hypertension, which develops after 20 weeks of gestation in a previously normotensive woman.

 

  • Chronic Hypertension: Defined as blood pressure of ≥ 140/90 mm Hg that was present before pregnancy or diagnosed before the 20th week of gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic retinopathy: This condition is a complication of diabetes affecting the eyes, not a direct indicator of systemic hypertension.

 

Option C. Diabetic nephropathy: This is a complication of diabetes that affects the kidneys and can be associated with hypertension, but it is not specific to the definition of systemic hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Episode of seizure: Seizures in the context of pregnancy are associated with eclampsia, a severe form of preeclampsia, but do not directly define systemic hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic hypertension in pregnancy is diagnosed if high blood pressure is present before pregnancy, is diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or persists beyond 12 weeks postpartum.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 43-year-old patient presented with spikes of fever and difficulty in breathing. Transesophageal echo revealed vegetations in the heart. The culture was positive for Burkholderia cepacia. Which of the following is the first line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins

 

The correct answer is B, Cotrimoxazole with 3rd generation cephalosporins. This combination is effective against Burkholderia cepacia, a pathogen known for its resistance to many standard antibiotics. The standard regimen includes Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole), which has broad-spectrum bacterial coverage, combined with a 3rd generation cephalosporin such as ceftazidime or cefoperazone-sulbactam to cover for the pathogen's unique resistance profiles and aggressive infection nature, especially in immunocompromised patients or those with existing cardiac issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminoglycoside and colistin: This option is incorrect due to the intrinsic resistance of Burkholderia cepacia to aminoglycosides. While colistin could still be effective, the resistance to aminoglycosides limits this combination's usefulness.

 

Option C. Carbapenems and 3rd generation cephalosporin: Incorrect because the combination of carbapenems with cephalosporins is generally not recommended. They both share a similar mechanism of action, inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis, and could potentially compete for the same binding sites, thus reducing their effectiveness.

 

Option D. Cefepime and tigecycline: Incorrect because tigecycline is not particularly effective against Burkholderia cepacia. Cefepime alone would not sufficiently manage the infection due to the bacteria's robust resistance profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard regimen for Burkholderia cepacia is cotrimoxazole with ceftazidime /cefoperazone-sulbactam.

questions.text: Black foot is seen in which poisoning: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arsenic

 

Blackfoot disease is an endemic peripheral vascular disease found among the inhabitants of a limited area on the southwest coast of Taiwan, where well water with a high concentration of arsenic causes peripheral vascular disease resulting in gangrene.

 

Other options are incorrect as the term Blackfoot disease is used only for arsenic

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arsenic, cadmium, lead and mercury are the heavy metals which can cause peripheral vascular disease due to chronic poisoning. This leads to general clinical features of peripheral vascular disease (numbness in feet, rest pain etc.).
  • Blackfoot disease is a unique term given to peripheral vascular disease produced by chronic Arsenic poisoning. The name "Blackfoot" refers to the characteristic darkening and gangrene of the feet and lower legs. This ultimately leads to amputation.
  • In peripheral vascular disease caused by other heavy metals, gangrene is not a common manifestation

 

  • Above picture shows Blackfoot disease:

questions.text: Dr. Sunita, a medical officer in a rural health clinic, is tasked with ensuring the potency and safety of vaccines. She comes across several vaccine vials, each with a Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) attached. The VVMs change color to indicate the cumulative exposure of the vaccine to heat, thus helping in determining the viability of the vaccine. She notices varying degrees of color changes across these VVMs. Given this scenario, which of the following choices correctly identifies which vaccine vials, based on the observed VVM color changes, should be considered safe for use? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Vials 1 and 2 can be used

 

  • Based on the image provided, it's evident that only vials 1 and 2 are suitable for use because the inner squares of these vials color lighter than the outer circles.
  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVM) are heat-sensitive indicators routinely used to monitor heat exposure of the vaccine and determine vaccine viability as the vaccine vial moves across the supply chain.
  • VVMs change color as the vaccine is exposed to cumulative heat. If the color of inner square is similar or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine vial should be discarded.
  • A VVM can be used to assess vaccine potency and not vaccine efficacy.
  • Expiry date can’t be determined by VVM and has no relation to extend the expiry date.
  • If the square and the circle are the same in colour, then the vaccine should be discarded.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases
Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Transferrin receptor 1 iron responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis
Ferritin mRNA concentration iron responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the internal iron homeostasis in iron-deficiency anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis

 

In iron deficiency anemia, there is an increase in transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis.

 

 

Progressive depletion of iron reserves first lowers serum iron and transferrin saturation levels without producing anemia. In this early stage there is increased erythroid activity in the bone marrow.

 

Anemia appears only when iron stores are completely depleted and is accompanied by low serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels.

 

The serum iron and ferritin are low, and the total plasma iron-binding capacity (reflecting elevated transferrin levels) is high. Low serum iron with increased iron-binding capacity results in a reduction of transferrin saturation to below 15%. Reduced iron stores inhibit hepcidin synthesis, and its serum levels fall and this in turn facilitates iron absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element increases and ferritin synthesis decreases: This statement is incorrect. In iron deficiency, ferritin synthesis decreases as the body conserves iron, but the ferritin mRNA concentration does not increase.

 

Option C. Transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements decreases transferrin receptor mRNA concentration and synthesis: This is incorrect because in iron deficiency, transferrin receptor 1 expression increases to maximize iron uptake.

 

Option D. Ferritin mRNA concentration iron-responsive element decreases and ferritin synthesis increases: This is also incorrect. In iron deficiency, both ferritin mRNA levels and ferritin synthesis decrease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In iron-deficiency anemia, transferrin receptor 1 iron-responsive elements increase mRNA concentration and synthesis to enhance iron uptake, while ferritin levels decrease as the body attempts to conserve iron.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, pg 1231-1234

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

 

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome: partial deletion of short arm of Chr 5, leads to cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.
  • Bloom syndrome: rare autosomal recessive disorder, characterized by short stature, sun sensitivity, predeposition of development of cancer and genomic instability.
  • Angelman syndrome: caused by deletion in maternal chromosome 15 or paternal uniparental disomy, affects nervous system, delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and ataxia.
  • Fragile X syndrome: genetic disorder, also known as Martin-Bell syndrome, most common cause of inherited mental retardation (among X-linked disorders), intellectual disability, and autism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom syndrome: features are:

 

  • Short stature
  • Sun sensitive rash over the nose and nose and cheeks
  • Immune deficiency 
  • Insulin resistance that resembles Type 2 Diabetes

 

The question doesn’t mention such feature. Therefore, bloom syndrome is not the right answer

 

Option C. Angelman syndrome: remember “angel is the mother” therefore, in this syndrome maternal gene is deleted. It is one of the examples of uniparental disomy. The clinical features are:

 

 

  1. Maternal gene is deleted
  2. Paternal gene is doubled
  3. Dev delay
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Microcephaly
  6. Hyperactive
  7. Spontaneous laughter - Happy Puppets
  8. Hypertonia
  9. UBE3A GENE ON Chr 15 is defective/absent

 

Option D. fragile x syndrome: it is the second most common non preventable cause of mental retardation. The features are:

 

  1. Male patient
  2. Large ears
  3. Large testes
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Nose will NOT be large

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: The nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc is derived from which of the labeled embryonic structures in the given image?  (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mark b

 

Explanation:

 

  • The notochord is a rod-like structure that forms during embryonic development and serves as the foundation for the future vertebral column.
  • The nucleus pulposus, the central gel-like core of the intervertebral disc, is derived from the notochord. The notochord initially provides structural support to the developing embryo and later contributes to the formation of the intervertebral discs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mark d. Ectoderm:

 

  • The ectoderm is another primary germ layer of the developing embryo and gives rise to structures such as the nervous system, skin, and epidermal tissues.
  • The ectoderm does not contribute to the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Option C. Mark a. Intraembryonic Mesoderm:

 

  • The intraembryonic mesoderm is a layer of embryonic tissue that gives rise to various structures in the developing embryo, including muscles, bones, and connective tissues.
  • While mesoderm does play a role in the development of the vertebral column and its associated structures, the nucleus pulposus specifically derives from the notochord.

 

Option D. Mark c. Endoderm:

 

  • The endoderm is one of the three primary germ layers of the developing embryo and gives rise to the epithelial linings of various organs, including the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and other internal organs.
  • The endoderm is not directly involved in the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrulation (Embryonic development of the germ layers):

 

  • Gastrulation is the early embryological process by which an embryo changes from a one-dimensional layer of epithelial cells (blastula) to a multilayered structure known as a gastrula.
  • The notochord is a rod-like embryological structure that is derived during gastrulation and plays an important role in vertebrate development.
  • The nucleus pulposus is the gelatinous centre of the intervertebral disc formed by the expansion of the notochord (by its remnants). As a result, it is derived from the notochord.

choices.text: I - A, II - B, III - C, IV - D
I - C, II - D, III - A, IV - B
I - D, II - C, III - A, IV - B
I - B, II - A, III - D, IV - C

questions.text: During a medical ethics seminar, Dr. Sharma discussed a series of international declarations that guide medical professionals in upholding ethical principles in various scenarios. These declarations were born out of historical events and societal needs to ensure the welfare of patients and respect human rights. Can you match these declarations with their respective significance? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) I - C, II - D, III - A, IV - B

 

  • Geneva Declaration: It is primarily focused on the physician's dedication to the humanitarian goals of medicine, emphasizing the commitment of the medical profession to human welfare and ethics. This declaration is assigned significance C.
  • Oslo Declaration: It deals with issues surrounding therapeutic abortion, offering guidelines and ethical considerations for medical professionals when abortion is a factor in medical treatment. This declaration is assigned significance D.
  • Tokyo Declaration: Provides guidelines for physicians concerning the ethical treatment of detainees and prisoners, specifically regarding torture and other forms of cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment. This declaration is assigned significance A.
  • Helsinki Declaration: A cornerstone document that outlines ethical principles for the medical community concerning human experimentation. This declaration provides comprehensive guidelines intended to protect the dignity, rights, safety, and well-being of research subjects. It is assigned significance B.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Aspirin & clopidogrel
Decompressive surgery
Mechanical thrombectomy

questions.text: A 53-year-old man was admitted with history of a cerebrovascular accident 2 days ago. The patient is drowsy with minimal response. CT findings is shown in the image below. What will be your next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decompressive surgery

 

The CT scan image shows significant edema and midline shift affecting more than 50% of the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA) territory. This extensive edema, along with the patient's low Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score, indicates severe brain swelling and increased intracranial pressure (ICP). In such cases, medical management alone (like mannitol for reducing ICP) may not be sufficient.

 

Guidelines for urgent decompression:

 

  • NIH Stroke scale > 15
  • Time < 48 hours
  • Age 18-60yrs
  • Territory infarct > 145cm3 or > 50% MCA territory
  • Informed consent that surgery improves survival but the patient may have significant disability.

 

Medical management of brain edema and increased intracranial pressure (ICP) may not be successful when significant swelling occurs in the cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere.

 

Therefore, a decompressive craniectomy should be considered to relieve the mass effect of the swollen cerebral or cerebellar hemisphere on the thalamus, brainstem and network projections to the cortex, which is manifested predominantly by decreased levels of arousal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin & clopidogrel: Incorrect as these medications are used for preventing further thrombotic events but are not suitable in the acute management of severe edema and brain shift.

 

Option B. Mannitol: Incorrect for sole use in this severe case, as it might not adequately control the mass effect and high ICP shown.

 

Option D. Mechanical thrombectomy: Incorrect because the primary issue in the CT image is the significant brain swelling and herniation risk, not an occlusion that can be resolved by thrombectomy at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cases of significant cerebral edema with midline shift, as seen on CT in acute stroke settings, decompressive surgery is often necessary to prevent fatal outcomes and manage increased intracranial pressure effectively.

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, Public health expert who works extensively with the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) in India. In a meeting with local health workers in 2017, he has shared the data and progress made in controlling leprosy. He mentions the crucial statistic of the Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR) as of March 31, 2016, to give a snapshot of the magnitude of new leprosy cases detected. This rate helps in understanding the effectiveness of ongoing programs and strategies. What value did Dr. Mehta share as the ANCDR for leprosy for that specific year? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 9.7/1 lakh population

 

During the 2015-2016 period, India recorded an annual new case detection rate (ANCDR) for leprosy at 9.7 per 100,000 people.

 

Annual New Case Detection Rate (ANCDR):

 

  • An important Indicator being used under the National Leprosy Eradication Program 
  • Indicator is calculated at the end of March every year, wherein New Cases detected during the period April (Previous Calendar year) and March (current year) is used
  • ANCDR - 2015-16: 9.71 per 100,000 population
  • ANCDR - 2021-22: 5.52 per 100,000 population

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ANCDR is a pivotal indicator in disease surveillance and control programs, helping public health officials and stakeholders understand the scale of new cases and the impact of interventions.
  • For leprosy in India, maintaining a keen understanding of this rate is essential for achieving the goals of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme.

choices.text: Strap his thorax, abdomen and lower limbs on a stretcher
Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately
Roll the patient and put on a hard board

questions.text: All of the following are done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Put patient on lateral position and shift him immediately

 

This option is not a standard practice when transporting conscious polytrauma patients. Shifting a conscious patient to a lateral position and immediately moving them can risk further injury and discomfort.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strap his thorax, abdomen, and lower limbs on a stretcher: This is a common and necessary practice when transporting a conscious polytrauma patient. It helps secure the patient to the stretcher to prevent movement and further injury during transport.

 

Option B. Apply a cervical collar: This is done to immobilize the cervical spine, till a cervical injury is ruled out.

 

Option D. Roll the patient and put on a hardboard: Rolling a conscious polytrauma patient and placing them on a hardboard (spinal board) can be a part of the standard protocol for immobilizing the spine and minimizing movement during transport. This is done to prevent potential spinal cord injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with polytrauma are shifted in supine or prone position (not in lateral position) by laying them over a firm surface, in order to restrict the spinal movement.

 

As per ATLS guidelines, in patients with trauma, airway management is first done along with cervical spine stabilization. All trauma patients unless proven otherwise are considered to have an injured vertebral column.

 

The patient is placed supine on a firm surface without rotating or bending the spinal column and a rigid cervical collar (Philadelphia collar) is applied.

questions.text: Which of the following life cycle is given below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E. Histolytica

 

  • The given life cycle is of Entamoeba histolytica.
  • Its life cycle includes 2 stages - the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst, both of which are seen in the image shown above. The transmission is primarily by the fecal-oral route. There is no animal reservoir.
  • The ingested cysts differentiate into trophozoites in the ileum which invade the colonic epithelium. The trophozoites penetrate to the submucosal layer and form abscesses which break down to form flask-shaped ulcer.
  • The trophozoites multiply by binary fission and produce cysts, and both stages are passed in the feces.
  • Trophozoites are rapidly destroyed outside the body. Cysts survive in the external environment and are responsible for transmission.
  • The most frequent site of systemic disease is the liver.
  • The genus Entamoeba has four morphologically identical species - E. histolytica, E. dispar, E. bangladeshi, and E. moshkovskii. E. moshkovskii which was initially thought to be non-pathogenic has recently been shown to be a causative agent of non-invasive diarrhea.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E. vermicularis: Enterobius vermicularis, also known as pinworm, has a simple life cycle that involves ingestion of eggs, hatching in the intestine, and laying eggs around the anus. It does not form trophozoites or cysts.

 

Option B. A. duodenal: Ancylostoma duodenale, a hookworm, has a life cycle involving skin penetration by larvae, migration through the bloodstream to the lungs, ascent to the throat, and finally ingestion to the intestine where they mature. It does not have cysts or trophozoites.

 

Option C. B. coli: Balantidium coli is a ciliate protozoan with a life cycle that involves a cyst stage and a trophozoite stage, similar to E. histolytica. However, it is characterized by the presence of cilia and typically associated with pigs as a reservoir.

 

Educational Objective

 

The life cycle of Entamoeba histolytica includes the motile trophozoite and the non-motile cyst stages, with transmission primarily by the fecal-oral route. The most frequent site of systemic disease caused by E. histolytica is the liver.

choices.text: 125 ml/cm H20
150 ml/cm H20
50 ml/cm H20
62.5 ml/cm H20

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with respiratory volume of 500ml. The intrapleural pressure measured -4 before inspiration and -8 at the end of inspiration. The pulmonary compliance of the patient is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: A) 125 ml/cm H20

 

The compliance of a system is defined as the change in volume that occurs per unit change in the pressure of the system.

 

Compliance is, therefore, a measurement of the elastic resistance of a system.

 

Pulmonary compliance (C) total compliance of both lungs, measuring the extent to which the lungs will expand (change in volume of lungs) for each unit increase in the trans-pulmonary pressure (when enough time is allowed for the system to reach equilibrium).

 

Compliance = Change in lung volume / Change in pressure

 

In the given case, change in lung volume is 500 and change in transpulmonary pressure is 4

Compliance = 500/4 = 125 ml/cm H20

 

Educational Objective

 

Pulmonary compliance measures the change in lung volume per unit change in transpulmonary pressure. It is a crucial indicator of the lung's ability to expand and is affected in various pulmonary diseases.

questions.text: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low grade fever. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat embolism

 

FAT EMBOLISM

  • Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours – think of fat embolism!
  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow.
  • Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Salient Features:
    • Presence of fat globules in pulmonary circulation.
    • Precipitated by physical trauma such as fracture of long bones, soft tissue trauma, and burns.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Clinical signs and symptoms develop after a asymptomatic latent period of about 12 - 48 hours.
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      • Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea.
      • Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation.
      • Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder.
  • Diagnosis:
    • FES is distinct from the presence of fat emboli.
    • Symptoms usually occur 1-3 days after a traumatic injury and are predominantly pulmonary (shortness of breath, hypoxemia), neurological (agitation, delirium, or coma), dermatological (petechial rash), and hematological (anemia, low platelets).
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood.
    • If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation.
    • Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg.
    • O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax. A pneumothorax is a collection of air outside the lung but within the pleural cavity. It occurs when air accumulates between the parietal and visceral pleurae inside the chest. The air accumulation can apply pressure on the lung and make it collapse. Causes of traumatic pneumothorax are penetrating or blunt trauma, rib fracture, diving or flying. While it can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur specifically after femur fracture fixation unless there was a procedure complication.

 

Option B. Pleural effusion. Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in between the parietal and visceral pleura, called the pleural cavity. It can occur by itself or can be the result of surrounding parenchymal disease like infection, malignancy, or inflammatory conditions. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is less likely to occur suddenly after femur fracture fixation unless there are other complicating factors.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure. Congestive heart failure (CHF) is a complex clinical syndrome characterized by inefficient myocardial performance, resulting in compromised blood supply to the body. CHF results from any disorder that impairs ventricular filling or ejection of blood to the systemic circulation. Patients usually present with fatigue and dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and systemic or pulmonary congestion. While congestive heart failure can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur suddenly after a femur fracture fixation unless the patient has pre-existing heart conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fat embolism is the most common complication of femur fracture.
  • It usually presents 48 hours after the injury with breathlessness and low grade fever.
  • The patient  remains asymptomatic in the initial 12-48 hours.

questions.text: 1,3 beta D- glucan is helpful for identification of? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Invasive candidiasis

 

1,3 beta D- glucan is helpful for the identification of Invasive candidiasis (invasive fungal infections).

 

Beta 1-3 glucan assay test detects the presence of (1-3)-3-d-glucan (BDG) which is an abundant cell wall polysaccharide found in most fungi except cryptococci, mucor, zygomycetes and blastomyces dermatitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rhizopus: Rhizopus is a genus of fungi causing mucormycosis, which typically does not produce significant amounts of (1,3)-β-D-glucan. Therefore, the BDG assay is not useful for detecting Rhizopus infections.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus: Cryptococcus species, which cause cryptococcosis, have a polysaccharide capsule that does not contain (1,3)-β-D-glucan, rendering the BDG assay ineffective for its detection.

 

Option D. Mucormycosis: Mucormycosis is caused by fungi in the order Mucorales, which do not produce (1,3)-β-D-glucan in significant amounts. Thus, the BDG assay is not applicable for diagnosing mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

1,3 beta D-glucan is helpful for the identification of invasive candidiasis by detecting the presence of (1,3)-β-D-glucan in the blood, a cell wall component of many pathogenic fungi, but it is not effective for detecting infections caused by fungi such as Cryptococcus, Rhizopus, and Mucormycosis.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary dermis

 

The papillary dermis is a layer of the skin that lies just below the epidermis. Blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns occurs within this layer, as it is the point where the burn has affected both the epidermis and the upper portion of the dermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermis: The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin. In superficial partial thickness burns, this layer is typically damaged, but blister formation occurs slightly deeper within the skin.

 

Option B. Subcutaneous tissue: The subcutaneous tissue is located beneath the dermis and is not typically involved in blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns.

 

Option D. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is located deeper in the skin and is not primarily associated with blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns. Blister formation occurs closer to the surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The papillary dermis is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial-thickness burn.

 

First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, with pain, redness, and mild swelling.

 

Second-degree burns involve the epidermis and some parts of the dermis (also known as partial-thickness burns). Further classified as-

 

  • Superficial second degree or superficial partial-thickness burn - involves the upper part of the dermis (papillary) and shows pain, blisters, and severe swelling.
  • Deep second degree or deep partial-thickness burn - extends deeper up to the reticular layer of the dermis and appears paler and more mottled, does not blanch to touch, but remains painful to pinprick.

 

Third-degree or full-thickness burns involve the complete thickness of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the esophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Image 3

 

The shows an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy. Barium swallow reveals an apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. The characteristic histopathological finding in this condition are nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 3.

 

In contrast to adenocarcinoma, half of squamous cell carcinomas occur in the middle third of the esophagus. Squamous cell carcinoma begins as an in-situ lesion termed squamous dysplasia (this lesion is referred to as intraepithelial neoplasia or carcinoma in situ at other sites). Early lesions appear as small, gray-white, plaque-like thickenings. Over months to years, they grow into tumor masses that may be polypoid or exophytic and protrude into and obstruct the lumen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus typically occurs in the middle third of the esophagus and is characterized histologically by nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, as seen in Image 3.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition Pg 1472, 1473

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is classified as which type of synovial joint? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ball and socket joint

 

Explanation:

 

The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

 

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures:
    • Posterior surface of the navicular
    • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
    • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saddle Type: A saddle joint, also known as a sellar joint, is a type of synovial joint found in the thumb (between the trapezium bone and the first metacarpal bone). It allows movement in two planes, such as flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. The talocalcaneonavicular joint does not fit this description.

 

Option B. Plane: A plane joint, also called a gliding joint, allows for limited sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces. While there are gliding joints in the foot, the talocalcaneonavicular joint is not primarily classified as a plane joint.

 

Option C. Ellipsoid (Condyloid): An ellipsoid joint, also known as a condyloid joint, is a synovial joint that allows movement in two planes: flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. This type of joint has an oval-shaped convex surface fitting into an elliptical concave surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ball and socket joint is characterized by a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket. This type of joint allows for a wide range of motion in multiple planes. The talocalcaneonavicular joint is  a ball and socket joint.

questions.text: Under which of the following, Rhinosporidium seeberi is classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aquatic Protistan protozoa

 

RHINOSPORIDIOSIS

 

  • Causative organism: Rhinosporidium Seeberi (earlier considered fungus, now classified under protozoa)
  • Life cycle: 3 stages: Trophic, Sporangium formation, Endospore production.
  • Spread by contaminated water of ponds, seen commonly in coastal areas
  • Appearance: leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple (strawberry), bleeds on touch.
  • Complaints: Blood tinged nasal discharge & stuffiness
  • Diagnosis by biopsy (spores bursting through chitinous wall of sporangia)
  • Treatment: Diathermy excision with base cauterization ± Dapsone

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Although previously considered a fungus, current classifications based on molecular analysis place Rhinosporidium seeberi under protozoa.

 

Option B: Viruses are infectious agents that replicate inside the living cells of organisms which is not a characteristic of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Option D: Bacteria are single-celled microorganisms with simple internal structures, quite distinct from the complex life cycle and morphology of Rhinosporidium seeberi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa, not a fungus, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in understanding transmission and management of infections.

choices.text: Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop
Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface

questions.text: What is the function of Acetone Free Methanol in Leishman stain? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop

Acetone-free methanol serves as a fixing agent in the Leishman stain process. Its primary function is to cause metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop, which preserves cellular architecture. This fixation occurs through protein denaturation and halts all biological processes, maintaining the cellular structure for microscopic examination. Therefore, the correct choice would be: "Causes metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop."

 

The procedure of Leishman stain:

  • Freshly prepare and rapidly air-dry blood film.
  • Cover the film with Leishman's Stain (S018S) and allow it to act for 1 minute. Methanol in the stain fixes the preparation.
  • Add double the volume of distilled water to the slide and mix.
  • Allow the diluted stain to act for 10-12 minutes.
  • Wash the film with distilled water or phosphate buffer of pH 7.0, drain and dry in air and examine

 

Other Options:

Option B. Prevents the cells from sticking to the slide surface: This is incorrect because methanol doesn't prevent adhesion; rather, it preserves cellular structure through protein denaturation.

 

Option C. Colors the red cells: This is not the role of acetone-free methanol. The actual coloring of the cells is performed by the dye components in the Leishman stain (methylene blue and eosin).

 

Option D. Fixes cells to slide: While methanol is a fixative, its primary mechanism is stopping metabolic activity, not adhering cells to the slide. As previously noted, adhesion to the slide surface is the function of substances like albumin.
 

Educational Objective:


Acetone-free methanol in the Leishman stain primarily functions by causing metabolic and enzymatic activity to stop through protein denaturation, which preserves cellular architecture and enables proper staining and microscopic examination.

questions.text: In SCID, what type of DNA repair is defective? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-homologous end joining repair

 

Human severe combined immune deficiency (SCID) is the most serious inherited immunological deficit which is caused due to defects in the predominant pathway for double-strand break repair called nonhomologous DNA end joining, or NHEJ.

 

Defects in DNA Repair:

 

 

Other Options: 

 

The table in the provided image highlights various DNA repair pathways and the associated cancer syndromes when these pathways are defective:

 

Option A. Base excision repair (BER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Base modifications, abasic sites
  • Cancer Syndromes: Not yet reported
