Option B. Nucleotide excision repair (NER):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Intra-strand crosslinks, bulky adducts
  • Cancer Syndromes: Xeroderma pigmentosum, ERCC6L2 deficiency

 

Option C. Mismatch repair (MMR):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Mismatches, indels
  • Cancer Syndromes: Constitutional MMR syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

SCID is caused by defects in the NHEJ pathway, which is responsible for repairing double-strand breaks in DNA. This defect impairs the immune system, leading to severe immunodeficiency.

 

Non-homologous end joining (NHEJ):

 

  • DNA Lesion: Double-strand breaks (DSBs)
  • Cancer Syndromes: Ligase IV deficiency, XLF/NHEJ1 deficiency, Rothmund-Thompson syndrome, Werner syndrome

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with the diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia was treated medically. She developed fever and tachypnea and a chest X-ray showed pulmonary infiltrates. What drug should she be given next? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone

 

APML is a leukemia with excellent prognosis managed with Arsenic trioxide and All-Trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by infiltrates, pleural effusion after treatment and improves with Dexamethasone. Used Intrathecally in children for AML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytarabine is used in the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Option C. Doxorubicin is a cardiotoxic drug used in Hodgkin, CA breast, thyroid.

 

Option D. Methotrexate is not recommended in APML treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is used to manage differentiation syndrome in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia, characterized by symptoms like fever, tachypnea, and pulmonary infiltrates following treatment with specific leukemia drugs.

 

Reference -Harrison/Oncology/Acute leukemia/chap100-743

questions.text: Criminal responsibility of Insane is defined in: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McNaughten's Rule

 

“McNaughten’s Rule” also known as “Legal test of insanity”, “right or wrong test” is the legal standard for determining criminal responsibility in cases of insanity.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Curren's rule: of 1964 states that an accused person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law, as a result of mental disease or defect.

 

Option C. Durham 's rule: of 1954 States that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

 

Option D. American law institute test: (1972) A person is not responsible for the crime, if at the time of committing it, he lacks adequate capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust it to the requirements of the law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

McNaughten's rule is defined by section 84 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC)

 

It states that "A person of unsound mind is not liable for an act."

 

It implies that the defendant was unable to distinguish between right and wrong or otherwise didn't understand what they did because of a "disease of the mind."

choices.text: Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection
Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with a history of thyroid swelling. A fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) report suggests papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, and the nodule appears “cold” on scan. Which of the following would not be an appropriate treatment option for her? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radioiodine ablation of thyroid

 

Radioiodine ablation (radioactive iodine therapy) is contraindicated in pregnant women due to the potential risk of fetal radiation exposure. Radioactive iodine can cross the placenta and cause severe fetal hypothyroidism or other developmental issues, making this treatment unsuitable during pregnancy. Alternative surgical approaches like total thyroidectomy or hemithyroidectomy can be considered based on the tumor size, lymph node involvement, and other clinical factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Thyroidectomy: This is a valid treatment option for managing papillary carcinoma in pregnant patients, especially if there is a concern about the aggressive nature of the tumor. Surgery is preferred during pregnancy over radiation-based therapies.

 

Option B. Total Thyroidectomy plus Lymph node dissection: Lymph node involvement in papillary carcinoma often necessitates lymph node dissection along with thyroidectomy. This is another viable option during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Right Hemithyroidectomy: For small, localized tumors, hemithyroidectomy may be an appropriate option. Surgery during pregnancy can be safely performed, typically in the second trimester to minimize risks to both the mother and fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radioiodine ablation is contraindicated during pregnancy due to fetal radiation exposure, making surgical approaches the preferred treatment for thyroid cancers diagnosed in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

 

On the fourth day, this child's bilirubin level is only 8 mg/dl, indicating physiologic jaundice. Because the child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding on a regular and exclusive basis.

 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is caused by increased bilirubin production from foetal red blood cell breakdown combined with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation by the immature neonatal liver.

 

It usually appears on the second or third day after birth, peaks on the fourth day at 5-6 mg/dL, and then drops to 2 mg/dL between the fifth and seventh days.

 

Note: Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

 

  1. Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth.
  2. Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant.
  3. Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level.
  4. Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) levels above the expected normal range -Jaundice is seen in the mid-abdomen (= 15 mg/dL) and soles (- 20 mg/dL).
  5. Total Serum Bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy.
  6. Total Serum Bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exchange transfusion: exchange transfusion is not the correct option.

 

Indications of exchange transfusion are:

 

  1. History of Direct coombs test positive
  2. Cord hemoglobin < 5gm/cl and cord bilirubin >10 mg /dl
  3. History of sibling death / erythroblastosis fetalis

 

Option B. Stop breastfeeding and start phototherapy: We don’t stop breast feeding unless the baby is a case of galactosemia or lactose intolerance because in these conditions breast feeding is contraindicated.

 

Option C. IV fluids and phototherapy: IV fluids is not the right option as the baby is feeding well. We don’t give IV fluids to a baby who is feeding well.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

choices.text: Benedict test and heat coagulation test
Heat coagulation test and Rothera's test

questions.text: Which test will be positive in starvation state in urine? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Rothera’s test

 

Detectable levels of ketone bodies in urine (ketonuria) are seen in conditions characterized by increased ketogenesis such as starvation. The urine test done for ketone bodies is the Rothera's test in which formation of a purple ring indicates presence of ketone bodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benedict test and heat coagulation test: Used to detect reducing sugars (such as glucose, fructose, and lactose) in urine. In the presence of reducing sugars, Benedict's reagent changes color from blue to green, yellow, or red, depending on the concentration of the sugar. This test is not specific to ketone bodies and is used primarily to diagnose conditions like diabetes mellitus where reducing sugars are present in the urine.

 

Option B. Heat coagulation test: Used to detect proteins in urine. When the urine sample is heated, the presence of proteins causes the formation of a precipitate or cloudiness. This test is used to diagnose conditions like proteinuria, seen in kidney disease, but it does not detect ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gerhardt's test - Ketone bodies in urine.
  • Benedict' test - Reducing sugars.
  • Heat coagulation test - Proteins.
  • Rothera’s test – detect Ketone bodies in urine.

questions.text: What is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug amongst the given drugs? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ofloxacin

 

In general, Rifampicin is the most potent bactericidal anti leprotic drug.

 

But in cases of Rifampicin resistance, we use regimens consisting of Ofloxacin+ Clofazimine + Clarithromycin/Minocycline are used for 24 months.

 

Out of these, the fluoroquinolone Ofloxacin is the most bactericidal anti leprotic drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic effective against a variety of bacterial infections but is not typically used or effective against Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is another fluoroquinolone that has broad antibacterial activity, including some activity against Mycobacterium species. However, it is not as potent as Ofloxacin in the treatment of leprosy.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: Erythromycin is a macrolide antibiotic that has some activity against Mycobacterium species but is less effective and less commonly used in the treatment of leprosy compared to Other Options: like Rifampicin and Ofloxacin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ofloxacin is the most bactericidal anti-leprotic drug among the given options, especially used in cases where there is resistance to the standard first-line treatment with Rifampicin.

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world, his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him out of jealousy. His wife claims contrary, claiming that he has only recently begun acting in this manner, and that he previously worked calmly as a school teacher. He's probably suffering from? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion of grandiosity and persecution

 

The patient's belief that he is the most important person in the world indicates a delusion of grandiosity. His belief that his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him due to jealousy represents a delusion of persecution. Both types of delusions are present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandiosity: Delusion of grandiosity is evident, but this choice doesn't encompass the persecutory beliefs he holds.

 

Option B. Delusion of persecution: While the patient does display delusions of persecution, this choice neglects the grandiose delusion.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference: The patient clearly exhibits delusions of grandiosity and persecution, but there's no evidence in the provided information suggesting a delusion of reference.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorders are characterized by the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 245-246.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with Renal calculus of > 4 cm of the Staghorn type. What is the best management modality in this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone. PCNL is highly effective in managing large stones like Staghorn calculi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones (<2cm), it may not be as successful for very large and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the kidney or upper urinary tract. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Open pyelolithotomy: This may be done in cases where PCNL fails or is contra-indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is the gold standard for the management of large and complex stones, like in this case.

 

PCNL is indicated in

 

  • Staghorn calculi - Stone >2 cm
  • Multiple stones - >1 cm

 

ESWL is only 45-60% efficacious in the treatment of large stones. Also, it causes frequent complications including pain, hydronephrosis, fever, and occasional urosepsis, due to difficulties in the passage of stone particles, especially when there has been insufficient disintegration.

 

Complications of percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:

 

  • Hemorrhage from the punctured renal parenchyma
  • Perforation of the collecting system with extravasation of saline irrigant
  • Perforation of the colon or pleural cavity during placement of the percutaneous track

questions.text: What is the most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young adults?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent shoulder dislocation

 

SEQUELAE OF TRAUMATIC SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Recurrent dislocation is most common in shoulder joint, accounting for nearly 50% of all dislocations.
  • Most commonly it is subcoracoid type.
  • Other complications include:
    • Muscle, ligament or tendon rupture
    • Nerve or blood vessel damage around the joint
    • Shoulder instability

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frozen shoulder. Following dislocation, the shoulder shows some degree of limited motion owing to pain or apprehension for some time, which usually spontaneously recovers. However, some patients experience continuous stiffness after dislocation. This may lead to frozen shoulder if not mobilized early.

 

Option C. Normal shoulder healing and movements. The healing after the shoulder dislocation takes around 12-16 weeks. The movements are started slowly under the rehabilitation process.

 

Option D. Subscapular tendinitis. It is a rare complication of shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common sequealae of the shoulder dislocation is the recurrence of the shoulder dislocation due to instability of the shoulder joint tissues.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mycobacteria

 

  • The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain.
  • Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.
  • Actinomyces and Corynebacterium are non-acid-fast.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid-fast staining technique.

 

 

Option C: The image given below is of a gram-stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii.

 

 

Option D: The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis, appear as pink bacilli on a blue background when stained with Ziehl-Neelsen stain due to their acid-fast properties.
  • They have a high lipid content in their cell walls, which retains the carbol fuchsin dye even after treatment with acid-alcohol, a hallmark of acid-fast organisms.

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ptosis of right eye

 

The patient has ptosis of the right eye. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea. Ptosis is generally unilateral, in over 70% of individuals. The drooping in this case is significant enough to cover a portion of the pupil, thereby obstructing part of the visual field, which is characteristic of ptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entropion of right eye: This condition involves the inward turning of the eyelid margin, not observed in the provided image.

 

Option B. Lagophthalmos of right eye: Refers to the inability to close the eyelids completely, not evident here.

 

Option D. Exophthalmos of left eye: Characterized by the protrusion of the eyeball, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis, particularly of the type seen in this patient, is typically caused by a dysfunction or disconnection of the levator muscle or its aponeurosis, either congenital or acquired.

 

Types:

 

 

Note: Pseudoptosis is apparent but not true drooping of the eyelid. Causes include lack of support of the lids by the globe (orbital volume deficit like an artificial eye, microphthalmos, or enophthalmos), contralateral lid retraction, ipsilateral hypotropia, brow ptosis, or dermatochalasis.

questions.text: During a major disaster response, the medical team in an emergency department needs to prioritize patients based on the severity of their injuries and their medical needs. This prioritization process is known as triage. Each patient is assigned a specific color code representing their current state and the urgency of their medical attention. Which of the following correctly matches the color designation with its corresponding level of patient priority in the triage process? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Green – ambulatory

 

  • Triage is a critical process used in emergency medicine to quickly classify patients according to the severity of their health condition and the urgency of their need for care.
  • The color-coding system is a standardized approach used globally, with each color representing a specific category of priority:
  • Green indicates "ambulatory" patients, who are those with relatively minor injuries or conditions that do not require immediate, life-saving intervention.
  • These patients can often walk and may have injuries such as infections, closed fractures, minor abrasions, and lacerations.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A male patient complained of bone and joint pain and was prescribed NSAIDs. After a few days, he returned with vesiculo-bullous lesions that subsequently healed, leaving a brownish discoloration on his face (particularly in the upper lip area), as shown in the image. Based on these symptoms, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fixed drug eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems.

 

A fixed drug eruption is a known adverse drug reaction characterized by recurrent skin eruptions at the same location upon re-exposure to a specific drug. The vesiculo-bullous lesions followed by brownish discoloration can be seen in fixed drug eruptions, making it the most likely diagnosis given the patient's history of NSAID use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is transmitted to humans via the bites of infected Anopheles mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: Fever (often cyclic), chills, sweating, headaches, muscle pains, fatigue, anemia, jaundice due to hemolysis, and enlargement of the spleen.
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: Malaria does not typically cause vesico-bullous lesions or discoloration of the face.

 

Option B. Dengue:

 

  • Etiology: Caused by the dengue virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Aedes mosquitoes.
  • Clinical Features: High fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash, and mild bleeding (e.g., nose or gum bleed, or easy bruising).
  • Why it's not the likely diagnosis: While dengue can cause rashes, it does not usually result in vesico-bullous lesions or leave a persistent brownish discoloration on the skin.

 

Option C. Chikungunya fever:

 

A strong differential diagnosis is post chikungunya pigmentation (PCP) of the face seen on the nose & cheeks (Chik Sign) as shown in the below image.

 

 

Why it's not the likely diagnosis: However, this is not the answer because there is no antecedent history of fever, myalgia, or other symptoms suggestive of chikungunya. PCP often appears as the fever subsides and may persist for about three to six months. PCP mimics melasma & may be misdiagnosed If proper history is not taken.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on re‐challenge with the same drug, hence their site on the skin is fixed, it has a short latency and is benign in nature.

 

FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.

 

  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply‐defined, round or oval erythematous and edematous plaque which evolves to become dusky, violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal. Most common cause:
    • NSAIDs - On Lips
    • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 118 page no 118.11, 118.12

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition pages 141-142, 1633

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to store blood for up to 35 days? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Citrate phosphate dextrose adenine – 1

 

Citrate-phosphate-dextrose solution with adenine (CPDA) is an anticoagulant and preservative for storage of blood. It can prolong red blood cell storage life up to 35 days. It maintains platelet viability. Usage of CPDA improves post-transfusion visibility and improves glucose and ATP levels in blood. CPDA can increase serum uric acid levels (due to adenine component).

 

The shelf life of storage of other options:

 

  • Acid Citrate dextrose - 21 days
  • Citrate-phosphate dextrose - 21 days
  • Citrate Phosphate 2 Dextrose (CP2D): 21 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine (CPDA-1) can be used to store blood for up to 35 days, making it the solution with the longest preservation capability among the options provided.

questions.text: A couple with 2 children who are not able to conceive for over an year now present to the OPD. The male partner is diagnosed to be having hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism. Which of the following is not true? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Low prolactin levels

 

Explanation:

 

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism in males is characterized by a deficiency of gonadotropins (LH and FSH), which leads to low testosterone levels and impaired spermatogenesis. This condition often results in oligospermia or azoospermia, contributing to infertility. Additionally, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is frequently associated with hyperprolactinemia rather than low prolactin levels.

 

  • Low LH and FSH: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is marked by low levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) due to inadequate secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • Low testosterone: The low levels of LH lead to reduced stimulation of Leydig cells in the testes, resulting in low testosterone levels.
  • Oligospermia: The low levels of FSH result in impaired spermatogenesis, often leading to oligospermia or azoospermia.
  • Low prolactin levels (Incorrect): Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is associated with hyperprolactinemia, not low prolactin levels. Elevated prolactin can inhibit the secretion of gonadotropins, further exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low LH and FSH: True. Gonadotropin deficiency is a hallmark of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Option B. Low testosterone: True. The deficiency in LH leads to low testosterone production.

 

Option C. Oligospermia: True. The deficiency in FSH leads to impaired spermatogenesis, causing oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A male with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism will have high prolactin levels, low gonadotropins (LH and FSH), low testosterone, and often oligospermia or azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 199, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: According to the latest labour care guidelines, the partogram is plotted in regular intervals after _ cm dilatation: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5 cm

 

  • Earlier, in the WHO modified partograph, labor is graphed and analysis includes use of action lines and alert lines.
  • In this partograph, the plotting starts in active phase (4cm)
  • The alert line is plotted at a cervical dilatation rate of 1cm/h
  • The action line is plotted 4h to the right of the alert line
  •  The 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • The WHO modified partograph has now been replaced by the WHO labor care guide where the new definition of active labor is 5 cm

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • As per the WHO modified partograph, plotting is started at 4cm cervical dilatation, and the 1st marking is always on the alert line
  • As per the Labor Care Guide, plotting is started at 5 cm cervical dilatation

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of progressive enlargement of his hands and feet. On examination, he has frontal bossing, a large tongue, and spade-shaped hands. His shoe size has also increased over the past few years. Which of the following tests is most appropriate for diagnosing his condition? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1)

 

The patient’s presentation, including features such as frontal bossing, macroglossia (large tongue), and spade-shaped hands, strongly suggests acromegaly. Acromegaly results from excessive secretion of growth hormone (GH), typically due to a pituitary adenoma. Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is the most reliable screening test for acromegaly because IGF-1 levels remain elevated throughout the day, unlike GH, which fluctuates. Elevated IGF-1 levels suggest acromegaly. A confirmatory test is the oral glucose tolerance test, where GH fails to suppress in acromegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid hormone assay: Thyroid function tests are used to diagnose thyroid disorders such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism. These tests are not used to diagnose acromegaly.

 

Option B. Serum prolactin: Although prolactinomas (prolactin-secreting tumors) are common pituitary adenomas, this patient's symptoms are not consistent with hyperprolactinemia. Prolactin measurement would not confirm acromegaly.

 

Option D. Serum testosterone: While testosterone testing may be indicated for evaluating hypogonadism, it is not relevant to the diagnosis of acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate initial test for diagnosing acromegaly is measuring insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels, as it reflects chronic exposure to elevated growth hormone.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Schwannoma

 

The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma showing hypercellular areas (Antoni A), including Verocay bodies, as well as looser (hypocellular) areas, myxoid regions (Antoni B).

 

 

 

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that are attached to the nerve but can be separated from it. Tumors form firm, gray masses that may have areas of cystic and xanthomatous change.

 

On microscopic examination tumors show a mixture of two growth patterns:

 

  • In the Antoni A pattern of growth, elongated cells with cytoplasmic processes are arranged in fascicles in areas of moderate to high cellularity and scant stromal matrix; the “nuclear-free zones” of processes that lie between the regions of nuclear palisading are termed Verocay bodies.
  • In the Antoni B pattern of growth, the tumor is less densely cellular (hypocellular) and consists of a loose meshwork of cells, microcysts and myxoid stroma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leiomyoma: Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors that do not typically present with the histological features observed in the provided image, such as Verocay bodies or the Antoni A/B patterns seen in schwannomas.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant tumor of skeletal muscle origin, often characterized by spindle-shaped cells and cross-striations on histology. It lacks the distinctive Antoni A and B patterns seen in schwannomas.

 

Option D. Fibromatosis: Fibromatosis refers to a group of benign fibrous tissue proliferations that are locally aggressive but lack the encapsulated, well-circumscribed nature of schwannomas. The histology of fibromatosis does not show the Antoni A and B patterns or Verocay bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannomas are benign nerve sheath tumors with distinct Antoni A and B growth patterns, including Verocay bodies. These features, along with the clinical presentation, are key to the diagnosis.

 

Clinical presentations: 

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no - 2595

choices.text: No need additional dose since she is ICT negative
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum irrespective of baby blood group
Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group

questions.text: Rh negative mother, ICT negative was given Anti D during 28 weeks of pregnancy. Which of the following is the ideal one? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hour postpartum depending on the baby blood group

 

In Rh-negative women with an Rh-positive partner, Anti-D immunoglobulin prophylaxis is administered to prevent Rh sensitization. If the mother is ICT (Indirect Coombs Test) negative, an initial dose of Anti-D (300 mcg IM) is given at 28 weeks of gestation. Following delivery, an additional dose of Anti-D should be administered within 72 hours if the newborn is Rh-positive. This prevents the mother from forming antibodies against Rh-positive fetal red blood cells that might have entered her circulation during delivery.

 

  • Anti-D (300 mcg IM) at 28 weeks: Given if ICT is negative.
  • Postpartum dose within 72 hours: Required if the baby is Rh-positive. This dose is essential to neutralize any fetal Rh-positive red cells that might have entered the mother's bloodstream during delivery.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. No need for an additional dose since she is ICT negative: Incorrect. Even if the ICT is negative, an additional dose is necessary postpartum if the baby is Rh-positive to prevent sensitization.

 

Option B. Give another dose of Anti-D 72 hours postpartum irrespective of baby blood group: Incorrect. The postpartum dose is only required if the baby is Rh-positive.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect as not all options are correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prophylaxis in Rh-negative women with an Rh-positive partner involves giving Anti-D (300 mcg IM) at 28 weeks (if ICT is negative) and repeating the dose within 72 hours after delivery if the baby is Rh-positive.

choices.text: Point of maximum tension in a fracture
Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury

questions.text: What are Kraissl’s lines?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Relaxed tension lines in skin

 

Kraissl’s lines, also known as relaxed skin tension lines (RSTLs), are lines on the skin that indicate the natural orientation of the skin under minimal or no tension. They are used in surgical planning, particularly in cosmetic surgery, to guide incisions so that they heal with the least visible scars. Kraissl’s lines differ from Langer's lines, which also describe lines of skin tension but are based on the alignment of collagen fibers within the dermis and are typically used to predict surgical wound healing outcomes.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Point of maximum tension in a fracture: Refers to the area where the mechanical stress is greatest on a broken bone, unrelated to skin tension lines.

 

Option C. Collagen and elastin lines in stab injury: Would refer to the orientation of these fibers in response to a penetrating trauma, which is not what Kraissl’s lines describe.

 

Option D. Point of tension in hanging: Refers to the mechanical stress points exerted during a hanging, specifically on the neck, which has no relation to the relaxed skin tension lines described by Kraissl.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Kraissl’s lines are crucial for surgical incision planning to ensure scars are minimally visible following healing, highlighting the importance of understanding skin tension dynamics in medical procedures.

questions.text: Which part of 2nd metatarsal is involved in the march fracture?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neck

 

MARCH FRACTURE

 

  • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck.
  • The second metatarsal is more prone to injury due to its limited motion from strong ligamentous attachment to the first and second cuneiforms and length compared to the other foot metatarsals.
  • They result from a sudden increase in the intensity, duration, and frequency of activity without sufficient rest.
  • The repetitive impact on the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises causes microfractures, which consolidate into stress fractures and are not the result of a single traumatic event.

 

 

  • Common Fracture Eponyms:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The march fracture involves the neck of the 2nd metatarsal followed by 3rd metatarsal.
  • It is a stress fracture of the metatarsal.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the shape of the trapezius muscle? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Triangular

 

Explanation:

 

  • The trapezius muscle is a large, triangular and paired muscle located on the posterior aspect of the neck and thorax. 
  • Each trapezius muscle is flat and triangularly shaped, with the base of the triangle situated along the vertebral column (the muscle's origin) and the apex pointing toward the tip of the shoulder (the muscle's insertion).

 

 

  • Trapezius muscle shape:
    • Considering left or right side - triangular shape
    • Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trapezius muscle:

questions.text: Dried blood spot (DBS) testing is commonly done in infants for: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inborn errors of metabolism.


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is a crucial tool used in neonatal screening for detecting inborn errors of metabolism. This test involves taking a small blood sample from the infant's heel, which is then dried on a filter paper and sent for analysis. Tandem mass spectrometry (TMS) is the primary technique used to analyze the sample for a wide range of metabolic disorders, such as phenylketonuria (PKU), maple syrup urine disease (MSUD), and others. Early detection through DBS testing allows for prompt diagnosis and treatment, significantly improving the prognosis for affected infants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood grouping: Blood grouping in neonates is typically done in cases of suspected neonatal jaundice to rule out Rh or ABO incompatibility, not using DBS testing.

 

Option C. Bilirubin testing: Bilirubin levels are tested to evaluate jaundice in neonates, particularly in cases of Rh or ABO incompatibility or breastfeeding-related jaundice, but this is not done using DBS.

 

Option D. Coombs Test: The Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that may cause hemolysis in conditions like hemolytic disease of the newborn. It is not performed using dried blood spots.

 

Educational Objective:


Dried Blood Spot (DBS) testing is primarily used for the early detection of inborn errors of metabolism in infants, using tandem mass spectrometry (TMS).

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.text: The value of TG and VLDL are high in chronic diabetes because of which of the following reasons: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

 

In chronic diabetes, increase in hormone sensitive lipase and decrease in lipoprotein is seen, due to which values of TG and VLDL are increased.

 

Insulin has inhibitory effect on hormone sensitive lipase. In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in hormone sensitive lipase activity. This promotes breakdown of lipids and release of TG, and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

 

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase, which is present on capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and degradation of transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to increase in VLDL and TG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase: Incorrect because in diabetes, the activities of these enzymes are reversed; HSL activity is increased, and LPL activity is decreased.

 

Option C. Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors: Incorrect because LDL receptor function generally affects LDL levels, not directly influencing VLDL or triglyceride levels.

 

Option D. Increased in activity of hepatic lipase: Incorrect for this context as hepatic lipase primarily affects the metabolism of HDL and to a lesser extent LDL, not directly impacting TG and VLDL levels in the way described for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In chronic diabetes, the combination of increased hormone sensitive lipase activity (due to low insulin levels) and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity leads to higher levels of triglycerides and VLDL. This reflects the central role of insulin in lipid metabolism regulation.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man, post-MI, had the following lab values. Which of the following must be his treatment plan? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

 

LDL - 125mg/dl

 

HDL - 33mg/dl

 

TGL - 270mg/dl
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atorvastatin 80 mg

 

Post-MI patients require aggressive management to reduce the risk of future cardiovascular events. The lab values indicate elevated LDL and triglycerides, along with low HDL. The treatment plan includes the use of high-intensity statin therapy, which is recommended to significantly lower LDL cholesterol as part of secondary prevention strategies in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). Atorvastatin 80 mg falls under the category of high-intensity statins and is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol significantly, which helps in reducing the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rosuvastatin + fenofibrate: This combination might be considered if there were specific concerns about triglyceride levels that could not be managed by statin therapy alone. However, the primary goal post-MI is to manage LDL levels aggressively with high-intensity statins.

 

Option C. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate primarily targets triglycerides and would not be the first choice when the primary objective is to lower LDL cholesterol post-MI.

 

Option D. Rosuvastatin 10 mg: While rosuvastatin is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol, a lower dose may not be sufficient for high-risk patients post-MI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high-intensity statin therapy, such as atorvastatin 80 mg, is essential in the management of patients after an MI to reduce the risk of subsequent cardiovascular events, regardless of initial cholesterol levels. This approach aligns with guidelines that emphasize aggressive LDL reduction in patients with established cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: The fibers indicated by the arrow in the given image originate from which of the following structures? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above image is the cross-section of the human brain in which the marked arrow indicates the fornix.
  • Fornix belongs to projectional fibers which are the type of white matter fibers. Fornix forms the efferent fibers of the hippocampus and connects it with the mammillary body. Hence the origin of fibers is hippocampus
  • The fornix is a white matter bundle located in the medial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres which arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus.
  • It connects various nodes of a limbic circuitry and is believed to play a key role in cognition and episodic memory recall.
  • Fornix is an example of association fiber and is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
  • The hippocampus is a seahorse-shaped structure located within the temporal lobes of the brain. The fornix originates from the hippocampus. Specifically, it receives input from the hippocampus and sends axons that project back to the hippocampus. This loop of connections is involved in memory formation and retrieval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Habenular: The habenular nuclei are small structures located near the thalamus and are involved in various functions, including the regulation of the pineal gland's activity. The fornix is not directly associated with the habenular nuclei. Instead, it primarily connects the hippocampus to other structures in the limbic system.

 

Option C. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain. The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies. This connection is an essential component of the Papez circuit, a neural circuit involved in memory and emotion.

 

Option D. Amygdala: The amygdala is an almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes and plays a key role in processing emotions, particularly fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala is part of the limbic system, it is not directly connected to the fornix. Instead, the amygdala communicates with other limbic structures through various neural pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A confirmed case of which of the following viral hemorrhagic fevers was found in India? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Nairovirus species. This disease is zoonotic, meaning it originates from animals, with ticks acting as vectors.

 

Crimean Congo Hemorrhagic Fever (CCHF):

 

  • Causative Agent: Nairovirus species.
  • Transmission: The primary vectors are ticks, specifically those of the Hyalomma genus.
  • Outbreaks: The disease can spread through person-to-person transmission, particularly in healthcare settings, where it poses a significant risk to healthcare workers and patients.
  • Symptoms: Include fever, muscle pain, dizziness, neck pain and stiffness, backache, headache, sore eyes, and photophobia. Severe cases can lead to extensive hemorrhaging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola: Ebola is another severe viral hemorrhagic fever but has not been reported in India. It primarily affects regions in Africa.

 

Option B. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is a mosquito-borne viral hemorrhagic disease endemic to Africa and South America. It has not been reported in India.

 

Option D. Marburg: Marburg virus causes a severe hemorrhagic fever similar to Ebola. It has also not been reported in India and is primarily found in Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is the viral hemorrhagic fever that has been confirmed in India. It is caused by the Nairovirus species and is transmitted by ticks, with potential for person-to-person transmission, especially in healthcare settings.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanisation in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20-25 Hz

 

Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 25Hz.

 

Tetanizing frequency: Rate of stimulation at which summation of contractions will occur

 

Tetanizing frequency can be calculated as à 1/contraction period.

 

As per the graph -

  • ﻿﻿Paper speed - 1000mm/sec.
  • ﻿﻿y-axis represents force of muscle contraction millivolts
  • x-axis represents duration of contraction in milliseconds with a scale of 10mm
  • ﻿﻿The scale on the x-axis is 10mm.
  • ﻿﻿Area under the graph is the muscle contraction.

 

Contraction period the duration from latent period to maximum force of contraction

So, in the given graph,

Contraction period is approximately 4 scales i.e., 40 mm.

As the speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec, contraction period = 40mm = (40/1000) = 40 msec = 0.04sec

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25Hz.

 

Educational Objective

 

Tetanisation

 

As the frequency increases, there comes a point where each new contraction occurs before the preceding one is over. As a result, the second contraction is added partially to the first, so that the total strength of contraction rises progressively with increasing frequency. When the frequency reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually become so rapid that they fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous. This is called tetanization.

questions.text: Identify the blue line shown in the below picture:(AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ohngren's line

 

  • Ohngren's line is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and angle of mandible.
  • It is used for classification of maxillary carcinoma.
  • Growth situated above the plane - Suprastructure - Poor Prognosis
  • Growth situated below the plane - Infrastructure - Good Prognosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frankfurt horizontal line, the line passing through the inferior border of infraorbital rim and superior border of external auditory canal, is one of the most widely used intracranial landmarks in cephalometric analysis.

 

 

Option B. Donaldson line is an imaginary line drawn posteriorly from the course of the horizontal semicircular canal, used to identify endolymphatic sac during endolymphatic sac decompression surgery for meniere’s disease.

 

 

Option C. According to Lederman’s classification, 2 horizontal lines called lines of Sebileau pass through orbit floor and maxillary sinus, producing Suprastructure, mesostructure and infrastructure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ohngren's line is used to classify maxillary carcinomas into suprastructure and infrastructure based on their location relative to the line, which is critical for determining the prognosis and approach for surgical intervention.

questions.text: A female from Himachal Pradesh presented with H/O thorn prick, a year back has a verrucous lesion in the skin with the following microscopic findings. Identify the agent? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

 

The given clinical history and histopathological image are suggestive of Chromoblastomycosis

 

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation.

 

Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics.

 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells (medlar/copper penny bodies)

 

The following are the various dematiaceous species of fungi

 

  • Phialophora verrucosa
  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Fonsecaea compacta
  • Rhinocladiella aquaspersa
  • Cladophialophora carrionii

 

Treatment: Surgical excision with wide margins is the treatment of choice for small lesions. Chemotherapy with flucytosine or itraconazole may be efficacious for larger lesions. The application of local heat is also beneficial.

 

MEDLAR/ SCLEROTIC BODIES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Blastomycosis is a systemic fungal infection caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis. It does not typically present with the sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option B. Pheohyphomycosis: Pheohyphomycosis is a broad term for infections caused by dematiaceous fungi but lacks the characteristic sclerotic bodies seen in Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Option D. Sporotrichosis: Sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii, typically presents with lymphocutaneous lesions but does not show the sclerotic bodies characteristic of Chromoblastomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its characteristic histopathological features, including granulomatous lesions with dark sclerotic bodies (Medlar or copper penny bodies), and is caused by various dematiaceous fungi. The clinical history of a thorn prick and the verrucous lesion further support this diagnosis.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring

 

PATELLA FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • The image displays a displaced patellar fracture, and the treatment of choice is Tension Band Wiring.
  • Tension Band Wiring (TBW) is a surgical method to secure the bones in place which are subjected to tension forces.
  • Wires and Screws or Pins are used to create this tension band effect.
  • In two-part fracture of Patella, the pull of Quadriceps on the proximal fragment keeps them apart.
  • In the operation, first the fractured fragments are reduced, fixed with TBW and then the extensor retinacula are repaired.
  • TBW converts distractive forces into compressive forces.

 

 

  • In case if there is comminuted fracture where accurate reduction is not possible, patellectomy is done.
  • Tension band wiring is done using: 
    • Cancellous screws for fracture of Olecranon process
    • K-wires and stainless steel wires for fracture of Patella

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension band wiring is the gold standard treatment for the two-part patella fracture.

questions.text: The most appropriate expansion of Apgar is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, respiration

 

  • The expansion of Apgar is appearance, pulse, grimace, activity and respiration.

 

 

 

The APGAR score is a quick assessment of a newborn's overall health and well-being immediately after birth. The score is based on a five-point scale that evaluates the newborn's appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. Each category is scored from 0-2, and the total score ranges from 0-10. A score of 7 or above is considered normal, while a score of 4-6 indicates that the newborn may require some medical attention, and a score of 3 or below indicates that the newborn requires immediate medical attention. The APGAR score is typically assessed at 1 and 5 minutes after birth and may be repeated if necessary.Top of FormBottom of Form

 

Educational Objective:


The Apgar score assesses a newborn's health based on five criteria: Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, and Respiration.

questions.text: The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tasimelteon

 

Tasimelteon and Ramelteon are melatonin agonists. Tasimelteon is used for the treatment of insomnia in blind persons, whereas Ramelteon is used for the treatment of jet lag and also used for sleep induction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latanoprostene: Is not relevant to the treatment of insomnia. It is a medication used to reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

 

Option B. Zerviate: Is an antihistamine eye drop used for the treatment of ocular itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis, not for insomnia.

 

Option D. Ramelteon: Is also a melatonin receptor agonist used for the treatment of insomnia, specifically for difficulties with sleep onset. It is not specifically indicated for Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder in blind individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tasimelteon is the drug of choice for treating insomnia in blind individuals due to its effectiveness in regulating the sleep-wake cycle by acting as a melatonin receptor agonist, particularly in those with Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder.

choices.text: Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with painful blisters on the skin and oral mucosa. Direct immunofluorescence is given below. Which of the following is false regarding the same? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antibiotics against hemidesmosomes

 

The given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

The question talking about the false statement.

 

In direct immunofluorescence testing for pemphigus vulgaris, the immunoglobulin deposition is observed along the plasma membranes of epidermal keratinocytes in a reticular or fishnet-like pattern, indicating an autoantibody attack against desmosomal adhesion proteins. This results in early suprabasal separation and loss of cell-to-cell adhesion (acantholysis). The severity and position of the blisters are related to the distribution of desmoglein 1 and 3 in the epidermis and the presence of autoantibodies to one or both proteins. The antibodies primarily disrupt the intercellular adhesive function of the desmosomes and may activate intercellular proteases. The observed pattern is due to the interepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3. The Tzanck smear is the preferred initial test, which involves collecting material from the floor of a fresh blister for microscopic examination, using Giemsa or Romanowsky stain. The presence of Tzank cells confirms the diagnosis.

 

This is incorrect and hence the false statement. Hemidesmosomes are associated with a different condition called bullous pemphigoid, where autoantibodies target components of the basement membrane, not the desmosomes as in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibodies against desmoglein 3: This statement is true, as pemphigus vulgaris involves antibodies against desmoglein 3, particularly in mucosal lesions.

 

Option B. Antibodies against desmoglein 1: This statement is also true. Pemphigus vulgaris can involve antibodies against desmoglein 1, which is primarily found in the superficial layers of the skin.

 

Option C. Suprabasal acantholytic blister is a characteristic feature: This is correct, as pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by suprabasal blisters formed due to acantholysis, resulting from the disruption of desmosomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by autoantibodies against desmosomal proteins (desmoglein 1 and 3), leading to a suprabasal acantholytic blister and a diagnostic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence.

choices.text: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.text: Proper functioning of an ICD tube is checked by: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oscillation of water column in the tube

 

Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the column of water in the chest tube oscillate up and down during respiration.

 

The oscillation or fluctuation of the water column in the water seal chamber of an ICD tube is a key indicator of proper functioning. This movement indicates that there is a patent (open) airway between the pleural space and the water seal, allowing air and fluid to exit the pleural cavity and preventing air from re-entering during inhalation. It's a visual confirmation that the ICD is effectively draining the pleural space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain: While air bubbles can sometimes be seen in the water seal chamber of an ICD system, their presence does not necessarily indicate proper functioning.

 

Option C. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can provide valuable information about the position and placement of the ICD tube, it is not typically used as the primary method for checking its ongoing functioning. X-rays are often performed initially after tube insertion to confirm placement.

 

Option D. Auscultation: Auscultation can help assess lung sounds and detect any abnormalities, but it may not be the most direct method for checking the functioning of an ICD tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

An intercostal drainage (ICD) tube is a thin, plastic tube that's inserted into the pleural space. The pleural space is the area between the chest wall and the lungs. 

 

The ICD tube is used to drain abnormal collections in the pleural cavity. It helps remove: Air (pneumothorax), Blood (hemothorax), Fluid (pleural effusion or hydrothorax, Chyle (chylothorax, Purulence (empyema. 

 

The ICD tube creates negative pressure in the chest cavity, which allows the lung to re-expand.

questions.text: Which procedure amongst the following has the highest probability of ureteric injury? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wertheim's hysterectomy

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the radical nature of the procedure. Wertheim's hysterectomy, also known as radical hysterectomy, involves extensive dissection and removal of not only the uterus but also the surrounding tissues, including the parametria and the upper part of the vagina. This extensive dissection increases the risk of ureteric injury.

 

However, it's important to note that while Wertheim's hysterectomy carries a higher individual risk for ureteric injury due to its radical nature, the most common cause of ureteric injury overall is abdominal hysterectomy, simply because it is the most commonly performed type of hysterectomy.

 

The overall incidence of ureteric injury in all pelvic operations is about 0.5-1%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abdominal hysterectomy: Although it is the most common cause of ureteric injury due to its high frequency, the individual risk per procedure is lower than that of Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Vaginal hysterectomy: This procedure has a lower risk of ureteric injury compared to abdominal and Wertheim's hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Anterior colporrhaphy: This procedure, which is used to repair the anterior vaginal wall, has a much lower risk of ureteric injury compared to hysterectomy procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteric injury is most associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to the extensive dissection involved in the procedure.

 

The risk of ureteric injury is highest with a radical hysterectomy followed laparoscopic or robotic hysterectomy followed by abdominal hysterectomy and least risk is with vaginal hysterectomy

 

Ref: TeLinde’s Operative gynecology 12th edition

questions.text: Dr. Radhika, the district health officer, is evaluating the efficiency of a subcenter in a rural region of India. This subcenter services a population of 5,000 people, and it has been reported that the crude birth rate (CBR) in this region stands at 20 per 1,000 people. Dr. Radhika wants to ensure that every pregnant woman receives antenatal care (ANC) to promote healthy pregnancies and reduce complications. With the current CBR, how many ANC registrations should the village health nurse (VHN) expect to handle annually? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 60

 

Calculation 

 

A subcentre serves a population of 5000 in plains.

 

CBR given is 20.

 

Expected number of pregnancies can be calculated by: Birth rate x population of the area / 1000 = 20 × 5000/1000 = 100.

 

A correction factor of 10% is added to adjust for pregnancy wastage in the form of abortions or stillbirths.

 

Hence, total number of expected pregnancies = Expected number of pregnancies + 10% of the same = 100 + 10 = 110

 

 Since not all pregnancies are officially registered, an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) is typically expected to have at least half of the anticipated pregnancies under her care registered at any point in time. Therefore, the count of Antenatal Care (ANC) registrations is calculated as 50% of the projected pregnancies.

 

Therefore, Total ANC registrations expected = total number of expected pregnancies/2 = 55

 

The closest answer is 60.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In assessing ANC needs based on CBR in a rural health setting, it's crucial to accurately apply demographic statistics to the actual population size.
  • Expectations should align with direct calculations unless specific adjustments are warranted by local conditions or policies.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the foramen labeled ‘2’ in the given image? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abducens nerve

 

The foramen marked as 2 in the given image is the superior orbital fissure and the abducens nerve passes through it.

 

Superior ophthalmic fissure is divided into 3 parts by annulus of zinn, parts of fissure and structures passing via each part are listed below:

  1. Superior -lateral part - Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve, trochlear nerve, superior opthalmic vein, lacrimal artery, meningeal branch of lacrimal artery. (Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve and trochlear nerve are the branches of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve.
  2. Middle/ Intermediate part - Nasocillary nerve (branch of ophthalmic division of trigeminal), occulomotor nerve (CN 3), abducens nerve (CN - 6) 
  3. Infero - medial part - Inferior opthalmic vein.


Note - Opthalmic vein passes via superior orbital fissure and not artery. Opthalmic artery passes via optic canal.
 

Brief summary about important structures passing via superior ophthalmic fissure is given below
 

Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The abducens nerve is responsible for controlling the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is essential for eye abduction (outward movement). Damage to the abducens nerve can result in difficulty moving the affected eye outward, leading to diplopia (double vision) when looking toward the affected side.

 

Ophthalmic Division of Trigeminal Nerve (Cranial Nerve V1): The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the upper face, including the forehead, scalp, and anterior part of the scalp. It also provides sensory innervation to the cornea, conjunctiva, and other structures within the orbit.

 

Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is responsible for rotating the eye downward and laterally. Damage to the trochlear nerve can lead to difficulty moving the affected eye downward and inward, causing vertical diplopia.

 

Superior ophthalmic vein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spinal Accessory Nerve: This nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. It primarily traverses the jugular foramen and is involved in motor functions, particularly in controlling the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Option C. Ophthalmic Artery: Although the ophthalmic artery passes through the orbit, it is not transmitted through the foramen marked 2 but accompanies the optic nerve through the optic canal.

 

Option D. Middle Meningeal Artery: The middle meningeal artery enters the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum, not the superior orbital fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA
Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid

questions.text: Identify the anaplerotic reaction among the following? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conversion of pyruvate to Oxaloacetate

 

Anaplerotic reactions are “filling up” reactions or “influx” reactions or “replenishing” reactions which supply 4-carbon units to the TCA cycle.

 

The important anaplerotic reactions are:

 

  1. Pyruvate to oxaloacetate by pyruvate carboxylase enzyme. It needs ATP.
  2. Glutamate is transaminated to alpha keto glutarate; and aspartate to oxaloacetate.
  3. Pyruvate can be carboxylated to malate by NADP+ dependent malic enzyme.

 

The citric acid cycle acts as a source of precursors of biosynthetic pathways, e.g., heme is synthesized from succinyl CoA and aspartate from oxaloacetate. To counterbalance such losses, and to keep the concentrations of the 4-carbon units in the cell, anaplerotic reactions are essential. This is called anaplerotic role of TCA cycle (Greek word, ana = up; plerotikos = to fill)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetyl CoA: This is not an anaplerotic reaction; it is a part of the link between glycolysis and the TCA cycle.

 

Option C. Conversion of pyruvate to Acetaldehyde: This reaction is part of ethanol fermentation, not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Option D. Conversion of pyruvate to Lactic acid: This is part of anaerobic glycolysis (fermentation), not an anaplerotic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplerotic reactions, such as the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, are crucial for maintaining the levels of TCA cycle intermediates, enabling the cycle to function efficiently and support biosynthetic demands.

questions.text: An esteemed research institute recently conducted a comprehensive study on individuals diagnosed with HIV to understand the progression and current health status of the participants. As a part of this study, the CD4 count, which plays a critical role in assessing the immune status of these individuals, was meticulously measured. Given the graphical representation provided that depicts the distribution of CD4 counts, can you infer the average CD4 count range that can be derived from this graph? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 300-400

 

If we convert the given graph data into a table, it will be as follows:


 

To determine the midpoint of each provided interval, it is necessary to calculate the midpoint for each interval individually. Following this, the resulting midpoints should be multiplied by the corresponding interval frequencies.

 

Mean = Sum of all observations / number of observations.

 

 

Mean = 34500/100 = 345.

 

Hence, 300 -400 is the answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When interpreting a frequency distribution graph like this for CD4 counts in HIV-positive individuals, it's essential to compute the weighted average based on the midpoint of each interval and the frequency of observations within each interval.
  • This provides a more accurate assessment of the overall average CD4 count, crucial for understanding the immune status in a clinical setting.

questions.text: What is the oxygen carrying capacity of 18-year-old boy with Hb of 14g/dl? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 18 mL/dL

 

The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is determined by the haemoglobin (Hb) concentration.

 

The average oxygen carrying capacity of haemoglobin is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of haemoglobin.

 

Oxygen carrying capacity formula:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = Hb (g/dL) × 1.34 mL/g

 

Substituting the given value:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 14 g/dL × 1.34 mL/g
  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 18.76 mL/dL
  • Therefore, the estimated oxygen carrying capacity for an 18-year-old boy with a haemoglobin concentration of 14 g/dL is approximately 18.76 mL/dL.

 

Educational Objective


The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of hemoglobin, a crucial metric in assessing the oxygenation potential of blood in clinical settings.

choices.text: The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck Stabilization
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X ray
The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support
The doctor should order a cervical X ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself

questions.text: A victim of a road traffic accident presented with paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The patient should not be shifted and portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization

 

The given clinical situation is suggestive of a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.

 

This option is correct because the patient is experiencing paralysis of both upper and lower limbs, which is indicative of a potential cervical spine injury. In such cases, it is crucial not to move the patient until the cervical spine is stabilized to prevent any further damage. Using a portable X-ray machine can help assess the cervical spine without the need to move the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X-rays: The patient's cervical spine must be stabilized before any radiographic evaluation is performed.

 

Option C. The doctor will instruct the radiographer to take cervical X-ray AP and lateral views without any cervical support: This option is not advisable because taking X-rays without cervical support can potentially worsen the patient's condition if there is a cervical spine injury. The patient's neck should be stabilized before any imaging is done.

 

Option D. The doctor should order a cervical X-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself: This option is not recommended because moving the patient without proper cervical spine stabilization can lead to further injury. The priority should be to immobilize the cervical spine and use imaging techniques that do not require moving the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management in a trauma patient with suspected cervical fracture consists of:

 

  1. The immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases is spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board
  2. It is followed by eliciting extremity movement to grossly assess spinal cord function. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicated an associated fracture.

 

Imaging is done by X-ray or CT with portable X-ray machines being preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but they cannot be used to visualize the cervicothoracic junction.

choices.text: Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
Ulnar fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
Ulnar shaft fracture and disruption of superior radio-ulnar joint
Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly defines Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

 

GALEAZZI FRACTURE

 

  • The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint, along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex, is called Galeazzi Fracture-dislocation.
  • It is the fracture of necessity.
  • A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results.
  • Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.
  • Monteggia and Galeazzi Fractures:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.

choices.text: Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

questions.text: A patient who was on a ventilator for one week suddenly gets agitated and self-extubates himself. What is the next step of management? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Watch for spontaneous breaths and re-intubate if needed

 

  • This is the most logical and safest immediate action. By observing the patient's spontaneous breathing, clinicians can gauge whether the patient is in distress or if they're maintaining their airway and oxygenating adequately. Self-extubation doesn't automatically necessitate re-intubation. If the patient is breathing well and does not desaturate, self-extubated patients may not require re-intubation. This can be confirmed by doing an arterial blood gas of the patient and checking his PaO2/FiO2 ratio and also watching for spontaneous breathing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Re-intubate: Simply re-intubating without assessment can be a precipitous action. It might be unnecessary if the patient can maintain their airway and oxygenation without assistance. Additionally, re-intubation has its own set of risks, including injury to the airway, so it's not a decision to be taken lightly.

 

Option B. Oxygenate and re-intubate: While it's always important to ensure a patient is well-oxygenated, especially if there's potential for re-intubation, the decision to re-intubate should be based on the patient's clinical status and not solely on the fact that they've self-extubated.

 

Option C. Start CPR: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) is initiated in situations of cardiac arrest. There's no indication in the scenario that the patient's heart has stopped. Starting CPR without evidence of cardiac arrest can cause harm, including broken ribs and internal injury.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Self-extubation requires careful assessment to determine if re-intubation is necessary. Observing the patient's spontaneous breathing and oxygenation status is crucial before making the decision to re-intubate.

questions.text: In a Preoperative surgical safety Checklist, which of the following is not a component? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Signature of the doctor

 

In a preoperative patient surgical safety checklist, doctor's signature is not needed.

 

the signature of the doctor, is not typically a component of the surgical safety checklist. Instead, the checklist focuses on verifying critical safety elements like patient consent, equipment functionality, and instrument sterility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Consent: Ensuring that informed consent has been obtained from the patient is a crucial component of preoperative safety checklists. It confirms that the patient has been informed about the procedure, risks, and alternatives and has given their consent for the surgery.

 

Option C. Functioning pulse oximeter: Checking the functioning of medical equipment like a pulse oximeter is an important step in preoperative safety. It ensures that necessary monitoring devices are in working order to monitor the patient's vital signs during surgery.

 

Option D. Sterility of instruments: Verifying the sterility of surgical instruments is essential to prevent infections during surgery. It ensures that all instruments that will come into contact with the patient are properly sterilized and safe for use.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which one of the following is not involved in iron metabolism? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transthyretin

 

Transthyretin is not involved in iron metabolism. It transports thyroxine.

 

Hepcidin, a 25-amino-acid (aa) peptide, is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceruloplasmin: Functions as a ferroxidase, converting Fe2+ (ferrous iron) to Fe3+ (ferric iron), which is essential for iron binding to transferrin for transport.

 

Option B. Hepcidin: A 25-amino-acid peptide that is the principal regulator of iron absorption and its distribution to tissues. It inhibits iron release from enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes by binding to ferroportin, leading to its degradation.

 

Option D. Transferrin: The main iron transport protein in the blood. It binds and transports iron to various tissues, including the bone marrow for erythropoiesis and the liver for storage.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 10% buffered formalin
95% ethyl alcohol
None of the above

questions.text: Fixative for PAP smear: (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 95% ethyl alcohol

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol. This fixative preserves the cellular detail necessary for accurate cytological evaluation by preventing cellular autolysis and degradation. The use of 95% ethyl alcohol ensures that the cells maintain their morphology, which is critical for detecting abnormalities such as dysplasia or carcinoma.

 

  • 95% Ethyl Alcohol: This is the standard fixative for Pap smears, ensuring optimal preservation of cellular details.
  • Ethanol Spray: In modern practice, an ethanol spray fixative is available, which can be conveniently used in an office setting to fix the smear immediately after it is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% buffered formalin: This fixative is typically used for histological specimens rather than cytological smears like the Pap test.

 

Option C. Air dried: Air drying is not recommended for Pap smears as it can cause cellular distortion and artifacts, which complicate the interpretation of the smear.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as 95% ethyl alcohol is the correct fixative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most commonly used fixative for a Pap smear is 95% ethyl alcohol, which preserves cellular morphology necessary for accurate cytological evaluation.

 

Ref: Page no 271, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to the OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, her eyes and pinna revealed blackish discoloration. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alkaptonuria

 

Explanation:
