Intervertebral disc calcification is seen in the image suggestive of alkaptonuria.

 

Deficiency: Homogentisic oxidase

 

Hyperpigmentation of ears and eyes suggestive of ochronosis is a clue. It is seen due to excessive build-up of homogentisic acid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DISH (Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis): Features ossification along the anterolateral aspect of at least four contiguous vertebral bodies, often with a "candle wax dripping" appearance, distinct from the findings in alkaptonuria.

 

Option B. Fluorosis: Typically presents with increased bone density and ossification of interosseous ligaments, not specifically associated with hyperpigmentation or the disc calcifications shown.

 

Option D. Ankylosing Spondylitis: Characterized by a "bamboo spine" appearance due to bony fusion, seen in younger patients (less than 50 years old), which does not typically include hyperpigmentation or the type of disc calcification seen in alkaptonuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alkaptonuria - Is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisic oxidase
  • Fluorosis – Increased bone density with interosseous ligament ossification 
  • DISH VS   Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B)  5’→ 3’ Exonuclease

 

DNA polymerase I (Kornberg’s enzyme) was isolated from Escherichia coli. It is a repair enzyme. It has both 3’ to 5’ and 5’ to 3’ exonuclease activities. When 5’ to 3’ exonuclease domain is removed, the remaining fragment retains the polymerization and proofreading activities; it is then called Klenow fragment. It is widely used in recombinant DNA technology.

 

The Klenow fragment retains the polymerization (5' → 3' DNA polymerase) and proofreading (3' → 5' exonuclease) activities but lacks the 5' → 3' exonuclease activity. Because of these retained activities, the Klenow fragment is widely used in recombinant DNA technology for applications that require DNA synthesis and proofreading without the degradation of the DNA template.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3' → 5' Exonuclease: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which allows it to proofread and correct errors during DNA synthesis.

 

Option C. 5' → 3' DNA polymerase: The Klenow fragment retains this activity, which is essential for synthesizing new DNA strands.

 

Option D. 3' → 5' DNA polymerase: This activity is not applicable in the context of DNA polymerase I and the Klenow fragment, as DNA polymerase functions in the 5' → 3' direction for synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I retains the 5' → 3' DNA polymerase and 3' → 5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities but lacks the 5' → 3' exonuclease activity, making it useful for specific applications in recombinant DNA technology.

questions.text: Which movement of the hip is being demonstrated by the examiner in the following diagram?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal rotation

 

HIP MOVEMENTS

 

  • The given image shows the internal rotation movement of the hip.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. External rotation.

 

 

Option C. Adduction.

 

 

Option D. Abduction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows internal rotation of hip.

choices.text: Repeat Colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came for routine PAP smear testing. The report came as HSIL. On colposcopy and biopsy, it was confirmed to be carcinoma in situ. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conization

 

Explanation:

 

Carcinoma in situ (CIS) of the cervix is classified as Stage 0 cancer. In a young woman with stage 0 cervical cancer, the management of choice is conization. Conization involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix, including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix. This procedure serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes:

 

  • Diagnostic: Conization provides a tissue specimen for histopathological examination, which is more definitive compared to a cytological specimen obtained from a Pap smear.
  • Therapeutic: If the histopathology shows clear margins, conization can be curative for carcinoma in situ.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical treatment and is generally reserved for cases where there is invasive cancer or other indications. It is not the first-line treatment for CIS in a young woman.

 

Option C. Repeat colposcopy and biopsy after 6 months: In the case of confirmed carcinoma in situ, conization is preferred. There is no need of repeat colpobiopsy 

 

Option D. HPV DNA testing: This test is used for screening and risk assessment but is not a treatment for confirmed carcinoma in situ.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conization, which involves the removal of a cone-shaped section of the cervix including the transformation zone and part of the endocervix, is the management of choice for carcinoma in situ in young women. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic if histopathology shows clear margins.

 

 

Ref: Page no 992, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Superficial transverse perineal

questions.text: The deepest part of perineal body injury, which causes cystocele, enterocoele and urethral descent is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pubococcygeus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pubococcygeus is the deepest part of the levator ani muscle.
  • Injury to it can cause enterocele, cystocele, and urethral descent.
  • The levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction.
  • Weakening of this muscle decreases support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bulbospongiosus, Option C. ischiocavernosus and Option D. superficial transverse perineal are all superficial muscles and their damage does not result in uterovaginal descent

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Supports of the vagal have been described by Delancey as shown below and defects in these lead to different levels of uterovaginal prolapse
    • Defect in Level 1 support: Vaginal apical prolapse and uterine prolapse
    • Defect in level 2 support: Cystocele and Rectocele
    • Defect in level 3 support: urethrocele and deficient perineal body

 

 

Ref: Page no 544, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: HPV Nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6, 11, 16, 18

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gardasil 9 is a nonavalent HPV vaccine effective against 9 serotypes of the virus
  • These include: 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.merckvaccines.com/gardasil9/

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in image below? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital melanocytic nevus

 

The Picture shown above depicts a child with a well circumscribed, black, heterogenous lesion covered with hair. This is a characteristic lesion of congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN).

 

CMNs are benign proliferations of nevus cells that are present at birth or develop shortly after. They are known for their variable pigmentation and the presence of terminal hair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermal verrucous nevus:

 

  • Description: A type of epidermal nevus (skin lesion) that is characterized by a warty or rough appearance as seen in the below image.

 

 

  • Why it's not the answer: While these can be present at birth or appear later in life, they don't typically present as deeply pigmented lesions with dense hair.

 

Option C. Melanoacanthoma:

 

  • Description: A rare, benign skin lesion that typically presents as a rapidly growing, hyperpigmented patch or plaque as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • It has a combination of melanocytes and keratinocytes.
  • Why it's not the answer: Although melanoacanthomas are pigmented lesions, they don't typically have dense hair growth, making it less consistent with the provided description.

 

Option D. Malignant melanoma:

 

  • Description: A type of skin cancer that arises from melanocytes. It can appear as a new, irregularly-shaped mole with uneven color or a mole that changes in size, shape, or color.
  • Why it's not the answer: While malignant melanoma is a pigmented lesion, the hallmark features include asymmetry, border irregularity, color variation, and diameter enlargement (often referred to by the mnemonic ABCD) as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • The presence of dense hair is not a characteristic feature of melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital Melanocytic Nevus (CMN):

 

  • Presentation: These nevi are typically pigmented and hairy and may vary in size. The presence of hair is a distinguishing feature that often helps differentiate them from other pigmented lesions.
  • Risk Factors: Larger nevi have a higher risk of developing malignant melanoma later in life, but this is rare with smaller nevi.
  • Management: Monitoring is essential, and in some cases, surgical removal may be considered for aesthetic reasons or to reduce melanoma risk, particularly in larger lesions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 75 Page no 75.14

questions.text: Which of the following milestones would you generally expect a 3-year-old child to display? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spoon handling

 

By the age of 24 months (2 years), most children develop the ability to use a spoon and feed themselves, which is a key fine motor skill. By the age of 3 years, this skill is typically well established, allowing the child to handle a spoon with greater proficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hopping on one foot: Hopping on one foot is a motor milestone that typically develops around the age of 4 years. Skipping usually comes later, around 5 years.

 

Option C. Copying a triangle: The ability to copy shapes such as a triangle is generally seen around 5 years of age. More complex shapes like a diamond are usually copied around 7 years of age.

 

Option D. Repeats sentences of 10 syllables: A child's ability to repeat longer sentences, including those with 10 syllables, generally develops around 4 to 5 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:


By the age of 3 years, a child is typically expected to handle a spoon and feed themselves, while more complex motor and language skills develop later.

questions.text: Fr with respect to size of Foley's catheter refers to: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Outer Diameter

 

Fr, short for French, is a unit of measurement used for the outer diameter of a Foley catheter. It is a common way to denote the size of the catheter, especially in medical and healthcare settings. The French scale is based on a 3:1 ratio, where one French unit (Fr) is approximately equal to 0.33 millimeters in outer diameter. For example, a Foley catheter with a size of 16 Fr has an outer diameter of approximately 5.3 millimeters.

 

Therefore, the diameter of a catheter in millimeters can be determined by dividing the French size by 3.

choices.text: Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed
Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed

questions.text: Which of the following is the test for immediate memory? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Digit span forward up to 7 digits with 2 skips allowed

 

This is the classic test for immediate memory. The patient is asked to repeat a sequence of digits (usually ranging from 5 to 9 numbers), and it tests the capacity of one's immediate memory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serial (100-7) subtraction test up to 5 steps: This tests concentration.

 

Option C. Digit span backwards up to 5 digits with 2 skips allowed: This is more challenging than the forward span and is used to assess working memory.

 

Option D. Serial (20-1) subtraction test up to 5 steps: Like the serial (100-7) test, it's more of an assessment for concentration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The digit span forward test, which involves repeating a sequence of numbers, is a measure of immediate memory and is a fundamental aspect of cognitive assessments.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 13.

questions.text: Dr. Sharma was enthusiastically reviewing the results of a randomized controlled trial (RCT) that aimed to compare the therapeutic benefits of Drug A and Drug B. To her surprise, the data suggested a statistically significant difference between the two medications, indicated by a p-value of <0.005. However, after a comprehensive review and collaboration with other experts, it was established that in real-world settings, both drugs had essentially equivalent therapeutic outcomes. This error in interpretation, where a difference was falsely identified when none existed in reality, is best described by which of the following statistical terms? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Alpha error

 

  • In the given scenario, null hypothesis (H0) can be that the two drugs being the same in effectiveness is true in reality.
  • The alternative hypothesis will be that both drugs are different.
  • Since P-value was found to be < 0.005, means that data is statistically significant and thus, null hypothesis is rejected.
  • But it is already established that the null hypothesis is true and now if we accept the alternative hypothesis even though it is false, this will be a type I error or alpha error.
  • Hypothesis (H): Is an assumption about the status of a phenomenon
  • Null Hypothesis (H0): In Biostatistics, when we have to prove a particular hypothesis about difference between 2 regimens, we make Null Hypothesis (For examples, If we have to prove that new treatment is better than older treatment, H0 = new treatment is not better than older treatment).

 

Statistical errors:

 

 

Type I Error (Alpha Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is true but rejected
  • Probability of Type I error is given by ‘P – value’ (probability of declaring a significant difference when actually it is not present)
  • Significance (a) level: is the maximum tolerable probability of Type I error
  • Alpha is fixed in advance: P – value calculated can be less than, equal to or greater than alpha (a)
  • Keep Type I error to be minimum (P < a): Then results are declared statistically significant

 

Type II Error (Beta Error):

 

  • Null hypothesis is false but not rejected (or accepted)
  • Probability of Type II error is given by beta (b) (probability of declaring no significant difference when actually it is present)

choices.text: Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb
Orbicularis oculi, neck, facial muscles, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, upper limb, thorax
Neck, muscles of eyelid, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

questions.text: In what sequence do muscles develop rigor mortis, progressing from early to late? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Orbicularis oculi, facial muscles, thorax, upper limb

 

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in various muscle groups.

 

Rigor mortis begins from the head and progresses down the body. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

 

  1. Myocardium
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rigor mortis

 

Rigor mortis is the post-mortem stiffening and contraction of muscles in the body, resulting from the depletion of energy stores, usually becoming noticeable a few hours after death and gradually resolving over time.”

 

  • It first affects the involuntary muscles first starting with the myocardium
  • Nysten’s law deals with the progression of rigor mortis in voluntary muscles
  • Order of appearance of Rigor mortis in different organs:

questions.text: Structure made up of dense irregular collagen is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dermis

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue. 

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligaments:

 

  • Composition: Primarily made up of dense regular connective tissue, which contains tightly packed collagen fibers that run in parallel directions.
  • Function: Connect bones to other bones.
  • Why it's not the answer: Ligaments have a more organized structure with the collagen fibers aligned in the same direction, which classifies them as dense regular connective tissue.

 

Option C. Tendons:

 

  • Composition: Made up of dense regular connective tissue, with collagen fibers that are closely packed and align in the same direction.
  • Function: Connect muscles to bones, aiding in the transmission of forces and movement.
  • Why it's not the answer: Like ligaments, tendons have collagen fibers that are organized in a parallel manner, making them dense regular connective tissue.

 

Option D. Bones:

 

  • Composition: Hard, dense connective tissue made up of cells (like osteocytes), as well as mineralized extracellular matrix containing collagen fibers and calcium phosphate.
  • Function: Provide structural support, protect vital organs, aid in movement, and store minerals.
  • Why it's not the answer: While bones do contain collagen, their primary structural component is the mineralized matrix which provides rigidity, distinguishing them from the dense irregular connective tissue of the dermis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticular dermis is comprised of the dense irregular connective tissue, that plays a crucial role in providing structural support and integrity to the skin due to its randomly oriented collagen fibers, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy rapidly develops hypoglycemia after moderate activity. Blood examination reveals raised levels of ketone bodies, lactic acid, and triglycerides. On examination, the liver and kidneys are found to be enlarged. Histopathology of the liver shows deposits of glycogen in an excess amount. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Gierke's disease

 

Clinical features are suggestive of Von Gierke’s disease (type I)

 

Salient features of Von Gierke’s Disease –

 

  • It is the most common type of glycogen storage disease.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase is deficient.
  • Fasting hypoglycemia that does not respond to stimulation by adrenaline. The glucose cannot be released from liver during overnight fasting .
  • Clinical Features: Hyperlipidemia, lactic acidosis and ketosis.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate is accumulated, so it is channeled to HMP shunt pathway producing more ribose and more purine nucleotides.
  • Purines are then catabolized to uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia
  • Glycogen gets deposited in liver. Massive liver enlargement may lead to cirrhosis.
  • Children usually die in early childhood.
  • Renomegaly

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pompe's disease: This is a glycogen storage disease characterized by a deficiency of acid alpha-glucosidase. It primarily affects muscles and causes cardiomegaly but does not present with the same biochemical profile as Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option C. McArdle's disease: This is characterized by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase and primarily affects muscle metabolism, leading to muscle cramps and myoglobinuria after exercise, but not the described biochemical abnormalities or hepatomegaly.

 

Option D. Cori's disease: Also known as Forbes disease or glycogen storage disease type III, it is caused by a deficiency of the debranching enzyme. While it can cause hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia, it does not present with the specific profile of ketonemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperlipidemia seen in Von Gierke's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Decrease in GFR
Decreases renal blood flow
Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all except? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries

 

Explanation

 

 

Efferent arteriolar constriction increases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries.

 

Constriction of the efferent arterioles:

 

  1. Increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries raising the glomerular hydrostatic pressure
  2. Reduces renal blood flow
  3. Increase in filtration fraction and glomerular colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure)

 

Therefore, if the constriction of efferent arterioles is severe (more than about a threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the rise in colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure) exceeds the increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure caused by efferent arteriolar constriction. When this occurs, the net force for filtration actually decreases, causing a reduction in GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in GFR: Incorrect in this context as initial efferent arteriolar constriction might actually increase GFR by raising hydrostatic pressure, though severe constriction can eventually decrease it.

 

Option B. Decreases renal blood flow: Incorrect as this is a direct effect of efferent arteriolar constriction.

 

Option D. Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries: Incorrect as this is indeed a result of efferent arteriolar constriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efferent arteriolar constriction leads to an increase in both hydrostatic and oncotic pressures within the glomerular capillaries, which can modify renal blood flow and the dynamics of glomerular filtration. It does not decrease the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented in clinic with low back pain & stiffness since 2 months. Modified Schober's test done was positive. An X-ray was done as shown in the image. Most likely diagnosis is:(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
    • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
    • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
    • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
    • Clinical Presentation:
      • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15 - 25 years.
      • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness and improves with activity.
      • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur. Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
      • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
  • Diagnostic Criteria: Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these three:
      • Inflammatory back pain
      • Limited chest expansion (<5 cm at 4th ICS) {not a reliable criterion in elderly because of pulmonary disorders}
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (Schober test/Modified Schober test).
    • Inflammatory back pain is classified if 4/5 are present
      1. Pain for > 3 months
      2. <40 years age
      3. Insidious onset
      4. Pain improves with exercise
      5. Pain at night
  • Spine radiograph shows:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.

 

 

Dagger sign

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
  • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) are seen.

 

 

Trolley track sign

 

  • Bamboo spine  appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e. there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration. So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phoshatase levels. Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to Dexa scan of 30 year old individual and T score is calculated. WHO classification of values in a DEXA scan are T score 0 to –1 is normal, T score –1 to –2.5 is osteopenia, and T score less than –2.5 is osteoporosis. The patient is usually asymptomatic until a vertebral fracture occurs. The x-ray of the spine shows codfish vertebrae.

 

 

Option C. PIVD. Lumbar Disc Herniation is a very common cause of low back pain and unilateral leg pain, known as radiculopathy. The patient usually presents with decreased lumbar movement, paraspinal muscle spasm. The provocative tests like straight leg raise is positive. The x-ray shows decreased space between the affected vertebrae due to disc prolapse.

 

 

Option D. Osteoarthritis. Spine osteoarthritis is the presence of disc degeneration and osteophyte formation. The typical presentation of patients with symptomatic osteoarthritis of the spine is pain, stiffness, and motion restriction, which is commonly accompanied by referred pain. The lumbar spine provides pain located in the buttock and thigh region. Lumbar spine osteoarthritis can be associated with radicular pain above the knee.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows the bamboo spine appearance which is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Out of the diagnostic criterias for ankylosing spondylitis, one of the criteria is the positive modified Schober’s test i.e., limited lumbar spine movement in saggital and frontal planes.

questions.text: Haglund’s deformity is seen in which joint?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ankle

 

HAGLUND DEFORMITY

 

  • Haglund deformity is prominent Calcaneal tuberosity and overlying bursitis (retro-calcaneal).
  • It is a bony enlargement formed at posterosuperior aspect of calcaneum along with retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haglund deformity is seen at the ankle joint.

choices.text: It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA
It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins

questions.text: True regarding Mitochondrial DNA is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA

 

Mitochondrial DNA and RNA

 

  1. There is a dichotomy on the mitochondrial metabolism. Some of the mitochondrial protein synthesis is under the control of mitochondrial DNA; but important proteins of the outer membrane of the mitochondria are synthesized under the influence of nuclear DNA.
  2. The mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is circular, has about 16,500 nucleotides. The mtDNA has information for synthesis of 2 ribosomal RNAs, 22 tRNAs and 13 proteins. All of them are components of electron transport chain. It has 37 genes that encode 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain (total of 67 i.e., about 20%). However, most of mitochondrial proteins are encoded by nuclear DNA and synthesized in the cytoplasm.
  3. Maternal inheritance: Since, the mitochondria are inherited cytoplasmically, the mtDNA is inherited from the mother. Mother transmits mtDNA through oocyte.
  4. There are hundreds of copies of mtDNA in each cell (nuclear DNA has only 2 copies).
  5. Heteroplasmy is defined as the presence of normal and mutant mtDNA in different proportions in different cells. During cell division, mtDNA replicates and they segregate to the daughter cells. If a mutation occurs in mtDNA, the daughter cells may inherit the mutant or normal mtDNA.
  6. High mutation rate: 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA
  7. Age-related accumulation of mutations in mtDNA may be responsible for age-related decrease in cellular OXPHOS function, and progression of other degenerative diseases.
  8. Defects in mitochondrial genome will lead to mitochondrial myopathies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One set from each parent: Incorrect. mtDNA is inherited only from the mother.

 

Option C. It codes for more than 25% of oxidative phosphorylation proteins: Incorrect. mtDNA encodes about 13 protein subunits of the respiratory chain, approximately 20% of the total, not more than 25%.

 

Option D. It has 3 X 10^9 base pairs: Incorrect. mtDNA is much smaller, with about 16,500 base pairs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate than nuclear DNA, is maternally inherited, and contains 37 genes encoding essential components of the electron transport chain.

 

Ref - Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students 7th edition

choices.text: Incidence reduces and prevalence remains the same
Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with metastatic melanoma and begins a newly developed combination of chemotherapy and immunotherapy. His oncologist explains that this treatment significantly prolongs survival. Which of the following statements best describes the expected impact of this treatment on the epidemiological metrics of melanoma? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incidence remains the same and prevalence increases

 

The introduction of the new drug combination improves survival in patients with metastatic melanoma. This means that more people will live longer with the disease, which directly increases prevalence—the total number of people living with the disease at a given time.

 

Since the treatment does not prevent the disease from occurring, the incidence—the rate of new cases—remains unchanged. Therefore, with longer survival but no change in the rate of new cases, the overall prevalence will rise.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time
  • Prevalence: Is total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over a point or period of time
  • Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence: Given the assumption that population is stable AND incidence & duration are unchanging,

 

Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of the disease

 

P = I × d

questions.text: The given life cycle is suggestive of which of the following viruses? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis B

 

The given life cycle is of the hepatitis B virus.

 

Steps:

 

  • The infectious virion attaches to cells and uncoating occurs.
  • Cell enzymes in the hepatocytes convert dsDNA to covalently closed circular double-stranded DNA (cccDNA)
  • HBV mRNA and pre-genome RNA is synthesized using cDNA as a template.
  • pre-genome RNA is encapsidated by packaging signal into new core particles.
  • These new core particles are templates for HBV reverse transcriptase.
  • Negative-strand DNA is synthesized by viral polymerase by reverse transcription.
  • The cores bud from the pre-Golgi membranes, acquiring HBAg-containing envelopes.
  • Once viral particles are assembled, they either exit the cell or cause reinfection of the same cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV: HIV is an RNA virus with a life cycle that involves reverse transcription of RNA into DNA, integration into the host genome, and the production of new virions. The depicted life cycle does not match HIV's replication cycle.

 

Option C. Influenza: Influenza is an RNA virus with a replication cycle involving the nuclear replication of viral RNA and budding from the plasma membrane. Its life cycle does not involve cccDNA or reverse transcription.

 

Option D. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a DNA virus that also forms episomal DNA in the nucleus, but its replication and assembly processes differ from those of HBV, particularly in the use of the Golgi for envelopment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B virus is characterized by the formation of cccDNA in the nucleus, reverse transcription of RNA to DNA within the core particles, and budding from the pre-Golgi membranes.

Option D)

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Only Myasthenia gravis, among the conditions mentioned above, would show dramatic improvement after administration of an injection (Anti-ChE medication).

 

In myasthenia gravis, there is unilateral myogenic ptosis where, after a short rest, the symptoms recover rapidly.

 

A quick test in the office can be to ask the patient to look up and hold that position, and then observe if there is fatiguability of the levator muscle such that the upper eyelids start to drift downwards while the patient is looking up. The definitive diagnosis is made through various clinical, pharmacological and serologic tests.

 

Diagnostic Tests

 

1. Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test:

 

Edrophonium chloride inhibits acetylcholinesterase, thereby prolonging the presence of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. This results in enhanced muscle strength. This test is only useful in patients with objective, measurable findings on physical exam, like ptosis or a tropia. In ptosis, a positive test is the elevation of eyelids in 2-5 minutes post administration of Tensilon. A negative response is no improvement within 3 minutes.

 

2. Ice Test:

 

This is also a simple diagnostic test that can be done in the clinic. It is highly sensitive and specific for MG. The ice test is useful for ptosis. An ice pack is applied to the affected upper eyelid for 2-5 minutes. A positive test is the improvement of ptosis by > 2mm or more. This transient improvement in ptosis is due to the cold decreasing the acetylcholinesterase break-down of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6th nerve palsy: This condition primarily causes abduction deficit (inability to move the eye laterally), which would not explain the ptosis nor improve with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option C. 3rd nerve palsy: Though it can cause ptosis and eye movement abnormalities, symptoms are due to mechanical dysfunctions or nerve damage and do not improve quickly with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Option D. Horner syndrome: Characterized by ptosis, miosis (pupil constriction), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating), but does not involve hypotropia or improve dramatically with Anti-ChE medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis

 

  • A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to autoimmune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane.
  • The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.
  • Ptosis and failure of convergence are early and prominent features.
  • A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmine or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • The resultant increase in acetylcholine available at the receptor sites leads to an improvement in the muscular function, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Note:

 

The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fiber Electromyography

 

The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with history of fever and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mono-nucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heterophile antibody test

 

  • Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody reaction test and is used in glandular fever like Infectious mononucleosis.
  • Heterophile antibodies have the ability to agglutinate RBCs of different animal species.
  • Paul Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes for agglutination and Monospot test uses horse erythrocytes for agglutination.
  • In Infectious Mononucleosis, IgM heterophile antibodies are detectable for the first 3 months of infection and they can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Complement mediated cell damage: This refers to a different mechanism where the complement system causes lysis of cells. It is not related to the principle of the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Option B. Precipitation reaction uses a soluble antigen to form a precipitate in a solid media when combined with an antibody.

 

Option D. Neutralisation reaction: Neutralization reactions involve antibodies that neutralize the pathogen, preventing it from infecting cells. This principle does not apply to the Paul Bunnell test.

 

Educational Objective

 

The Paul Bunnell test is a heterophile antibody test used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis. It detects IgM heterophile antibodies that can agglutinate sheep erythrocytes, which are present during the early stages of the infection.

choices.text: It does not depend on the macronutrients

questions.text: Which of the following is Thermogenic food? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High protein diet

 

Increased heat production or increased metabolic rate following the intake of food is called as thermogenic effect of food or diet-induced thermogenesis or specific dynamic action (SDA) of food (non-shivering thermogenesis).

 

Part of this is due to the expenditure of energy for digestion; absorption and active transport of products of the digestion. Another reason for this expenditure of energy is that reserve materials, such as glycogen, triacyl glycerol, protein, etc. are synthesized from small molecules available after digestion.

 

A high protein diet leads to higher protein turnover resulting in increased diet induced thermogenesis.

 

The values of SDA are: for proteins 30%, for lipids 15%, and for carbohydrates 5%. This means that out of every 100 grams of proteins consumed, the energy available for doing useful work is 30% less than the calculated value.

Thermogenesis results from the presence of an uncoupling protein, thermogenin, in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

 

It is a common experience that during hot weather following the consumption of a protein rich meal, one feels hot and humid for a while. On the other hand, in cold weather, the same would provide a comfortable feeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High fat diet: While fats do contribute to thermogenesis, their specific dynamic action (SDA) is lower (15%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Option B. It does not depend on the macronutrients: This statement is incorrect, as the thermogenic effect of food does depend on the type of macronutrient consumed.

 

Option D. High carbohydrate diet: Carbohydrates have a lower thermogenic effect (5%) compared to proteins (30%).

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high protein diet has the highest thermogenic effect compared to fats and carbohydrates, leading to increased energy expenditure during digestion and metabolism.

questions.text: Name the location of the nucleus supplying the muscle marked with the question mark in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superior colliculus

 

The highlighted muscle is the medial rectus, which is supplied by the oculomotor nerve. The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve is situated at the level of the superior colliculus. The oculomotor nerve arises from a nuclear complex that includes the oculomotor nucleus and Edinger-Westphal preganglionic nucleus. The oculomotor nucleus is comprised of several groups of large motor neurons that innervate the ipsilateral inferior rectus, inferior oblique, and medial rectus in dorsoventral order. Additionally, a column of cells located medially innervates the contralateral superior rectus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior olivary: This is part of the auditory pathway and has no involvement in eye muscle control.

 

Option B. Inferior colliculus: Also part of the auditory pathway, located in the midbrain but not involved in motor control of eye movements.

 

Option D. Fascial colliculus: This term is likely a typographical error for "facial colliculus," which refers to a structure in the brainstem associated with the facial nerve, not the oculomotor nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleus of the oculomotor nerve, responsible for innervating the medial rectus muscle among others, is located at the level of the superior colliculus in the midbrain. This is crucial for understanding the neural control of eye movements, particularly in how various components of the eye are coordinated for proper visual alignment and focus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss and looked jaundiced. Upon further investigation, you suspect a parasitic infection. You obtain a stool sample and operculated eggs in the feces. Further examination reveals the presence of a parasite with a complex life cycle with snail and plants as the intermediate host. Which parasite is most likely responsible for the above symptoms? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica

 

Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domestic animals.

 

Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae (metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, where they mature into adults.

 

The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch in freshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst on aquatic vegetation.

 

Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.

 

Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

 

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Fasciolopsis buski: Fasciolopsis buski is an intestinal fluke, and while it also involves snails as intermediate hosts, it does not primarily target the liver. Infection typically occurs through ingestion of aquatic plants, but the symptoms and life cycle do not match those described.

 

Option C. Paragonimus westermani: Paragonimus westermani, the lung fluke, has a complex life cycle involving snails and crustaceans. It primarily causes pulmonary symptoms rather than abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss. Eggs are typically found in sputum, not feces.

 

Option D. Clonorchis sinensis: Clonorchis sinensis, the Chinese liver fluke, also involves snails as intermediate hosts and can cause liver-related symptoms. However, the life cycle and specific hosts differ slightly from Fasciola hepatica. It primarily affects the liver and bile ducts but is more common in certain geographic regions.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Fasciola hepatica, the sheep liver fluke, is diagnosed by identifying eggs in the feces, and it has a complex life cycle involving snails and aquatic vegetation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the hormone from the picture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth Hormone

 

The above image shows variations in growth hormone levels through the day.

 

The level is low during the day and is around 5 ng/mL (another reference says <2 ng/mL) increasing in response to specific stimuli like:

 

  1. Exercise.
  2. Physical and emotional stress.
  3. Ingestion of protein.
  4. In hypoglycaemia (Starvation, Fasting)
  5. Spike occurs after 3 hours of meals or exercise.

 

In adults and children in the evening, it shows the highest level.

 

The secretion of GH is episodic and variable; sometimes, the level may reach 40 ng/ml in a healthy subject.

 

The highest values are noted during the deepest sleep level. So, its level is increased during sleep. The GH may increase ten times the normal level during sleep.

 

So, the best time to for growth hormone is 60 to 90 minutes after deep sleep. Or do the exercise for 30 minutes and get the GH sample, which will be at the highest level.

           

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cortisol: Incorrect. Cortisol typically peaks in the early morning and lowers throughout the day, not in response to meals or exercise in this marked pattern.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen levels do not show such acute changes in response to daily activities like meals or exercise.

 

Option D. Insulin: Incorrect. Insulin spikes are typically observed post-meal but would not show the pattern of peaks associated with exercise or sleep as depicted.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone levels exhibit significant variability, influenced by factors such as time of day, meals, exercise, and sleep, with the highest levels occurring during deep sleep. This pattern underlines the hormone's critical roles in growth, metabolism, and recovery processes.

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. She is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain. On examination, a right adnexal mass was palpable and non-tender. On ultrasound, a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary was noted. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

 

Explanation:

 

The next best step in managing a postmenopausal woman with a small (3 x 3 cm) smooth ovarian cyst is to measure CA-125 levels. CA-125 is a tumor marker used to assess the risk of ovarian cancer, especially in postmenopausal women. Given the benign characteristics of the cyst on ultrasound and the small size, the initial step is to evaluate CA-125 levels:

 

  • CA-125 Levels: If the CA-125 levels are normal (less than 35), the patient can be advised to have regular follow-ups.
  • Regular Follow-ups: If CA-125 levels are normal, a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be repeated in 6-12 weeks to monitor the cyst. If the cyst persists but remains benign, yearly TVS is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and advise regular follow-up once in 6 months: While reassurance is part of the management, initial evaluation with CA-125 is necessary to rule out malignancy before deciding on the follow-up schedule.

 

Option B. Confirm USG findings by ordering a CT scan: A CT scan is not the first-line investigation for a simple cyst with benign features. Initial evaluation with CA-125 is more appropriate.

 

Option C. Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of the cyst: This is invasive and not indicated for a small, benign-appearing cyst without other concerning features.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple cysts in the post-menopausal age grp:

 

  • ≤ 1cm: Considered normal
  • ≤ 5 cm: Ca125; if normal, repeat in 6-12 weeks
  • > 6 cm: Surgical evaluation

 

Ref: Page no 217, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Dr. Rathi, an obstetrician in a suburban Indian clinic, was counseling Mrs. Mehta, a software engineer, on nutritional needs during pregnancy. Mrs. Mehta has a sedentary desk job and is entering her second trimester. The doctor emphasized the significance of an appropriate caloric intake to ensure both maternal and fetal health. Given her lifestyle and the stage of pregnancy, by how much should Mrs. Mehta ideally increase her daily caloric consumption? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 350 kcal/day

 

The suggested daily calorie intake for a pregnant woman in a sedentary occupation should be raised by approximately 350 calories.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy Additional Energy Requirements:
    • +350 kcal/day
  • Lactation Additional Energy Requirements:
    • 0-6 m: +600 kcal/day
    • 6-12 m: +520 kcal/day

questions.text: The stain done on a section of liver shown below is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sweet’s reticulin stain

 

Stain demonstrates reticular fibers of the liver and hence has to be reticulin stain.

 

On microscope - plump hepatocytes are surrounded by rims of atrophic hepatocytes. The variation in parenchymal architecture is not easily seen on an H&E stain, and reticulin staining is required to appreciate the changes in hepatocellular architecture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warthin starry stain: This stain is typically used to identify organisms such as Helicobacter pylori or spirochetes and is not used for reticulin fibers.

 

Option B. Steiner silver stain: Steiner silver stain is used for the detection of certain microorganisms, like Legionella and Treponema, and is not related to reticulin fibers.

 

Option D. Grimelius silver stain: This stain is used for the detection of neuroendocrine cells by highlighting granules within these cells, and again, it is not related to the reticulin fibers of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sweet’s reticulin stain is specifically used to demonstrate reticular fibers in the liver, allowing for the visualization of changes in hepatocellular architecture that are not apparent with H&E staining.

questions.text: Dr. Rajan is a consultant at a primary health center, frequently encountering cases of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and reproductive tract infections (RTIs). He usually prefers syndromic approach for managing these conditions due to limited diagnostic facilities. A 28-year-old male patient walks in, presenting with discharge from his urethra, indicating a possible urethritis. The patient is unaware of the specific causative organism. Given the syndromic management approach, which combination of medications would Dr. Rajan most likely prescribe to effectively treat both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cefixime + Azithromycin

 

  •  According to the syndromic approach for managing STIs/RTIs, the preferred treatment for both gonococcal and non-gonococcal urethritis involves a combination of Azithromycin and Cefixime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lady was discharged after a normal vaginal delivery. On the third day she came back with fever, tachycardia and seizures. Fundus showed papilledema with no focal deficits. Diagnosis is? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cortical vein thrombosis

 

  • The given clinical situation likely suggests Cortical Vein Thrombosis.
  • Cortical Vein thrombosis
    • Risk factors:
      • Pregnancy and puerperium
      • Oral contraceptives
      • Pro thrombotic conditions
    • Clinical presentation
      • Highly variable
      • Headache is the most common symptom.
      • With or without
      • Vomiting
      • Papilledema
      • Focal deficits
    • Investigation
      • Brain MRI with MR venography - most sensitive
      • CT - normal in 30 % of cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Subarachnoid hemorrhage unlikely as there are no focal deficits

 

Option B. Meningitis: Meningitis would have presented with neck rigidity / photophobia and early papilledema goes against acute meningitis.

 

Option C. Acute Migraine: Acute Migraine does not present with seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cortical/ Cerebral vein thrombosis should be thought of in a patient with headache and seizures/ other neurological deficits following delivery

questions.text: Cause of death in the position shown in the image below is: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Positional asphyxia

 

The position shown is Jack-knife position that leads to positional asphyxia (Restriction of lung expansion d/t abnormal position of the body). It is a position where the victim's thighs and knees are driven against the chest causing indirect compression of the chest and restriction of breathing movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Wedging: Infant falls in the small gap between wall & bed and getting wedged there. It is a type of traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option B) Burking: Accused sits on chest of victim & closes mouth/ nostril as well. Its Mechanism is smothering combined with traumatic asphyxia.

 

Option D) Traumatic asphyxia: it is asphyxia due to restriction of lung expansion as a result of mechanical fixation of chest and not due to abnormal body position hence this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classification of Mechanical Asphyxia

 

1. Suffocation Asphyxia

  • Smothering
  • Gagging
  • Traumatic Asphyxia (Crush Asphyxia)
  • Positional Asphyxia (Postural Asphyxia)
  • Burking
  • Overlaying
  • Choking (Café Coronary)

 

2. Compression of neck

  • Hanging – force is body weight / body is suspended
  • Strangulation – force is anything other than body weight / no suspension.

 

3. Drowning

questions.text: ALK positivity is seen in which of the following neoplasms: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor

 

ALK (anaplastic lymphoma kinase) is seen in Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor of lung.

 

(ALK) Anaplastic lymphoma kinase {CD246} is a tyrosine kinase receptor encoded by the ALK gene located on chromosome 2p

 

ALK positive tumors respond to ALK kinase inhibitors, therefore it has an excellent prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibromatosis: ALK positivity is not associated with fibromatosis. This condition is characterized by fibroblastic proliferation, and ALK is not typically involved.

 

Option B. Synovial sarcoma: Synovial sarcoma does not show ALK positivity. It is more often associated with specific translocations, such as t(X;18)(p11;q11), resulting in SS18-SSX fusion genes.

 

Option C. Ewing sarcoma: Ewing sarcoma is characterized by a specific EWSR1-FLI1 fusion gene due to a translocation involving chromosomes 11 and 22. ALK positivity is not seen in Ewing sarcoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ALK positivity is seen in:

 

  • Lung Cancers – Adenocarcinoma, small cell cancer, anaplastic cancer
  • Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Renal cell carcinomas
  • Esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
  • Breast cancer notably the inflammatory subtype
  • Colonic adenocarcinoma
  • Glioblastoma multiforme
  • Anaplastic thyroid cancer

questions.text: In the image given below, identify the muscle responsible for the opening of the mouth? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. b

 

In the above image the structure marked ‘b’ represents the lateral pterygoid muscle which is responsible for opening the mouth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. a-Temporalis: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and retraction of mandible.

 

Option C. c – Medial pterygoid: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and ‘side-to-side’ movements of the mandible.

 

Option D. d –Buccinator: This muscle is responsible for compresses cheek against molar teeth
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: Which of the marked foramen does the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve pass through? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation

 

The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve passes through the foramen ovale which is marked as 4 in the above image.

 

The foramen ovale is also located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.

 

The structure that passes through the foramen ovale is the mandibular nerve (the third division of the trigeminal nerve, Cranial Nerve V3). It carries sensory information from the face and provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.

 

Foramen ovale is situated anterior and medial to foramen spinosum, and is larger in size than spinosum.


Structures passing vis foramen ovale can be remembered by the following mnemonic
M - Mandibular nerve (3rd division of trigeminal)
A - Accessory meningeal artery
L - Lesser petrosal nerve
E - emissary veins
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • The foramen spinosum is a small foramen located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, near the foramen ovale.
  • The structure that passes through the foramen spinosum is the middle meningeal artery. This artery supplies blood to the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

 

Option B. Internal Acoustic Meatus:

 

  • The internal acoustic meatus is located in the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • Several important structures pass through this foramen:
    1. Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII): It carries motor and sensory fibers related to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    2. Vestibulocochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII): It carries sensory information related to hearing and balance.

 

Option C. Jugular Foramen:

 

  • The jugular foramen is located at the junction of the temporal and occipital bones, near the base of the skull.
  • Several structures pass through the jugular foramen:
    1. Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX): It carries motor and sensory fibers to the pharynx and taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue.
    2. Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X): It carries motor and sensory fibers to various organs in the thorax and abdomen and plays a crucial role in autonomic functions.
    3. Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI): It supplies motor fibers to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
    4. Internal jugular vein: It is a major vein that drains blood from the brain and parts of the face.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The provided picture shows a patient who has undergone mastoidectomy. Identify the lateral semicircular canal in the image. (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A

 

In the given image of a post-mastoidectomy surgical field, label A corresponds to the lateral semicircular canal. The lateral semicircular canal is a crucial component of the inner ear's vestibular system, involved in maintaining balance and spatial orientation. It can be identified by its specific location relative to other anatomical landmarks visible in the image, such as the tympanic bone, mastoid tip, and the spine of Henle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: This label points to the posterior semicircular canal, which is a bony protrusion in the mastoid portion of the temporal bone, serving as an important landmark during mastoid surgery.

 

Option C: This indicates the sigmoid sinus, a dural venous sinus within the skull, lying beneath the cranial bone and above the structures of the middle and inner ear.

 

Option D: Labelled as the Tegmen, which is part of the temporal bone that forms the roof over the middle ear and mastoid antrum, shielding these structures from the intracranial contents.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The lateral semicircular canal, identified at label A, is part of the vestibular system, crucial for balance and orientation.

questions.text: Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Striate cortex

 

Explanation:

 

  • The structure marked A in the above image is the splenium of the corpus callosum and it is connected to the striate cortex.
  • The striate cortex, also known as the primary visual cortex or V1, is involved in early visual processing, such as processing basic features of visual stimuli like edges, orientation, and motion. It does have connections to the splenium of the corpus callosum, especially for the transfer of visual information between the hemispheres. This connection allows the brain to process visual information from both eyes and integrate it into a cohesive visual experience.
  • The splenium of the corpus callosum primarily connects various regions of the cerebral hemispheres, facilitating communication between the left and right cerebral hemispheres.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cortex: The orbital cortex is involved in various aspects of emotional processing and decision-making. It is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is a crucial structure for memory formation and spatial navigation. While it has connections to other parts of the brain, its primary connection to the corpus callosum is through the more anterior parts, not the splenium.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum. It is a structure located at the base of the brain where some of the optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over to the opposite side of the brain. This crossover allows for the integration of visual input from both eyes, but it occurs before the information reaches the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The corpus callosum is divided into four parts: 
    • The rostrum is continuous with the lamina terminalis and connects the orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The genu is the bend of the anterior corpus callosum and the forceps minor is a tract that projects fibres from the genu to connect the medial and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The body forms the long central section and its fibres pass through the corona radiata to reach the surface of the hemispheres. 
    • The splenium tapers away at the posterior section, with the forceps major projecting fibres from the splenium to connect the two occipital lobes. Striate cortex (visual area) is located in occupital lobe.
  • The hippocampus is not connected directly to the splenium, but situated inferior to the splenium.

questions.text: A young patient with acute psychosis is admitted to the hospital. He wakes up and asks for his wife, even though she is in the same room as him. When she is pointed out, he claims that she is not his wife and that she is being impersonated by someone else. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capgras syndrome

 

The described scenario involves the patient's belief that a familiar person, in this case his wife, has been replaced by an imposter. This specific delusion is characteristic of Capgras syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fregoli syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a delusional misidentification syndrome where the patient believes that a familiar persons can change his physical appearance and disguise as a stranger, and that he can take multiple different appearances.

 

Option C. Delusion of subjective doubles: Delusion of subjective doubles refers to the patient's belief that he or she has many doubles who are living life of their own.

 

Option D. Othello syndrome: Othello syndrome pertains to the delusional belief that one's partner is unfaithful.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional misidentification syndromes include Capgras syndrome, Fregoli’s syndrome, syndrome of intermetamorphosis and syndrome of subjective doubles.

 

 

Reference: Sim’s Symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 124-125.

choices.text: Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg

questions.text: All are components of CURB65 except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Systolic blood pressure less than 10mm Hg

 

The correct answer, D, specifies a systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg, which is not part of the CURB-65 criteria. The specified threshold for blood pressure in the CURB-65 is ≤90 mm Hg systolic or ≤60 mm Hg diastolic.

 

CURB-65 criteria is used to assess the severity of illness in case of pneumonia, especially community acquired pneumonia. It includes 5 variables -

 

C - Confusion

 

U - Urea>7mmol/L

 

R - Respiratory rate >30/mins

 

B - Blood pressure, SBP </=90 mmHg or diastolic </= 60 mmHg

 

65 - Age >/= 65 years

 

Management

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CURB-65 scoring system is used to evaluate pneumonia severity, which does not include systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg but instead sets the threshold at ≤90 mm Hg systolic or ≤60 mm Hg diastolic.

questions.text: While performing triage of children who are victims of a school bus accident, which one will you attend to first? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Airway Obstruction

 

The most appropriate answer is airway obstruction.

 

Maintaining a patent airway is crucial for the survival of any trauma patient, especially children. An airway obstruction can quickly lead to severe respiratory distress and, if left untreated, can result in death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grade 4 Shock: While shock is a critical condition, attending to airway obstruction takes precedence because it directly impacts oxygenation, which is vital for life. Treating shock without addressing airway obstruction may not be effective.

 

Option C. Flail Chest: Flail chest is a serious chest injury, but it may not be an immediate threat to the airway. It should be assessed and treated promptly but is not the first priority compared to airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Severe head injury: Head injuries are also critical, but immediate attention to airway obstruction is necessary to ensure the child's ability to breathe and maintain oxygenation. Head injuries can be assessed and managed after ensuring a clear airway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triage decisions are to be made by deciding which injuries constitute the greatest immediate threat to life.

 

In general, airway problems are more rapidly lethal than breathing problems › circulation problems > neurologic injuries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with NYHA Class III heart failure presents with shortness of breath, peripheral edema, and laboratory findings showing a potassium level of 5.5 mEq/L and a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Which of the following drugs would NOT be contraindicated in this scenario? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Furosemide

 

In this patient with heart failure and hyperkalemia (potassium of 5.5 mEq/L), certain medications that can increase potassium levels are contraindicated. Furosemide, a loop diuretic, is preferred in such a scenario because it helps in potassium excretion, thereby lowering potassium levels. Therefore, furosemide is not contraindicated in this patient and may be beneficial in reducing the edema and hyperkalemia associated with heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Although digoxin does not directly affect potassium levels, it can become toxic in the presence of electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia. Therefore, close monitoring is required, and digoxin should be used cautiously.

 

Option B. Spironolactone: This is a potassium-sparing diuretic and is typically avoided in patients with elevated potassium levels, as it can worsen hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Enalapril: An ACE inhibitor, enalapril can increase potassium levels by reducing aldosterone secretion, further contributing to hyperkalemia. Thus, it should be avoided in patients with hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In heart failure patients with hyperkalemia, furosemide is a safe choice as it promotes potassium excretion. Drugs that increase potassium levels, such as spironolactone and ACE inhibitors, should be avoided.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm?: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior vena cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. The IVC passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening, which is situated to the right of the central tendon. This opening allows the IVC to move between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophagus: The esophagus passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the esophageal hiatus, which is located just to the left of the central tendon. This allows the esophagus to traverse from the thoracic cavity to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option B. Aorta: The descending (thoracic) aorta carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body. It passes through the diaphragm via the aortic hiatus, which is posterior to the central tendon. The aorta then continues its descent into the abdominal cavity.

 

Option D. Sympathetic Chain: The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, consists of a series of ganglia connected by nerve fibers. It runs vertically along each side of the vertebral column and is not directly associated with the diaphragm or its central tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diaphragm has three anatomic openings: the aortic hiatus (T12), the esophageal hiatus (T10), and the caval foramen (T8)

 

  • The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm from the caval foramen.
  • Esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus.
  • Aorta passes through the aortic hiatus.

 

Sympathetic chain passes through the minor apertures crossing the crura of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Cellular junctions present in a cardiac muscle are all except? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zonula occludens

 

Zonula occludens is the other name for the tight junction. It is absent in a cardiac muscle.

 

Cardiac muscle fibers are striated bound by sarcolemma with a centrally placed nucleus.

 

Myofibrils are embedded in the sarcoplasm.

 

Sarcomere of the cardiac muscle has all the contractile proteins, namely actin, myosin, troponin and tropomyosin. Cardiac muscle fiber is branched.

 

Intercalated disk - formed by the fusion of the membrane of the cardiac muscle branches.

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Fascia adherens - broad intercellular junction both of sarcolemma and intercalated disc of cardiac muscle fibers that anchors actin filaments.

 

Option C. Gap junction - fused membranes adjacent muscle fibers form gap junctions. It is permeable to ions and it facilitates the rapid conduction of action potential from one fiber to another.

 

Option D. Macula adherens - Also called as desmosomes are intercellular junctions specialized for strong adhesion. They prevent the separation of cardiac myocytes during individual fiber contraction by binding to intracellular intermediate filaments (cytoskeleton), which joins cells together.

 

 

Educational Objective

 

 

Zonula occludens are absent in cardiac muscle; instead, this muscle type prominently features fascia adherens, gap junctions, and macula adherens, which are essential for mechanical stability and coordinated contraction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given HE image? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatic valvular disease

 

The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease. During acute Rheumatic Fever (RF), focal inflammatory lesions are found in various tissues. Distinctive lesions occur in the heart, called Aschoff bodies, which consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to ovoid nuclei in which the chromatin is disposed in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation “caterpillar cells”) and may become multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Infective endocarditis is characterized by large, friable vegetations composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microorganisms, which would not exhibit the Aschoff bodies seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Myxoma: Myxomas are benign tumors of the heart that typically present as a gelatinous mass, and they do not feature Aschoff bodies or the inflammatory response seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that can affect the heart but does not produce the Aschoff bodies characteristic of rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Aschoff bodies, characterized by foci of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and Anitschkow cells, is pathognomonic for rheumatic valvular disease and indicates a history of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page no – 1044

questions.text: Definition of PUO includes all of the following except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Undiagnosed after one week of investigation

 

The correct answer is C because the definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) does not specify that the fever must remain undiagnosed for only one week. According to the established criteria for diagnosing PUO, the investigation can be longer and more thorough before labeling a fever as PUO. The criteria include a fever exceeding 38.3°C on at least two occasions, persisting for more than three weeks, and a diagnosis that remains uncertain after comprehensive history taking, physical examinations, and routine investigations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fever persisting for more than 3 weeks: This is incorrect because it is a part of the definition of PUO, where the fever must last for more than three weeks.

 

Option B. Immunocompromised status should be ruled out: This is incorrect  as a choice because being non-immunocompromised is a criterion in the diagnosis of PUO, which means any immunocompromised status should indeed be ruled out.

 

Option D. Temperature more than 38.3°C: This is also incorrect as it is part of the criteria, where the temperature must be more than 38.3°C on multiple occasions to consider it as PUO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Criteria for diagnosis of PUO:

 

  • Fever > 38.3 degrees C (101° F) on 2 occasions.
  • Duration > 3 weeks.
  • Not immunocompromised state.
  • Diagnosis not certain after history, physical examination and routine and obligatory investigations.

questions.text: Below is a radioactive scan for thyroid pathology. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting Adenoma

 

Image findings are suggestive of hypersecreting adenoma.

 

  1. Increased uptake in the right lobe at the thyroid
  2. Suppressed uptake in left lobe of thyroid

 

These findings are highly suggestive of a hypersecreting adenoma. This condition occurs when a benign tumor in the thyroid gland produces thyroid hormone independently of the normal regulatory mechanisms, leading to an overactive area (hot spot) in one part of the thyroid, with suppression of activity in the rest of the gland due to negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid: Incorrect as this type of cancer typically presents with a "cold nodule," which shows reduced or no uptake on a radioactive scan. The scan shows no areas of reduced uptake indicative of a cold nodule.

 

Option C. Grave’s disease: Incorrect because Grave's disease generally causes a diffuse increase in uptake across the entire thyroid gland due to widespread stimulation of thyroid tissue. The scan does not show diffuse uptake, which rules out Grave's disease.

 

Option D. Lateral aberrant thyroid: Incorrect as this condition involves ectopic thyroid tissue that might appear as functioning thyroid tissue outside the normal location. The scan does not indicate any ectopic thyroid tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersecreting adenoma in the thyroid is characterized by increased radioactive uptake in one area of the thyroid with suppression in other areas, reflecting independent hormone production from the adenoma.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old smoker who is a known case of hypertension was on enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide. He had an episode of hemoptysis and on evaluation, he was found to have bronchogenic carcinoma with brain metastasis. His lab values were Na-124mg/dL, creatinine - 2.8mg%, blood sugar 112mg/dL, blood urea - 24mg/dL, serum osmolality 255mosm, urine osmolality - 110 mosm, 24-hour urinary sodium - 110 and BP - 150/90 mmHg.

 

Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis of the low sodium values in him? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SIADH

 

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH) is the most probable diagnosis in this patient. The diagnostic criteria and the patient's clinical presentation support this conclusion:

 

 

Additionally, lung cancer (specifically bronchogenic carcinoma) can often cause SIADH, either through ectopic production of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) or related paraneoplastic syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diuretic induced hyponatremia: Incorrect because the pattern of serum and urine osmolality does not align solely with diuretic use; the high urine sodium and euvolemia are more indicative of SIADH.

 

Option C. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome: Incorrect as this condition typically presents with hypovolemia and low blood pressure due to significant sodium and fluid loss, which is not evident in this patient who maintains a normal blood pressure.

 

Option D. Pseudohyponatremia: Incorrect because the reduced serum osmolality directly indicates true hyponatremia, not a distortion caused by high levels of lipids or proteins in the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SIADH can be associated with malignancies like lung cancer, presenting with hyponatremia, low serum osmolality, and inappropriately concentrated urine despite the presence of low plasma osmolality. This clinical scenario should prompt consideration of SIADH, particularly in patients with known malignancies and typical lab findings.
