questions.text: In the given electron micrograph, the structure marked with an asterisk (*) represents which of the following? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation

 

  • The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates presynaptic secretory vesicles.
  • The structure marked with the arrowhead is postsynaptic density.
  • The secretory vesicles are synthesized by the neurons and are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.
  • In the synaptic region, the plasma membrane of the presynaptic cell is specialized for vesicle exocytosis; synaptic vesicles, which contain a neurotransmitter, are clustered in these regions. The opposing membrane of the postsynaptic cell (in this case, a neuron) contains receptors for the neurotransmitter.

 

 

On electron microscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A . Mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies of 0.5-2.0 micron long on an electron microscope, consisting of an outer and an inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B. Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph represents presynaptic secretory vesicles, essential for neurotransmitter storage and release during synaptic transmission, highlighting their role in neuronal communication.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to OPD with a twin pregnancy at 10 weeks of gestation. She has a 3-year-old female child who was born at term and had 2 first trimester abortions previously. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score/formula? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) G4P1 A2 L1

 

Determining the Parity Index/ Obstetric Formula

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

The obstetric score here is G4P1A2L1.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. But if it results in 2 living children it will be Live 2.

choices.text: Amoxicillin
Fluconazole
Metronidazole

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of greenish discharge per vagina and on examination she had a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the treatment for her? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metronidazole

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of greenish-yellow discharge and a strawberry cervix is characteristic of trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. The diagnostic feature of trichomoniasis includes the presence of motile flagellate organisms on a wet mount microscopy.

 

  • Characteristic findings:
    • Colour of discharge: Greenish yellow
    • On examination: Strawberry cervix and vagina
    • pH: >5
    • Diagnosis (Wet mount): Motile flagellate organism

 

Treatment:

 

  • The recommended treatment for trichomoniasis is metronidazole. It can be administered as a single dose of 2g or 200mg TDS for 7 days.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: This antibiotic is used to treat various bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections, but it is not the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis.

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: This antibiotic is used for bacterial infections but is not effective against trichomoniasis.

 

Option C. Fluconazole: This antifungal medication is used to treat candidiasis, not trichomoniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strawberry cervix and greenish-yellow vaginal discharge are characteristic of trichomoniasis, which is treated with metronidazole.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Strawberry cervix and vagina are characteristic of Trichomoniasis

 

Ref: Page no 164, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops.
Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day.
Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. No history of fever or blood in stools. The mother says he is irritable and eagerly drinks water if given. On examination, eyes are sunken and in the skin pinch test, the skin retracted within two seconds but not immediately. What treatment is advised for the child? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give oral fluids and zinc supplementation only and ask mother to come back if danger sign develops

 

In this question, the child has some dehydration because he or she is restless and irritable, drinks water freely, has sluggish skin retraction (2 seconds) on skin pinch test, and has sunken eyes.

 

Treatment according to the WHO Integrated Management of Neonatal and Childhood Diseases (IMNCI) guideline plan B.

 

  • Oral rehydration therapy
  • Zinc supplements,
  • Sustained breastfeeding

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Give oral fluids and ask mother to continue the same and visit again the next day: Zinc supplementation is an important treatment protocol for diarrhea. In this option that point was missing, therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option C. Consider severe dehydration start IV fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre: If the child was having refusal to drink with skin pinch more than 2 seconds, we could have thought of severe dehydration. Therefore this is not the right option.

 

Option D. Wait and observe: Child is eagerly drinking which is a feature of some dehydration, therefore, wait and observe is not the right option.

 

Educational Objective:


In a child with some dehydration, the recommended treatment includes oral rehydration therapy, zinc supplementation, and continued breastfeeding, with instructions to return if danger signs develop.

questions.text: A patient has a HbA2 of 3% and HbF of 97%. A peripheral blood smear is taken. Which of the following blood pictures will be seen in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

Based on the patient's HbA2 and HbF levels, this patient likely has beta thalassemia major, a condition where the body produces less than normal amounts of hemoglobin beta chains. This results in a decrease in HbA, and an increase in HbF and HbA2.

 

Beta thalassemia will have high HbA2 levels (>3.5%) and slightly increased HbF

 

The peripheral blood smear of a patient with beta thalassemia major will show hypochromic microcytic red blood cells (Image 1), which are smaller and paler than normal. Howell-jolly bodies (image 2) will also be seen. These cells may also be more variable in size and shape, and may have a target cell appearance (Image 3) due to increased membrane-to-cytoplasm ratio.

 

Other possible findings on the blood smear may include anisocytosis (variation in cell size), poikilocytosis (variation in cell shape), and nucleated red blood cells (if the patient has severe anemia).

 

It's important to note that the blood smear alone is not sufficient to diagnose beta thalassemia major, and additional laboratory tests and genetic testing may be necessary for confirmation.

 

Image 2 shows Howell–Jolly bodies, which are small, round, dark purple inclusions within red blood cells (RBCs), representing residual nuclear DNA fragments. These inclusions are typically removed by a healthy spleen; their presence often indicates splenic dysfunction or absence.

 

Conditions Associated with Howell–Jolly Bodies

 

The presence of Howell–Jolly bodies is commonly associated with:

 

  • Post-splenectomy: Following surgical removal of the spleen
  • Functional asplenia or hyposplenism: Conditions like sickle cell disease can lead to spleen dysfunction
  • Megaloblastic anemia: Due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency
  • Severe hemolytic anemia: Where rapid RBC destruction overwhelms the spleen's filtering capacity
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes: Bone marrow disorders affecting blood cell production

 

Educational Objective:

 

In beta thalassemia major, the peripheral blood smear typically shows hypochromic microcytic red blood cells and target cells, which are best represented by Image 1 and Image 3.

choices.text: High up in the false pelvis

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady nearing her due date has been admitted following regular contractions. The resident doctor did an examination and told the intern that the head is at +1 station. Where is the exact position of head? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Just below ischial spine

 

In obstetrics, the station of the fetal head during labor is measured relative to the ischial spines of the maternal pelvis. The ischial spines are bony landmarks that serve as reference points.

 

  • 0 Station: The presenting part of the fetus is at the level of the ischial spines.
  • Positive Stations (+1 to +5): These indicate the presenting part is below the ischial spines. For example, +1 station means the presenting part is 1 cm below the ischial spines.
  • Negative Stations (-1 to -5): These indicate the presenting part is above the ischial spines.

 

At +1 station, the fetal head is just below the ischial spine by 1 cm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. At the perineum: This would indicate a more advanced station, such as +4 or +5.

 

Option C. Just above the ischial spine: This would be a negative station (e.g., -1 or -2).

 

Option D. High up in the false pelvis: This would correspond to a much higher, negative station.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When the station of the head is described during a vaginal exam, it is with respect to the ischial spine:

 

  • The ischial spine is taken as 0 station.
  • Anything above the ischial spine is denoted as a negative station (-).
  • Anything below the ischial spine is denoted as a positive station (+).

 

Ref: Page no 153, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenocysteine

 

Selenocysteine is abbreviated as SeCys is the 21st human amino acid.

It is formed by co-translational modification.

 

It is seen at the active site of the following enzymes:

 

  1. Thioredoxin reductase
  2. Glutathione peroxidase, which scavenges peroxides;
  3. De-iodinase that removes iodine from thyroxine to make triiodothyronine
  4. Selenoprotein P, a glycoprotein seen in mammalian blood.

 

Replacement of Secys by Cys will lead to decreased activity of these enzymes.

Deficiency of these enzymes may be related with atherosclerosis, as these enzymes have an antioxidant function. Their concentration falls in selenium deficiency.

 

Its structure is COOH–CHNH2–CH2–SeH. It is incorporated into protein during translation process. There is a tRNA, specific to carry Secys. The codon is UGA. Biosynthesis of selenocysteine is by replacing the oxygen of serine by selenium; this is done by two steps:

 

  1. Se + ATP → Se-P + AMP + Pi
  2. Serine + Se-P → SeCys + Pi

 

The code for SeCys is UGA, which is identified by a SeCys insertion element in the mRNA, with the help of a specific elongation factor. The tRNA-Sec is first charged with serine, then it is converted into SeCys. This is then inserted into the correct position, when protein is synthesized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triiodothyronine (T3): Formed by post-translational modification of thyroxine (T4) through the enzymatic removal of an iodine atom.

 

Option C. Hydroxyproline: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of proline, a process critical for the stability of collagen.

 

Option D. Hydroxylysine: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of lysine, also important in collagen stability.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Sense changes in position of the muscle
Sense changes in length of the muscle

questions.text: The function of the Golgi tendon organ is to? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sense changes in muscle tension

 

The Golgi tendon organ functions as a crucial sensory receptor that provides important feedback to the central nervous system, contributing to muscle control, injury prevention, and maintaining appropriate muscle tension during various activities.

 

The Golgi tendon organ is an encapsulated sensory receptor through which muscle tendon fibers pass. About 10 to 15 muscle fibers are usually connected to each Golgi tendon organ, and the organ is stimulated when this small bundle of muscle fibers is “tensed” by Excessive contraction or stretching the muscle.

 

The major difference in excitation of the Golgi tendon organ versus the muscle spindle is that the spindle detects muscle length and changes in muscle length, whereas the tendon organ detects muscle tension as reflected by the tension in itself.

 

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sense changes in muscle direction: Incorrect because muscle direction is not detected by GTOs but rather involves the coordinated action of multiple muscles and joints.

 

Option C. Sense changes in the position of the muscle: Incorrect because muscle position is generally sensed by muscle spindles, not GTOs.

 

Option D. Sense changes in the length of the muscle: Incorrect because muscle length changes are detected by muscle spindles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Golgi tendon organ primarily functions to monitor and respond to changes in muscle tension, helping to prevent muscle damage from excessive force during activities.

questions.text: A child presents with bilateral proptosis. Which investigation will help you in arriving at a diagnosis of chloroma? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Peripheral smear

 

Chloroma or granulocytic sarcoma is an extramedullary manifestation of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). It is a localized tumor forming mass occurring in the skin or orbit due to local infiltration of the tissues by leukemic cells. The tumor is greenish in appearance due to the presence of myeloperoxidase.

 

The diagnosis of AML is made by a combination of routine blood picture and bone marrow examination, coupled with cytochemical stains and other special laboratory investigations.

 

The best investigation among the given options would be a peripheral blood smear which shows the following-

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: While platelet count can be abnormal in AML, it is not the primary diagnostic tool for chloroma.

 

Option C. Hb concentration: Hemoglobin concentration might be reduced in AML due to anemia, but it is not specific for diagnosing chloroma.

 

Option D. Leucocytic count: Leukocyte count can be elevated, normal, or low in AML, but it does not specifically help diagnose chloroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The peripheral blood smear is the key investigation to diagnose chloroma, revealing the presence of myeloblasts, which are indicative of acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cortan pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, page no - 1154

choices.text: Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM
Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV
Atropine 3 mg
Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.text: The drug of choice in Anaphylactic Shock is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM

 

Anaphylactic shock is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that requires immediate treatment. The first-line treatment for anaphylactic shock is the administration of adrenaline (epinephrine). Adrenaline works by counteracting the severe hypotension, bronchospasm, and edema that occur during anaphylactic reactions.

 

Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM is the recommended dose for the treatment of anaphylaxis. This intramuscular injection provides rapid absorption and action, which is critical in managing the symptoms of anaphylaxis effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV: This dose and concentration of adrenaline are typically used in cardiac arrest scenarios, not for initial treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Option C. Atropine 3 mg: Atropine is used primarily to treat bradycardia (slow heart rate) and is not effective in managing anaphylactic shock.

 

Option D. Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV: Adenosine is used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and is not relevant for the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 33-year-old male with attempted poisoning was brought to the casualty in a drowsy state. His pulse was 140/min, respiratory rate -30/min. His ABG showed metabolic acidosis. Urine analysis showed Calcium oxalate crystals. Identify the likely poison?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ethylene glycol

 

The presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a key diagnostic sign of ethylene glycol poisoning. Metabolic acidosis and drowsiness is also indicating towards ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formaldehyde is ruled out because the patient’s symptoms like, metabolic acidosis, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, do not align with the typical effects of formaldehyde poisoning, which usually involves respiratory and mucous membrane irritation.

 

Option C. Paraldehyde While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with paraldehyde poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of ethylene glycol poisoning.

 

Option D. Methyl alcohol (methanol) While drowsiness and metabolic acidosis can be associated with methyl alcohol poisoning, the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine is a characteristic feature of glycol poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene glycol poisoning

 

Ethylene glycol is the major constituent of antifreeze solutions. It is a clear, colorless, odorless, non-volatile liquid with a bitter-sweet taste.

 

Action: Ethylene glycol itself is not toxic, but the toxicity is due to metabolites glycolic and oxalic acids which inhibits oxidative phosphorylation.

 

  • Oxalic acid combines with calcium to form calcium oxalate crystals which accumulates in the proximal convoluted tubules causing renal failure.
  • Metabolic acidosis occurs from glycolic acid.
  • Ingestion of ethylene glycol produces CNS depression which may be accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramps. Metabolites of ethylene glycol produce severe metabolic acidosis and damage to the brain, heart, and kidneys

 

Treatment - Sodium bicarbonate, calcium gluconate, and 4-methyl pyrazole.

questions.text: In the fracture seen in the X-ray below, what is the most commonly expected vascular injury?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brachial artery

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
  • Fracture supracondylar humerus is:
    • Most common fracture associated with vascular injury.
    • Most common fracture to involve brachial artery (10% cases).
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome in children.
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemic contracture.
    • Non-union is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial artery. It can be associated with the fracture of the distal radius.

 

Option C. Ulnar artery. It can be associated with the comminuted fracture of the distal radius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar humerus fracture which is mostly associated with the brachial artery injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequent presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal mass

 

The most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor is as an abdominal mass.

 

Abdominal mass is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are characterized by the development of firm, palpable masses in the abdominal wall or other abdominal structures. This is the hallmark sign of these tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal pain: While abdominal pain can be a symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors, it is not the most frequent presentation. These tumors often manifest as painless masses in the abdominal area.

 

Option C. Fever: Fever is generally not a primary symptom of abdominal desmoid tumors. These tumors are primarily associated with the formation of masses rather than systemic symptoms like fever.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse: Rectal prolapse is not a common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An abdominal desmoid tumor is a tumor that arises from fibro-aponeurotic tissue in the musculoaponeurotic structures of the abdominal wall, especially below the level of the umbilicus.

 

Desmoid tumors are frequently seen to be associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP) syndrome.

 

It commonly presents as a slow-growing mass and tends to infiltrate muscle in the immediate area. Eventually, it can undergo a myxomatous change and then shows an increase in size more rapidly.

 

The investigation of choice for desmoid tumor is MRI. Biopsy with immunohistochemistry can help in establishing the diagnosis. The tumors typically stain positive for

 

  • 3-catenin
  • Actin and
  • Vimentin.

 

It stains negative for cytokeratin and S-100.

 

  • Treatment includes wide excision with a margin clearance of 2.5cm to avoid recurrence. It is a completely unencapsulated fibroma and is hard to cut. The defect then requires repair using mesh to prevent hernia in the future.
  • Radiotherapy alone is an acceptable treatment option for patients with unresectable desmoid tumors
  • Prognosis is good, with no metastasis or sarcomatous change. Although they lack metastatic potential, they can be multifocal as well as locally aggressive and invasive, with a high propensity for recurrence.

choices.text: Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration
Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive

questions.text: Difference in trajectory between inspiratory loop and the expiratory loop in the curve is due to: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

 

The above shows the compliance diagram of lung

 

Compliance Diagram of the Lungs

 

It is a diagram relating lung volume changes to changes in transpulmonary pressure. 

 

The characteristics of the compliance diagram are determined

 

The surfactant, secreted by type II pneumocytes, reduces surface tension in alveoli.


During inspiration, alveoli expand, decreasing the surfactant concentration, which leads to increased surface tension, requiring more pressure to keep alveoli open.


During expiration, alveoli deflate, increasing surfactant concentration, thus decreasing surface tension, and requiring less pressure.


This asymmetry in surface tension during inspiration and expiration contributes to the difference in the trajectory (hysteresis) of the curve
 

The tissue elastic forces tending to cause collapse of the air-filled lung represent only about one third of the total lung elasticity, whereas the fluid-air surface tension forces in the alveoli represent about two thirds.

 

Thus, a greater transpulmonary pressure is required to open a previously closed airway due to surface tension at the air-water interface due to surfactant deficit, than to keep an open airway from closing, reflecting abundant surfactant.

 

 

 

Surfactant concentration increases during expiration (smaller alveoli → surfactant molecules closer), lowering surface tension and making expiration easier compared to inspiration. This is the correct cause of hysteresis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration: Incorrect, as this refers to the pressure gradients that drive airflow but does not directly cause the loop shape differences seen in the compliance graph.

 

Option C. Airway resistance can be higher during expiration due to dynamic airway compression, especially in obstructive diseases.

However, the P-V loop is a static curve, plotted during slow, controlled breathing or when airflow has ceased — not during forced maneuvers — so airway resistance has minimal impact on this loop. This might be more relevant to flow-volume loops, not pressure-volume loops

 

Option D. This is true physiologically — inspiration involves active muscle contraction, and expiration is usually passive at rest. But this does not explain the hysteresis in the pressure-volume loop.  The loop reflects lung compliance and surface tension, not the energy used for breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The difference between inspiratory and expiratory pressure-volume loops (hysteresis) is primarily due to dynamic changes in surfactant concentration, which alters surface tension between inspiration and expiration. Understanding this helps explain lung compliance behavior and the role of surfactant in stabilizing alveoli.

questions.text: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

 

  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor.
  • It is also the most common epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland.
  • The most common epithelial tumors, in order of frequency, are as follows:
    1. Benign mixed tumor (BMT), also known as a pleomorphic adenoma (PA)
    2. Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC)
    3. Pleomorphic adenocarcinoma (ACA)
    4. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

 

Note: Most common malignant epithelial tumor of the lacrimal gland: Adenoid cystic carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoid cystic carcinoma: Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant tumor that can occur in various glands in the body, including the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by slow growth and the tendency to invade nearby structures.

 

Option C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is another type of malignant tumor that can affect the lacrimal gland. It is characterized by a combination of mucin-secreting and squamous (epidermoid) cells.

 

Option D. Malignant mixed tumor: Malignant mixed tumor, also known as carcinoma ex pleomorphic adenoma, occurs when a previously benign pleomorphic adenoma transforms into a malignant tumor. It is less common than pleomorphic adenoma but represents a more aggressive form of lacrimal gland tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is usually benign and arises from the glandular tissue. It can sometimes have a mixture of cell types, hence the name "pleomorphic."

choices.text: Hemodynamically unstable patient should not be sent for CT scan
All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only
X-ray of the pelvis is done in primary survey
X-rays in primary survey may also be done in pregnant women

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding imaging in the primary survey of a trauma patient except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) All patients should have chest X-ray PA view only

 

Chest X-ray and X-ray pelvis are taken in AP view in the adjuncts to the primary survey of a trauma patient.

 

This statement is false. Chest X-rays are often a standard part of the primary survey to assess for chest injuries and potential life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax or hemothorax, however AP view is commonly used in the primary survey. PA view requires patient to be standing, which is usually not possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemodynamically unstable patients should not be sent for CT scans: This statement is true. Hemodynamically unstable patients are in a critical condition, and their immediate management should prioritize stabilizing their condition.

 

Option C. X-ray of the pelvis is done in the primary survey: This statement is true. Pelvic X-rays may be performed if pelvic injury is suspected based on clinical assessment, however they are not universally conducted in all trauma patients during the primary survey, hence considered as “adjuncts”.

 

Option D. X-rays in the primary survey may be done in pregnant women: This statement is generally true. Pregnant trauma patients should undergo imaging as needed during the primary survey to assess for injuries. However, the choice of imaging modalities and the use of shielding techniques should consider the safety of the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

 

  • Primary survey and simultaneous resuscitation - in order to identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey - proceeding to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care - developing a definitive management plan

 

ABCDE of trauma care:

 

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control hemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

 

Adjuncts to the primary survey are-

 

  • Blood - CBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheterization
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit. When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

 

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only in a patient stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: Ceftriaxone 180 mg is required for a patient. You're using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml. Ceftriaxone 500 mg/5ml is contained in the vial. How many divisions will you fill in the 2 mL syringe to give 180 mg ceftriaxone? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 18

 

In a vial of Ceftriaxone, it is given than 500mg is there in 5ml.

 

Therefore 180 mg will be present in 1.8 ml.

 

In the 2ml syringe there are 10 divisions per ml.

 

Thus, to take 1.8ml, we need to fill 10*1.8 = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:


To administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone using a 2 mL syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

questions.text: What would be a useful diagnostic tool to consider for a patient who presented with symptoms of hair loss, itching of the scalp, and a mild discharge? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) KOH mount

 

The above image shows tinea capitis, which presents with a well-demarcated scaly patch in which hair shafts are broken off just above the skin resulting in alopecia / hair loss. KOH mount is useful for the depicted condition.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

  • Ectothrix - Spores & fungus present outside the hair shaft.
  • Endothrix - Spores & fungi present inside the hair shaft.

 

 

Kerion:

 

  • Presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy.
  • It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis.
  • The most common causative organisms of kerion are Zoophilic dermatophytes, T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

 

Fig: Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling

 

  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum is Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton associated Tinea capitis specifically is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tzanck smear:

 

  • Use: It is a microscopic examination used to identify cells from blistering skin conditions. It's especially useful in detecting herpes simplex, herpes zoster, and pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Why it's not the answer: The presented symptoms are not typical of blistering skin conditions or herpetic infections, which is where a Tzanck smear would be most useful.

 

Option B. Gram stain:

 

  • Use: This is a staining technique used to classify bacterial species into two groups (Gram-positive and Gram-negative) based on the chemical and physical properties of their cell walls.
  • Why it's not the answer: While a bacterial infection could lead to scalp discharge, the combination of hair loss and itching specifically suggests a fungal etiology over a bacterial one.

 

Option C. Slit skin smear:

 

  • Use: This test is primarily used for diagnosing leprosy by detecting Mycobacterium leprae in skin lesions.
  • Why it's not the answer: The symptoms described are not indicative of leprosy, which generally presents as skin patches with sensory loss or nerve enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.39

questions.text: In fetal alcohol syndrome, which of the following is not seen? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrocephaly

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is associated with various structural, behavioral, and developmental anomalies due to prenatal alcohol exposure. One of the key features of FAS is microcephaly, not macrocephaly. High levels of alcohol ingestion during pregnancy can severely impact embryonic and fetal development.

 

The presence of at least one of the following characteristics is indicative of fetal alcohol syndrome:

 

  • Growth restriction: Can occur before and/or after birth.
  • Facial anomalies: These include small palpebral fissures, indistinct or absent philtrum, epicanthic folds, flattened nasal bridge, short length of nose, thin upper lip, low-set and unparallel ears, and retarded midfacial development.
  • CNS dysfunction: Includes microcephaly, mental retardation, and abnormal neurobehavioral development such as attention deficit with hyperactivity.

 

Other features that may be seen in FAS include:

 

  • Incomplete holoprosencephaly: A condition where the forebrain does not completely divide into two hemispheres.
  • Agenesis of the corpus callosum and cerebellar vermis: Developmental anomalies where these brain structures are partially or completely absent.
  • Cardiac anomalies: Such as ventricular septal defect (VSD), atrial septal defect (ASD), and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Macrocephaly is not seen in fetal alcohol syndrome; instead, microcephaly is characteristic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thinning of corpus callosum: This is a characteristic finding in fetal alcohol syndrome due to developmental anomalies.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: This is commonly seen in fetal alcohol syndrome and is one of the diagnostic features.

 

Option C. Holoprosencephaly: Incomplete holoprosencephaly can be seen in fetal alcohol syndrome as a result of severe midline developmental anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal alcohol syndrome is associated with microcephaly, not macrocephaly.

 

Ref: Page no 397, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: When you add calcium and thromboplastin to platelet poor plasma which pathway is assessed? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Extrinsic

 

Thromboplastin (Factor III) binds with Factor VII. When calcium is added, it activates extrinsic pathway.

 

 

Activated Prothrombin Time (aPTT) measures the integrity of the intrinsic system (Factors XII, XI, VIII, IX) and common clotting pathways. Calcium and activating substances (kaolin) are added to the plasma-

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Intrinsic: The intrinsic pathway is assessed using the Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time (aPTT) test, where calcium and an activating substance like kaolin (not thromboplastin) are added to the plasma to measure the activity of Factors XII, XI, IX, and VIII.

 

Option C. Fibrinolysis: Fibrinolysis is the process of breaking down fibrin clots, which is not directly assessed by adding thromboplastin and calcium. It is evaluated by other means, such as measuring fibrin degradation products (FDPs) or D-dimer levels.

 

Option D. Common: While the extrinsic pathway feeds into the common pathway (Factors X, V, II, and I), the specific test described (PT) is primarily assessing the extrinsic pathway, though it also gives some information about the common pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adding calcium and thromboplastin to platelet-poor plasma assesses the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, which is the basis for the Prothrombin Time (PT) test.

questions.text: Which parameter is best used to monitor the adequacy of and guide fluid resuscitation in a patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urine Output

 

Urine output is the best measure of organ perfusion and the best monitor for adequacy of fluid resuscitation.

 

Adequate end-organ perfusion is best indicated by urine output of >0.5 to 1 mL/kg/h. However, it does not give minute-to-minute values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CVP (central venous pressure): CVP is a poor reflector of preload. Central venous pressure (CVP) is the mean pressure in the superior vena cava, indicating right ventricular end-diastolic pressure or preload. Normal CVP ranges from 2 to 7 mm Hg (3 to 9 cm H20). A sick or injured patient with a CVP <3 mm Hg is presumed to be volume depleted and maybe given fluids with relative safety. However, CVP is unreliable for assessment of volume status or left ventricular function.

 

Option C. Blood pressure: Blood pressure is an important vital sign, but it alone may not provide a complete picture of a patient's fluid status. Hypotension (low blood pressure) can be a late sign of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and normotension (normal blood pressure) does not guarantee adequate tissue perfusion. The level of consciousness is an important marker for cerebral perfusion.

 

Option D. Oxygen saturation: Oxygen saturation (SpO2) measures the amount of oxygen in the blood, and while it is essential for assessing respiratory status, it is not a direct indicator of fluid balance or adequacy of fluid resuscitation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urine output is a valuable and non-invasive parameter for assessing fluid resuscitation. Adequate urine output indicates that the patient's kidneys are functioning well and that they are likely receiving an appropriate amount of fluids. It is a practical and real-time measure of the patient's response to fluid therapy.

choices.text: Cell wall synthesis inhibition
Cell membrane inhibition
Peptide synthesis inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cell wall synthesis inhibition

 

Vancomycin binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent used against gram positive agent like MRSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like polymyxins target the cell membrane.

 

Option C. Peptide synthesis inhibition: This option is incorrect. Peptide synthesis inhibition is typically the mechanism of action for drugs like tetracyclines and macrolides that interfere with ribosomal function.

 

Option D. 50S ribosome inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like macrolides (e.g., erythromycin), chloramphenicol, and clindamycin inhibit the 50S ribosomal subunit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, preventing peptidoglycan elongation and cross-linking, leading to cell lysis and death. It is especially effective against gram-positive bacteria like MRSA.

choices.text: Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

questions.text: A 25-year-old female came with complaints of 4 months amenorrhea. Her FSH and LH were elevated above the normal value, thyroid function tests were normal. Which is the next step in management? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give progesterone and stop after 10 days for withdrawal bleeding

 

Explanation

 

  • Since LH and FSH are elevated above the normal value, the possibility of a pregnancy can be ruled out as FSH and LH levels fall to very low levels in pregnancy
  • The first step in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea after ruling out pregnancy is to do a progesterone challenge test i.e. to see if she bleeds after a challenge of progesterone.
  • If she bleeds, the diagnosis is anovulation like in PCOS

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estimate serum estradiol values: Serum estradiol level measurement has no role in evaluation of secondary amenorrhoea

 

Option D. Do a urine pregnancy test: FSH levels in pregnancy are very very low so pregnancy is unlikely; otherwise the most common cause of secondary amenorrhoea is pregnancy

 

Option C. Check USG for Polycystic ovaries: This is done if the patient bleeds following progesterone withdrawal as it determines the cause of anovular cycles

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary amenorrhea is defined as a period of amenorrhoea of 6 months
  • Pregnancy needs to be ruled out
  • The most common cause of secondary amenorrhea after ruling out pregnancy is anovulation (PCOS) which can be determined by the progesterone withdrawal test

 

Ref: Page no 457, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Relapse is seen in? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Plasmodium viva and ovale

 

Malaria relapse:

 

  • In case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which multiply inside hepatic cells to form schizonts and others persist and remain dormant as hypnozoites.
  • True relapse is caused due to hypnozoites (resting forms). Some get activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In case of Plasmodium falciparum and malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plasmodium vivax and falciparum: While P. vivax can cause relapse, P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites and therefore does not cause relapse.

 

Option B. Plasmodium ovale and falciparum: P. ovale can cause relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. falciparum does not form hypnozoites.

 

Option D. Plasmodium vivax and malariae: P. vivax causes relapse due to hypnozoites, but P. malariae does not form hypnozoites and does not cause relapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Relapse in malaria is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale due to the presence of hypnozoites, the dormant liver stages that can reactivate and cause renewed infection.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male came with complaints of ascending weakness in both lower limb and upper body. There was no history of trauma. Which of the following is the next investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum Potassium

 

Disturbance in serum potassium levels (hypokalemia or hyperkalemia) present with ascending muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serum Magnesium: Incorrect for this scenario as disturbances in magnesium typically cause tetany (muscle spasms) when low and generalized weakness when high, but are less directly linked to the type of ascending muscle weakness described.

 

Option C. Serum Sodium: Incorrect because changes in serum sodium levels generally affect neurological function but do not typically cause muscular weakness.

 

Option D. Serum Calcium: Incorrect as calcium imbalances would more likely cause tetany (from hypocalcemia) or symptoms like fatigue, depression, and cardiac arrhythmias (from hypercalcemia), rather than ascending muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The disturbances in serum potassium levels can manifest as muscle weakness, making it a vital test in cases of unexplained, ascending muscle weakness without trauma.

questions.text: Identify the organism given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Balantidium coli

 

The given image is the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli.

 

Balantidium coli occurs in two stages

 

  • Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over the entire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end is broad. At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, there is a small anal pore (cytopyge).
  • Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.

 

Living trophozoites/cysts are yellowish or greenish in color on wet mount.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba dispar: Entamoeba dispar is morphologically identical to Entamoeba histolytica but non-pathogenic. It does not have the characteristic cilia and shape seen in Balantidium coli.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium species are small protozoans that cause cryptosporidiosis. They appear as small, round oocysts and do not have cilia.

 

Option D. Giardia: Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan that causes giardiasis. Its trophozoites have a distinctive pear shape with flagella and two nuclei that resemble "eyes."

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balantidium coli is characterized by its oval shape, presence of cilia, and distinct anterior and posterior ends in the trophozoite form. The trophozoite stage contains two nuclei and is motile, while the cyst stage is smaller and round, aiding in transmission and infection.

choices.text: In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors
Upper third molar is most commonly absent in Mongolians
Prominent lingual ridge and labial ridge in mongols

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding teeth and ethnicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. In Africanoids the cusps of molars are wide and deep with shovel shaped cusps in incisors

 

The cusps of molars are wide and deep and cusps of incisors are shovel-shaped is typically seen in Mongoloid races not in Africanoids hence the statement is incorrect. In Africanoids there is presence of large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

 

Option B), Option C), Option D): these statements are correct as explained in the core concept above. The question is asking for the wrong statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key differences between race

questions.text: Feed forward control system is employed during the regulation of? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Temperature

 

Feed forward control system is employed during regulation of temperature.

 

This is the control system of our body that anticipates and makes corrective changes without any stimulus. Such a system is called Feed forward or Anticipatory or Adaptive Control.

 

For instance, some movements of the body occur so rapidly that there is not enough time for nerve signals to travel from the peripheral parts of the body all the way to the brain and then back to the periphery again to control the movement. Therefore, the brain uses a principle called feed-forward control to cause required muscle contractions wherein sensory nerve signals from the moving parts inform the brain whether the movement is performed correctly. If not, the brain corrects the feed-forward signals that it sends to the muscles the next time the movement is required. Then, if still further correction is needed, this will be done again for subsequent movements. This is called adaptive control.

 

Examples include:

 

  • Thermoregulation by hypothalamus BEFORE the changes in environmental temperature changes the body's core body temperature
  • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion- Increase in gastric acid secretion on thinking about food
  • Thinking about exercise leading to increase heart rate & respiratory rate
  • Motor coordination by cerebellum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood volume: Incorrect. The regulation of blood volume is primarily a feedback mechanism based on circulating blood volume and blood pressure.

 

Option B. pH: Incorrect. pH regulation in the body involves feedback mechanisms that monitor and adjust to changes in hydrogen ion concentration.

 

Option D. Blood pressure: Incorrect. While there are anticipatory aspects in blood pressure regulation during activities like exercise, it's primarily governed by feedback mechanisms responding to changes in blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The feed forward control system is a preemptive regulatory mechanism employed notably in temperature regulation, allowing the body to anticipate environmental changes and adjust physiological responses in advance to maintain homeostasis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, he had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension along with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoas abscess

 

The given clinical finding of pain on hip extension is “psoas sign” which is seen in inflammation of psoas like abscess or appendicitis. However, presence of mass in right lumbar makes psoas abscess more likely.

 

Psoas abscess is an infection that occurs in the psoas muscle, which is located in the lower back and can extend into the right lower quadrant. It can cause lower back pain, hip pain on passive extension, and the presence of a mass in the lumbar region, making it a likely diagnosis based on the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is an infection of the kidneys and typically presents with symptoms such as fever, flank pain, and urinary symptoms. While it can cause lower back pain, it doesn't typically result in a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option C. Appendicitis: Appendicitis usually presents with pain in the right lower quadrant, but it doesn't typically involve lower back pain or the presence of a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Option D. Torsion of right undescended testis: Testicular torsion is a condition involving the twisting of the spermatic cord, which leads to severe testicular pain and swelling. It does not typically cause lower back pain or a palpable mass in the lumbar region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

History of abdominal pain and mass in the right lumbar region, with pain on passive extension of the right hip (psoas sign), points towards the diagnosis of psoas abscess.

 

The history of lower back pain needs to be evaluated with the possibility of tubercular origin to be kept in mind in this patient.

 

Treatment is usually by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

choices.text: Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance
90% of patients will be benefitted by giving the drug
90% of test results could have occurred by chance

questions.text: An investigative study was conducted in Mumbai wherein a promising new antihypertensive medication was evaluated for its potential efficacy. Initial clinical trials with a diverse cohort of patients with chronic hypertension revealed promising results in managing elevated blood pressure levels. The efficacy of the drug was measured meticulously, and upon analyzing the data, a p-value of < 0.10 was documented. Given this statistical information and considering the nuances of research interpretation, which of the following statements best elucidates the implications of this p-value in terms of the drug's effect? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Not more than 10% of the people benefitted by the drug could be due to chance

 

  • A P-value of less than 0.10 suggests that the likelihood of the drug's benefits occurring due to chance is no higher than 10%.

 

 INTERPRETATION:

 

  • Out of 100 repeated tests, a statistically insignificant difference will occur only 10 times, while a statistically significant difference will emerge 90 times.
  • There is a 10% probability of incorrectly concluding that a drug is beneficial when it is not, which can happen in statistical studies when deciding whether to accept or reject a null hypothesis.
  • The P value is compared to a predetermined threshold value 'a'; if the P value is less than 'a', the test is considered statistically significant, and the null hypothesis is rejected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The p-value is a statistical parameter used to evaluate whether the results of an experiment are statistically significant.
  • In this case, a p-value of < 0.10 suggests there is up to a 10% chance that the observed benefits from the antihypertensive drug could be due to random variation rather than a true effect of the drug.

questions.text: An autopsy was performed to find the cause of death of a person brought dead to the casualty. It showed abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage and contused tissues in the neck. The cause of death is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Throttling

 

The description of the autopsy findings, including abrasions on the neck, fracture of the thyroid cartilage, and contused tissues in the neck, typically indicates death resulting from external pressure on the neck. Throttling is the act of applying pressure to the neck, often by external force or someone’s hands, which can lead to these specific injuries.

 

Manual strangulation, also known as throttling, is a type of asphyxial death where the perpetrator uses his hand to encircle and compress the front and side of the neck.

 

Autopsy finding

 

External Findings:

 

  • Neck abrasions and bruises, often near the laryngeal prominence and jawline.
  • Signs of asphyxia: cyanosis, facial swelling, Tardieu’s spot, and bleeding from the nose and ears.
  • Finger bruises, usually 1.5–2 cm in size.
  • Extent depends on factors like pressure, assailant’s nails, and victim’s resistance.
  • Thumb marks are more prominent, and multiple abrasions may result from victim’s struggle.

 

Internal Findings:

 

  • Muscle tears.
  • Tongue damage.
  • Inward hyoid bone fracture.
  • Thyroid cartilage fracture.
  • Carotid sheath laceration and carotid artery damage.

 

The given autopsy images are suggestive of throttling as bruises and abrasions on the neck is seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hanging: In the case of hanging, there will be a ligature mark, which is not mentioned in the question.

 

Option C. Strangulation: Strangulation is a very generalized term used to describe deaths due to violent asphyxia. Eg- ligature strangulation, throttling etc. Since Throttling is already given in option B we can consider option C strangulation as ligature strangulation. It cannot be the answer as ligature mark is not seen.

 

Option D. Mugging: In mugging cases, the assailant typically compresses or squeezes the victim’s neck by using the crook of their elbow or knee. While a victim killed by this method may exhibit signs of asphyxia, a neck examination may not reveal any signs of violence because the compression is applied using the soft muscles of the arm or leg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling involves manual strangulation by applying pressure to the neck, causing abrasions, contusions, and fractures in the neck structures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is brought into the emergency department with acute myocardial infarction and has received fibrinolytic therapy. The patient begins to experience excessive bleeding post-therapy. Which of the following is the best antidote to reverse the effects of fibrinolytic therapy? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epsilon-aminocaproic acid

 

Epsilon-aminocaproic acid (EACA) is a potent inhibitor of fibrinolysis and is used to counteract the effects of fibrinolytic agents such as streptokinase or tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). It works by inhibiting plasminogen activation, preventing the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, thereby halting the breakdown of fibrin clots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine: This drug is primarily used to reverse the effects of heparin, not fibrinolytic agents.

 

Option B. Streptokinase: Streptokinase is a fibrinolytic agent and is used to dissolve clots. It would exacerbate bleeding, not treat it.

 

Option C. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent clot formation. It is unrelated to fibrinolytic therapy and does not serve as an antidote for bleeding complications from fibrinolytic drugs.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Epsilon-aminocaproic acid is the antidote used to reverse bleeding complications caused by fibrinolytic agents like streptokinase.

choices.text: 1/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
2/3 of the total protein requirement + ½ of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement
½ of the total protein requirement + 2/3 of total energy requirement

questions.text: Dr. Anil, working as a nutritional consultant with the government of India, is reviewing the Mid-Day Meal (MDM) scheme, an initiative to enhance the nutritional intake among school-going children. He emphasizes that the nutritional component of the meals should not just be about filling stomachs but ensuring that children get adequate protein and energy to support their growth and learning. Given the constraints and the need to ensure minimal nutritional adequacy, what should the minimum supplementation be in the Mid-Day Meal to support the children's needs? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) ½ of the total protein requirement + 1/3 of total energy requirement

 

  • The meal should supplement 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement.
  • Mid-day meal programme (MDMP): Also known as ‘School Lunch Programme’, it has been in operation since 1961.
  • The major objective of MDMP: To attract more children for admission to schools and retain them so that literacy improvement of children could be brought about.
  • The meal is a supplement and not a substitute to the home diet
  • The meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • MDMP is being operationalised under the Ministry of Human Resource & Development 
  • National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad is of the view that minimum number of feeding days in year be 250 to have the desired impact on children

 

Mid-day meal scheme (MDMS) (National Programme of Nutritional Support to Primary Education):

 

  • Launched in 1995
  • Main objective: Universalisation of primary education by increasing enrolment, retention and attendance and simultaneously impacting on nutrition of students in primary classes
  • The mid-day meal should supply 1/3 of the total energy requirement and 1/2 of the total protein requirement
  • A model menu for mid-day school meal

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Principles for formulating mid-day meals:

 

  • Meal should be a supplement only not a substitute for home diet
  • Meal should provide 1/3 calories and 1/2 proteins
  • Meal cost should be low
  • Complicated cooking process must not be involved
  • Use locally available foods
  • Keep changing menu frequently

 

Mid-Day Meal Scheme is now renamed as PM POSHAN or Pradhan Mantri Poshan Shakti Nirman.

questions.text: A young woman, aged 25, presented with hearing impairment that emerged shortly after her initial pregnancy. Provided below is her audiometry findings. What could be the potential diagnosis for this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

 

Hearing loss that developed shortly after the first pregnancy along with Carhart's notch seen in the audiogram is suggestive of otosclerosis.

 

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

 

  • Blue color indicates the left ear.
  • x indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal. So it indicates conductive deafness.
  • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. A characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz called Carhart’s notch is seen.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, left-sided otosclerosis is the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

 

Option B: Meniere's disease shows a low-frequency loss in the SNHL curve.

 

 

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss - PTA shows a characteristic Acoustic dip at 4000 Hz (Boiler’s Notch).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presented with a painless breast lump measuring 6.2 X 4.5 cm in the left upper outer quadrant and no axillary nodes. Core cut biopsy showed ductal carcinoma in situ. She underwent tumor resection with adequate margins and postoperative H&E showed DCIS with intermediate-grade necrosis and with 6-mm clearance on margins. What would be the next step in treatment? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

According to Silverstein Van Nuys prognostic index which is used for DCIS, the total score is 9, and the patient would require adjuvant radiotherapy.

 

Age: 43 years (score 2), size: 62mm (score 3), clearance margin: 6mm (score 2) with intermediate-grade necrosis (score 2).

 

The Silverstein Van Nuys Prognostic Index (VNPI) is a prognostic tool used in the management of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) of the breast. DCIS is a non-invasive form of breast cancer, and the VNPI helps guide treatment decisions by assessing the risk of local recurrence.

 

The VNPI combines three significant predictors of local recurrence:

 

  1. Tumor size: The size of the DCIS lesion.
  2. Margin width: The width of clear tissue margins around the tumor after surgical resection.
  3. Pathologic classification: The histopathological characteristics of the DCIS, including features like grade and necrosis.

 

Scores on the VNPI typically range from 1 (best prognosis) to 3 (worst prognosis), with higher scores indicating a higher risk of local recurrence

 

The VNPI assists oncologists and surgeons in determining the appropriate treatment approach for patients with DCIS. For example, patients with a lower VNPI score may be candidates for less aggressive treatment, while those with a higher score may require more intensive therapies such as radiation therapy or mastectomy.

 

Score <7: No further treatment

 

Score 7-9: Adjuvant radiotherapy

 

Score >9: Simple mastectomy

questions.text: A 75-year-old male after a fall in bathroom had hip fracture as seen in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shortened and externally rotated

 

HIP FRACTURE

 

  • The given image in the question shows a displaced femoral neck fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as fall from a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density.
  • 70% of all hip fractures occur in women. 
  • Symptoms include pain in the groin or pain referred along the medial side of the thigh and knee in an impacted fracture.
  • In a displaced fracture, there will be pain in the entire hip. 
  • In an impacted fracture, there is no obvious clinical deformity on examination. There is mild discomfort in the active/passive hip range of motion, and pain with percussion over the greater trochanter.
  • In displaced fractures, the leg appears in external rotation and abduction deformity with shortening of the limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows a displaced femoral neck fracture in the elderly patient.
  • Following the fracture, the limb appears shortened with external rotation and abduction deformity at the hip.

questions.text: What is the window period for thrombolysis in case of stroke? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 41/2 hours

 

The window period for the administration of intravenous recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) in the case of an acute ischemic stroke is 4½ hours from the onset of symptoms. This time frame is critical as rtPA is most effective when administered early, aiming to dissolve the blood clot and restore blood flow to the affected part of the brain, thus minimizing or reversing the damage caused by the stroke.

 

Indications:

 

  • After Clinical diagnosis of stroke established
  • If onset of symptoms to time of drug administration </= 4.5 hours
  • If age >/= 18 years
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory
  • Consent given by patient or surrogate

 

Contraindications:

 

  • Coma/stupor/ recent MI.
  • Major surgery in last 14 days/ GI bleeding in last 21 days/ minor stroke symptoms.
  • Rapidly improving symptoms.
  • Sustained BP > 185/110 mmHg despite treatment.
  • Platelets < 100,000; HCT < 25%; glucose < 50 or > 400 mg/dL.
  • Use of heparin within 48hrs and prolonged PTT or elevated INR.
  • Prior stroke or head injury within 3 months; prior intracranial hemorrhage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The therapeutic window for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke using rtPA is up to 4½ hours from symptom onset, and strict criteria must be met to ensure the safety and efficacy of treatment. This timeframe is crucial for maximizing the potential benefits of the treatment while minimizing risks.

questions.text: Urine LAM is used for the diagnosis of? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M. tuberculosis

 

  • Urine lipoarabinomannan (LAM) assay is used for the diagnosis of tuberculosis.
  • Lipoarabinomannan (LAM) antigen is a lipopolysaccharide present in mycobacterial cell wall.
  • It is released from metabolically active cells or degenerating cells of patients having tuberculosis.
  • Urine LAM testing is especially useful in diagnosing TB in patients with HIV and low CD 4 counts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M. leprae: Mycobacterium leprae causes leprosy, and its diagnosis is typically made through skin biopsy and slit-skin smear. Urine LAM is not used for diagnosing leprosy.

 

Option C. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma species cause respiratory and urogenital infections. They lack a cell wall and, therefore, LAM is not relevant to their diagnosis.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes is a bacterial pathogen causing listeriosis, diagnosed typically through blood culture or cerebrospinal fluid analysis. Urine LAM is not applicable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Urine LAM assay is a diagnostic tool for tuberculosis, particularly useful for patients with HIV and low CD4 counts due to the detection of the LAM antigen from mycobacterial cell walls in urine.

choices.text: PGP stands for permeability glycoprotein
Also known as CD243
Also known as ABCB1
Also known as MDR2

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about P-glycoprotein? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Also known as MDR2

 

Also known as MDR2 is not true about P-glycoprotein. P-glycoprotein is also known as permeability glycoprotein (PGP), CD243, and ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1). MDR2, on the other hand, is a different protein called multidrug resistance protein 2, which is also involved in drug transport.

 

Other Options:

 

P-glycoprotein (PGP) is a well-known membrane protein that functions as a drug transporter. It is involved in the efflux of drugs and other substances from cells, contributing to multidrug resistance.

 

Option A. PGP stands for permeability glycoprotein: This is true. P-glycoprotein is indeed referred to as permeability glycoprotein.

 

Option B. Also known as CD243: This is true. P-glycoprotein is identified as CD243 in the cluster of differentiation nomenclature.

 

Option C. Also known as ABCB1: This is true. P-glycoprotein is also known as ATP-binding cassette sub-family B member 1 (ABCB1).

 

Educational Objective:

 

P-glycoprotein is known as permeability glycoprotein (PGP), CD243, and ABCB1, but it is not referred to as MDR2. MDR2 is a separate protein involved in drug transport.

choices.text: Amphotericin B

questions.text: For which of the following drugs, absorption is increased after a fatty meal? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Griseofulvin

 

Griseofulvin is an antifungal drug that acts by blocking the microtubules. It is given orally, preferably with a fatty meal, which has been found to increase its absorption. This enhancement in absorption is due to the lipophilic nature of griseofulvin, which allows it to dissolve better in the presence of dietary fats, facilitating its uptake in the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication primarily administered intravenously due to poor oral absorption. Its absorption is not significantly affected by meals.

 

Option C. Ampicillin: Ampicillin is an antibiotic that is generally well absorbed on an empty stomach. Food can actually reduce the absorption of ampicillin.

 

Option D. Aspirin: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory and antipyretic drug. Its absorption is not significantly increased by fatty meals, although taking it with food can help minimize gastrointestinal side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs whose absorption increase with meals

Griseofulvin

Statins

Halofantrine

Erlotinib

choices.text: No advice as most of drug are not present in breast milk
Give longer half-life drugs
Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious
To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

questions.text: What advice do you give to a mother who is using medications during lactation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. To feed just before the next dose, when the plasma concentration of the drug would be the least

 

When administering medications to a lactating mother, the timing of breast feeding is very important. It is advised to feed the baby just before the intake of the drug, as at that time the plasma concentration of the drug would be least. Then after feeding the drug is taken.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No advice as most of the drug are not present in breast milk: This is incorrect. Many drugs can pass into breast milk to varying degrees. Therefore, careful consideration and advice are needed to minimize infant exposure.

 

Option B. Give longer half-life drugs: This is not a general recommendation. Drugs with longer half-lives stay in the body longer and can potentially accumulate in the breast milk, increasing exposure to the infant.

 

Option C. Tell the mother to feed when it is least efficacious: This advice is not clear or practical. The key is to time breastfeeding relative to the dosing schedule to minimize drug transfer to the breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best advice for a lactating mother using medications is to breastfeed just before taking her next dose of medication. This practice ensures that the drug's plasma concentration is at its lowest during breastfeeding, thereby reducing the amount of drug that passes into the breast milk and minimizing exposure to the infant.

choices.text: Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol
Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthine
Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthine on adenosine receptor
Corticosteroids increase mucous secretion.

questions.text: Acute exacerbation of asthma was comprehended, salbutamol was prescribed, however, no improvement was noticed. Intravenous corticosteroids and aminophylline were given and the condition improved. What is the probable mechanism by which the corticosteroids would have improved the condition? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Corticosteroids increase bronchial responsiveness to salbutamol

 

Corticosteroids are not bronchodilators by itself, but they are used in acute exacerbation of asthma because they decrease the secretion of mucous, decrease the inflammatory mediators and also increase the responsiveness of the β receptors to the action of the β2 agonists. Therefore, it can be said that Corticosteroids improved the condition by increasing the airway responsiveness to salbutamol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corticosteroids cause direct bronchodilatation when used with xanthine: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids do not cause direct bronchodilation. Their primary role is to reduce inflammation and enhance the effects of bronchodilators.

 

Option C. Corticosteroids indirectly increase the effect of xanthine on adenosine receptor: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids do not have a direct or indirect effect on the xanthine (aminophylline) action on adenosine receptors.

 

Option D. Corticosteroids increase mucous secretion: This is incorrect. Corticosteroids actually decrease mucus secretion, which helps to clear the airways and improve airflow during an asthma exacerbation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corticosteroids improve the condition of patients with acute asthma exacerbation by increasing the bronchial responsiveness to β2 agonists like salbutamol, reducing inflammation, and decreasing mucus secretion.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is an antagonist at ‘µ’ and a complete agonist at ‘k’ receptors? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pentazocine

 

Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist agent, which acts as a full agonist at the Kappa receptors but as a partial agonist or antagonist at the mu receptors. It is used as an analgesic, but contraindicated in myocardial infarction due to its potential to increase heart rate and blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Buprenorphine: Buprenorphine is a partial agonist at mu (μ) receptors and an antagonist at kappa (κ) receptors. It is used for pain management and in the treatment of opioid dependence.

 

Option C. Tramadol: Tramadol is a weak agonist at mu (μ) receptors and also inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin. It does not have significant kappa (κ) receptor activity.

 

Option D. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is a potent full agonist at mu (μ) receptors with no significant activity at kappa (κ) receptors. It is used for severe pain management, particularly in surgical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pentazocine is an opioid that acts as an antagonist at mu (μ) receptors and a full agonist at kappa (κ) receptors. This unique profile allows it to serve as an analgesic with a potentially lower risk of certain side effects, although it is contraindicated in myocardial infarction.

choices.text: Class I
Class II
Class III

questions.text: Dofetilide belongs to which class of anti-arrhythmic drugs? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Class III

 

Dofetilide is a class III anti arrhythmic drug that works by blocking K+ channels. The other class III anti arrhythmic include Amiodarone, Ibutilide, Sotalol and bretylium.

 

The side effect is QT prolongation/Torsades de pointes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: These are sodium channel blockers.

 

Option B. Class II: These are beta-blockers.

 

Option D. Class IV: These are calcium channel blockers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class III drugs include:

B: Bretylium

I: Ibutilide

N

D: Dofetilide

A: Amiodarone

S: Sotalol

questions.text: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. β1 agonist and β2 agonist

 

The drug's likely mechanism of action is β1 and β2 agonism.

 

Due to its action on β1 receptors, there is an increase in the HR of the patient and also of the SBP (Increase in HR leads to an increase in the CO upto a certain extent). The agonistic action on the β2 receptors causes vasodilation and leads to a fall in the DBP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α1 agonist and β1 agonist: α1 agonists typically cause vasoconstriction, which would increase both SBP and DBP. This does not align with the observed decrease in DBP.

 

Option B. M2 agonist and M3 agonist: M2 and M3 receptor agonism would likely lead to bradycardia and increased gastrointestinal motility, respectively. They do not explain the observed increase in HR and SBP, nor the decrease in DBP.

 

Option C. α1 antagonist and β2 agonist: While α1 antagonism could contribute to a decrease in DBP through vasodilation, it would not typically cause an increase in SBP and HR, which are more specifically associated with β1 agonism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of increased systolic blood pressure, decreased diastolic blood pressure, and increased heart rate suggests that drug 'X' acts as a β1 and β2 agonist, leading to increased cardiac output and vasodilation.

questions.text: The drug that decreases the size of prostate is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Finasteride

 

Finasteride: It inhibits the conversion of testosterone into its active form, DHT (dihydrotestosterone), by acting as a competitive inhibitor of the 5-reductase enzyme. It has a long-term effect of reducing prostatic epithelial cell proliferation, which reduces the size of the prostate and improves urine flow.

 

Tamsulosin is a Selective α1A Antagonist which dilates prostatic urethra and hence produces immediate symptom relief in BPH. It has no effect on reducing size of the prostate.

 

Flutamide is a Androgen Receptor antagonist with no hormonal activity. It is used for the treatment of metastatic prostatic cancer in conjunction with GnRH agonists.
