Other Options:

 

Option A. Tamsulosin: Tamsulosin is a selective alpha-1A adrenergic receptor antagonist. It works by relaxing the muscles in the prostate and bladder neck, making it easier to urinate. While it provides symptomatic relief for BPH, it does not reduce the size of the prostate.

 

Option B. Sildenafil: Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor used primarily for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. It has no effect on prostate size.

 

Option D. Flutamide: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist that is used in the treatment of metastatic prostate cancer. It does not reduce the size of the prostate but works by blocking the effects of androgens (male hormones).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Finasteride decreases the size of the prostate by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), thereby reducing prostatic cell proliferation and improving urinary symptoms in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

choices.text: Herbal medication with no effect known
Sham surgery
Cognitive behavioral therapy

questions.text: Which one of the following is a placebo? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sham surgery

 

Sham surgery (placebo surgery) is a fictitious surgical intervention when the actual step that is of therapeutic benefit is omitted. For example, opening the abdomen and then again suturing it without any sort of intervention done on the viscera.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herbal medication with no effect known: While an herbal medication with no known effect might be considered a placebo in certain contexts, it is not specifically designed as a placebo. It could contain active ingredients with unknown effects.

 

Option B. Physiotherapy: Physiotherapy is an established therapeutic practice with known benefits for various conditions. It is not a placebo.

 

Option D. Cognitive behavioral therapy: Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a well-established psychological treatment for a variety of mental health conditions. It is not a placebo, as it involves specific therapeutic techniques aimed at changing maladaptive thinking and behavior patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sham surgery is a type of placebo where the therapeutic intervention is omitted, used primarily in clinical trials to control for the placebo effect and test the efficacy of surgical procedures.

choices.text: Necrotizing TB granuloma
Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia
Severe fungal pneumonia

questions.text: A 35-year-old depressed man came with complaints of sudden onset breathlessness, with desaturation. Chest x-ray showed bilateral diffuse infiltrates with predominant involvement of right middle and lower lobes. The patient could not be revived despite treatment. On autopsy, the lungs, appeared grossly normal. The histopathology image of the lung is as shown below. Which among the following is the appropriate cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia

 

The above image shows a foreign body granuloma. Foreign bodies are surrounded by macrophages and lymphocytes. This change results from aspiration of stomach contents or food particles in this case probably vegetative matter.

 

Aspiration pneumonia occurs in markedly debilitated patients or those who aspirate gastric contents either while unconscious (e.g., after a stroke) or during repeated vomiting. These patients have abnormal gag and swallowing reflexes that predispose to aspiration. The resultant pneumonia is partly chemical because of the extremely irritating effects of the gastric acid, and partly bacterial (from the oral flora). Typically, more than one organism is recovered on culture, aerobes being more common than anaerobes. This type of pneumonia is often necrotizing, pursues a fulminant clinical course, and is a frequent cause of death.

 

The most commonly affected lobes in Necrotizing pneumonia are the right middle and lower lobes, consistent with the findings in this case.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing TB granuloma: Tuberculosis typically presents with caseating granulomas, not foreign body granulomas as seen in this image. The clinical scenario also does not support TB.

 

Option C. Sarcoid granuloma: Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas, which differ from the foreign body granuloma seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. Severe fungal pneumonia: Fungal infections can cause granulomatous inflammation, but they typically present with necrotizing granulomas or other distinct histological features. The presence of foreign material is more indicative of aspiration pneumonia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Vegetative matter aspiration pneumonia can lead to the formation of foreign body granulomas, characterized by macrophages and lymphocytes surrounding the aspirated material. This condition is often associated with severe clinical outcomes, especially in debilitated patients.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No 1344

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is used for electrolyte estimation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lithium Heparin

 

  • Lithium Heparin is preferred for electrolyte testing because it does not interfere with the measurement of most electrolytes, such as sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is also the best anticoagulant for tests that require accurate pH, blood gases, electrolytes, and ionized calcium levels.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. EDTA: While EDTA is widely used for hematological examinations, it is not suitable for electrolyte estimation because it can chelate calcium and interfere with other ion measurements.

 

Option B. Citrate: Sodium citrate is primarily used for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, PTT) because it binds calcium ions to prevent clotting, but it is not ideal for electrolyte estimation.

 

Option C. Sodium Fluoride: Sodium fluoride is used primarily for glucose and lactate testing because it inhibits glycolysis, but it is not appropriate for electrolyte testing as it can interfere with the results.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is undergoing reconstructive surgery after trauma to the chest wall. During the procedure, the surgeon uses a muscle flap to cover a defect as shown in the image. Which flap is most likely being used in this reconstruction? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serratus anterior flap

 

The Serratus anterior flap is a widely used option for chest wall reconstruction, especially in cases involving trauma or oncologic resection. The muscle originates from the lateral surfaces of the upper 8–9 ribs and is inserted into the medial border of the scapula. It is innervated by the long thoracic nerve (C5, C6, C7) and supplied by the lateral thoracic artery (upper part) and the thoracodorsal artery (lower part). This flap can be rotated medially to cover large defects in the pectoral region, making it the flap of choice for lateral chest wall reconstruction in the described case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectoral myocutaneous flap: This flap is also used in chest wall reconstruction, but it primarily covers anterior chest defects. The described rotation pattern (lateral to medial) is more characteristic of the serratus anterior flap.

 

Option C. TRAM flap: The Transverse Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (TRAM) flap is usually employed in breast reconstruction, not chest wall defects, making it less relevant to this scenario.

 

Option D. VRAM flap: The Vertical Rectus Abdominis Myocutaneous (VRAM) flap is also used for breast or abdominal wall reconstruction and is not typically used for the chest wall, as suggested in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Serratus anterior flap is a versatile muscle flap used for chest wall reconstruction. It is often rotated medially to cover lateral or pectoral defects due to its excellent blood supply and robust arc of rotation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with generalized lymphadenopathy and fatigue. A biopsy of one of the lymph nodes reveals features suggestive of mantle cell lymphoma. Immunohistochemical staining shows the tumor cells are negative for Cyclin D1 expression. Which of the following immunohistochemical markers would be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis of Cyclin D1 negative mantle cell lymphoma? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SOX11

 

Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is typically characterized by the overexpression of Cyclin D1 due to the t(11;14) chromosomal translocation. However, a subset of mantle cell lymphomas are Cyclin D1-negative. In these cases, the SOX11 marker is often used for diagnosis. SOX11 is a transcription factor expressed in the majority of mantle cell lymphomas, including those that are negative for Cyclin D1. The presence of SOX11 helps distinguish mantle cell lymphoma from other lymphomas when Cyclin D1 is absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ITRA 1: ITRA 1 (Interferon-Inducible Transmembrane Protein 1) is not associated with mantle cell lymphoma. It has no diagnostic relevance in distinguishing Cyclin D1-negative mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Option C. MYD88: MYD88 mutations are most commonly associated with Waldenström's macroglobulinemia and certain types of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), not mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Option D. Annexin V: Annexin V is commonly used in studies of apoptosis (programmed cell death) but is not specific to mantle cell lymphoma and does not play a role in the diagnosis of Cyclin D1-negative cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SOX11 is an important immunohistochemical marker used to diagnose Cyclin D1-negative mantle cell lymphoma and has significant clinical relevance in confirming the diagnosis in the absence of Cyclin D1 expression.

choices.text: 1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain

questions.text: A 25-year-old immunology student is studying the effects of enzymatic digestion on immunoglobulins. She uses papain to cleave the immunoglobulin molecule. What are the resulting products after papain acts on an immunoglobulin? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

 

Papain is a proteolytic enzyme that cleaves immunoglobulin (Ig) molecules into specific fragments. When papain acts on an Ig molecule, it cleaves the Ig at a site above the hinge region, resulting in two Fab (Fragment antigen-binding) fragments and one Fc (Fragment crystallizable) fragment. The two Fab fragments retain the antigen-binding regions of the antibody, while the Fc fragment is responsible for effector functions such as binding to Fc receptors or activating complement. This cleavage results in the separation of the antigen-binding and effector regions of the antibody.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papain cleaves immunoglobulins to produce 2 Fab fragments and 1 Fc fragment, effectively separating the antigen-binding sites from the effector region of the antibody.

choices.text: B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

questions.text: Among the following, which cells express MHC class II molecules? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) B cells, dendritic cells, mononuclear phagocytes

 

MHC class II molecules are predominantly expressed on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as B cells, dendritic cells, and mononuclear phagocytes (macrophages). These cells present processed antigens to helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) and play a critical role in initiating immune responses by displaying fragments of ingested antigens for T cell recognition.

 

MHC molecules function by presenting protein fragments (peptides) on the surface of cells for recognition by T cells. In humans, MHC molecules are referred to as Human Leukocyte Antigens (HLA), which are encoded by genes on chromosome 6. HLA molecules are highly polymorphic, with thousands of different alleles existing in the human population, contributing to individual variations in immune responses and complicating organ transplantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NK cells: Natural Killer (NK) cells do not express MHC class II molecules. They play a role in innate immunity by recognizing stressed or infected cells that lack MHC class I expression and killing them without the need for antigen presentation.

 

Option B. All nucleated cells: While all nucleated cells express MHC class I molecules, only specific antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as B cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages express MHC class II molecules.

 

Option D. Platelets: Platelets do not express MHC class II molecules. They are primarily involved in clotting and do not function as antigen-presenting cells in immune responses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC class II molecules are expressed on professional antigen-presenting cells, such as B cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages, which are crucial for initiating immune responses by interacting with helper T cells.

choices.text: Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months
Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman has undergone successful treatment for breast cancer (1.2 x 1 cm tumor) with positive axillary nodes. She completed radiotherapy and chemotherapy and is now receiving tamoxifen. What is the appropriate follow-up plan for this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Annual mammogram

 

The appropriate follow-up for breast cancer survivors includes regular physical examinations and imaging with mammography. Mammograms are the key imaging modality used for surveillance following treatment for breast cancer. The current recommendation is to perform an annual mammogram to detect any recurrence or new breast malignancy.

 

Routine blood tests (including tumor markers or liver function tests) and other imaging studies like bone scans are not recommended for asymptomatic patients as part of routine surveillance. These are usually reserved for cases with clinical signs or symptoms suggesting recurrence or metastasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Regular checking of LFT once in 6 months: Liver function tests (LFTs) are not part of routine surveillance for breast cancer survivors unless the patient is on a medication that requires monitoring (e.g., tamoxifen can affect liver function, but LFTs are not recommended unless clinically indicated).

 

Option C. Follow-up with tumor markers once in 6 months: Tumor markers such as CA 15-3 or CEA are not recommended for routine follow-up in breast cancer patients, as their role in detecting early recurrence is not well-established.

 

Option D. Yearly bone scans: Bone scans are not recommended as routine follow-up unless there are symptoms suggestive of bone metastasis, such as bone pain or elevated alkaline phosphatase levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine follow-up for breast cancer survivors includes annual mammography and periodic physical exams. Other tests like tumor markers or bone scans are reserved for symptomatic patients or those with specific clinical concerns.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGE) was performed, and the biopsy results reveal the transition between normal squamous epithelium and mucin-filled glands, indicative of intestinal-type metaplasia with goblet cells. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barrett's esophagus

 

Barrett’s esophagus is characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus with intestinal metaplasia, including goblet cells. This condition arises due to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and is considered a premalignant state because it significantly increases the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma. The biopsy showing mucin-filled glands and goblet cells supports the diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagitis: Esophagitis involves inflammation of the esophagus, often due to acid reflux, but does not show the presence of intestinal metaplasia or goblet cells.

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: This type of esophageal cancer originates from the squamous epithelium, which would not show intestinal-type metaplasia or goblet cells.

 

Option C. Adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinoma can develop from Barrett’s esophagus but is characterized by malignant glandular structures, not just the presence of goblet cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus, characterized by intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells, is a premalignant condition that significantly increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma and warrants regular surveillance.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man had a fall followed by one episode of vomiting. When brought to the emergency department, he was awake and conscious but had persistent anterograde amnesia. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Concussion

 

The history of a fall followed by persistent anterograde amnesia strongly points to a diagnosis of concussion. Concussion is a mild traumatic brain injury (TBI) that commonly results from falls, vehicle accidents, or sports injuries. Anterograde amnesia, where the patient cannot recall events that occur after the injury, is a hallmark feature of a concussion. Other symptoms may include headache, dizziness, nausea, and vomiting. In most cases, patients recover fully with rest and conservative management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drunkenness: A person who is intoxicated would likely present with drowsiness or confusion, not an isolated anterograde amnesia while remaining awake and conscious.

 

Option B. Diffuse axonal injury: This condition results from high-speed deceleration leading to shearing of axons. It is associated with microhemorrhages and often leads to a persistent vegetative state rather than transient amnesia.

 

Option D. Cerebral venous thrombosis: This presents with symptoms such as headache, seizures, and visual disturbances due to acute thrombosis in the dural venous sinuses. It would not typically present with isolated amnesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterograde amnesia following a head injury is a hallmark of concussion, a common type of mild traumatic brain injury.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath that worsens throughout the day. Pulmonary function testing was performed, and the flow-volume loop from her spirometry is shown below (Patient 1). Based on the spirometry findings, what is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

 

Myasthenia gravis, a neuromuscular disorder, often presents with muscle weakness that worsens throughout the day. It affects the respiratory muscles, leading to a restrictive pattern on spirometry. The patient's spirometry shows a reduction in lung volumes such as total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity (VC), and residual volume (RV), which are typical in restrictive lung diseases caused by neuromuscular dysfunction, such as in myasthenia gravis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endobronchial neoplasm: Endobronchial tumors usually cause an obstructive pattern on spirometry. This is seen as an increased total lung capacity (TLC) and residual volume (RV), shifting the flow-volume loop to the left. The patient’s spirometry does not match this pattern.

 

Option B. Bronchial Asthma: Bronchial asthma typically presents with an obstructive pattern on spirometry due to airway narrowing. The flow-volume curve would shift to the left due to increased lung volumes, particularly residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC). The patient’s spirometry shows a restrictive pattern, not obstructive.

 

Option D Emphysema: Emphysema is another obstructive lung disease where hyperinflation causes increased residual volume (RV) and total lung capacity (TLC). This would shift the flow-volume loop to the left. The patient’s spirometry is more indicative of a restrictive disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that causes restrictive lung disease due to weakened respiratory muscles, leading to a reduction in lung volumes and a restrictive pattern on spirometry.

choices.text: Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly
Genital and oral painful ulcers
Glomerulonephritis and heart failure
Joint pains with nodules on skin

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with a history of backache and polyarthralgia. Immunofluorescence (IF) findings reveal a nucleolar pattern. Which of the following clinical features is most consistent with her condition? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly

 

The nucleolar pattern observed on immunofluorescence (IF) suggests systemic sclerosis, also known as sclerodactyly. This autoimmune condition often presents with Raynaud phenomenon and thickening of the skin, particularly affecting the fingers and hands (sclerodactyly). The nucleolar pattern reflects antibodies to RNA, commonly seen in sclerodactyly and other forms of systemic sclerosis. In limited systemic sclerosis, patients may develop a constellation of symptoms including Calcinosis, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia (CREST syndrome).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Genital and oral painful ulcers: These are characteristic of Behçet's disease, an inflammatory disorder that does not typically present with a nucleolar pattern on IF.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis and heart failure: These symptoms suggest systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or another vasculitis, which do not typically display a nucleolar pattern but rather a diffuse or speckled pattern on IF.

 

Option D. Joint pains with nodules on skin: This presentation is more typical of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with rheumatoid nodules and does not usually present with a nucleolar IF pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleolar pattern on immunofluorescence is most commonly associated with systemic sclerosis (sclerodactyly) and is often accompanied by features such as Raynaud phenomenon and skin thickening.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with progressive loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. She is diagnosed with a pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasma. Which of the following visual field defects is most likely in this patient? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bitemporal hemianopia

 

A lesion at the optic chiasma typically causes bitemporal hemianopia, where the patient loses vision in the outer (temporal) fields of both eyes. This occurs because the nasal fibers of the retina, responsible for the temporal visual fields, decussate (cross) at the optic chiasma. Compression of the chiasma, as in pituitary adenomas, interrupts this crossing and results in loss of the outer visual fields of both eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central scotoma: This refers to a loss of vision in the central field, usually seen in conditions affecting the optic nerve or macula, such as optic neuritis or macular degeneration.

 

Option B. Bilateral hemianopia: This term is nonspecific but can refer to homonymous hemianopia, a condition where vision is lost in the same side of the visual field in both eyes, usually due to a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma.

 

Option C. Binasal hemianopia: This is a rare visual defect that affects the inner visual fields (nasal fields) and typically occurs with bilateral compression of the optic nerves at the lateral chiasm, not the midline chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a neck swelling that moves with deglutition. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroglossal cyst

 

A thyroglossal cyst is a congenital anomaly that arises due to incomplete closure of the thyroglossal duct, which is the path of descent of the thyroid gland from the base of the tongue during embryonic development. The cyst typically presents as a midline neck swelling, and it classically moves with deglutition (swallowing) and tongue protrusion due to its attachment to the hyoid bone. This characteristic movement distinguishes it from other neck swellings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: This congenital anomaly occurs laterally, not in the midline, and does not typically move with deglutition. It results from failure of obliteration of the branchial clefts during embryonic development.

 

Option B. Cystic hygroma: A congenital lymphatic malformation often located in the posterior triangle of the neck, cystic hygromas do not move with swallowing or tongue protrusion.

 

Option D. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Swellings of lymph nodes do not move with deglutition or tongue protrusion and are typically found in lateral positions rather than midline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thyroglossal cysts are congenital midline neck swellings that move with deglutition and tongue protrusion due to their attachment to the hyoid bone. The treatment is Sistrunk’s operation, which involves excision of the cyst along with the entire thyroglossal tract and a portion of the hyoid bone.
